column10: Although there are some great ideas here and the story is supposed to be quite good, there are some major problems with the controls and combat systems that really hurt the overall experience. Unskippable encounter cutscenes in group fights get real annoying real fast, and the cheap shots from offscreen enemies or swarming the player with a sea of targets that obscure vision seem to be the main way encounters have been designed to add difficulty which mostly just makes for a frustrating time.

I really tried to give this one a chance. The previous game was really nice.
This is just a jumbled unfinished mess. Avoid unless you're extremely patient with the janky movement and terrible controls. You're going to die multiple times just because the game decided to jump up a wall instead of jumping over the enemy you're fighting.
 - So many cutscenes mid-fights. A captain appeared, a captain re-appeared. A captain amushed you.
 - Button prompts everywhere
 - Janky sluggish movement in combat
 - Terrible reaction to controls. You press the button prompt and so many times nothing happens
 - You're waiting for a button prompt to counter which never happens
 - The entire nemesis system is a huge annoyance this time around. Feels more like a tax than something you can have fun with.

+ Story is passable
+ Graphics are ok for when it came out
+ When it's not bogged down by the above, the stealth stabbing, sniping etc can be quite nice.

I can't, in good faith, recommend this game to anyone but the most patient people out there. Even though it has plenty of cool mechanics, a good story and characters, the lack of precision of the controls kills the experience for me. Trying to perform simple actions in this game is INFURIATING. Because of how key combinations work in this game, even if you were to change the bindings you would still have a frustrating time trying to do things like jumping, running, attacking, stealth, etc. 

I've lost count of the amount of times I tried to perform a ledge grab just to end up stabbing some random dude in the middle of enemy camp. Or when I tried to clamber up a wall, while looking at it, just to have Talion literally run the OPPOSITE direction and throw me in the face of an enemy captains trap. I lost a siege, after hours of preparation, because my bodyguard got stuck in a wall and I couldnt handle the sheer amount of enemies stunlocking me in place. 

It really feels like Monolith never learned anything from the problems that arose from the Batman games's combat mechanics. Since I wanted to fight Uruks and not the  goddamn controls, I'm giving up on this one.

I once stated that this game is my favorite single player title. While that was definitely the feeling I got after finishing it, time has passed and my taste in games changed, yet I got back into it to get all the missing achievements and play the story one more time just to discover that the game is as good as I remember and it's still up there in my top of best games ever made.
Shadow of War is exactly what a sequel should look like, you get what people loved about the previous game (Shadow of Mordor) and you improve every single aspect of it. The story, even if it's non canon, it was greatly improved. While the first one felt more of a prologue and an introduction for Talion's adventure, this one has multiple storylines that make it great, including a great ending where our Ranger is not banished from death anymore. It has, by far, the best mechanics you can find in any RPG title, with a very generous skill tree that lets you tremendously improve the combat experience from the beginning to the end. The story expansion DLCs were also amazing, Blade of Galadriel and Desolation of Mordor introduce new gameplay elements that are just as good as the main campaign, a little bit too short, but a great experience. This game also has the most underrated system in all of the gaming history: the Nemesis system that has such a huge depth and allows you to encounter unique enemies with their own personality leading to infinite replayability. 
Just to briefly show the complexity of the Nemesis system, here is a story from my latest playthrough: I was trying to get the achievement "Everything Is Permitted" where you need to Shame an Assassin until he becomes Deranged. I found one in Núrnen, I beat the crap out of him and shamed him. Than I tracked him down and when we met again, he received the title "The Unashamed" continuously moking that he can not be shamed. I beat him, shamed him again and tracked him down to shame him for the third time. After that he became Deranged and I got my achievement. Shortly after, he ambushed me, not being able to speak words anymore and I ended his misery. I thought that was it, but after many quests, I returned to Núrnen just to be ambushed by him after cheating death. I killed him one more time, but he had the perk for BloodBrother with one of my Orc Followers, meaning I was betrayed, so I had to kill his brother too. Time passed and I got ambushed by him again as he cheated death the second time. I decided to not kill him now, so instead I made him my bodyguard. After taking the fortress, I made him the Overlord so he can't bother me anymore. After finishing the game I decided to make him fight for his life in Fighting Pits and he died. He returned from the death once again and this time I couldn't dominate him, because he remembers how he died, having the Iron Will to resist. I need to mention that every single encounter he adapted and learned from his previous lives so I had to use new tricks to kill him.
I really wish to see another title from Monolith Studios in the future. I recommend this game with all my heart!

It's a shame the devs/team for this game are effectively gone and WB trademarked the idea of the "Nemesis System." Imagine if they were able to make another game with this system, not a sequel necessarily. How could they add to the system, polish it, and just how much fun would it be? 
I was complaining how this would never happen but someone said that there was a Wonder Woman game announced, but looking into it, it was announced AND NOTHING ELSE. It's been quite a while too... but I'm not holding my breathe.


I replayed this game (first run was on my PS4 at release) and frankly, it's still amazing. I had a particularly rough start since I played on the hardest difficulty (not Brutal) and kept dying. Thankfully, I managed to get past the start and start dying less. 
I don't understand what people complain about the plot. It immediately starts setting up something but kinda vaguely. What ends up happening is that it is leading up to a plot twist and even though I knew it was coming, I was still at the edge of my seat when I got to it. 

If I have a major complaint, it would be that picking up artifacts/relics/whatever in this game -> has a voice over thing that you get to listen to. It is relevant to the relic and adds lore and stuff. Good stuff! What's the complaint? No subtitles; and if you back out, it stops. It doesn't play until it gets interrupted (that would make sense) or something... it just stops.

Something that happened to be me in my original PS4 run, and I'm remembering this very clearly, is that there was a certain captain with Iron Will. I killed this jerk over and over and over and over again, including decapitating him, but he would revive and revive and are you kidding me? I thought decapitating him permanently solves this problem? I got lucky that he was dazed with execution attacks, so he was an annoyance more than anything. I dubbed this as the "Persistent Captain."
Some time after I finished this game (original run), I saw other people's "Persistent Captains" and I was jelly because mine was kinda dumb and could only brag about how he is like Talion - with the ability to come back no matter how many times I killed him... also his weakness kinda ruined things. Someone else got a poet of sorts as their Persistent Captain and I was quite jelly of that one in particular. 
And... I didn't get a "Persistent Captain" in this run. Maybe it was the difficulty or something?


Anyway, in conclusion, I highly recommend this game and the prequel, Shadow of Mordor. You can get both for incredibly cheap price during the sale - including all the DLC - and I highly recommend both. With the exceptions of hating Lord of the Rings and/or Batman Arkham Style combat, everyone should enjoy these games very much.

This is one of the best RPGs I have ever played

Pros
THE NEMESIS SYSTEM is very good and gives near infinite replay value (random generated orcs with stories)

Very cuul finishers

The skills are actually interesting with interesting modifiers, you also get them in just the right ammount

Cons:

Enemies are randomly generated, meaning you can (rarely) get stuck on an orc because they don't have a weakness

You can easily forget what you were doing or get interrupted by an orc ambush (it can be fun at the start)

When you get killed by an orc they level up, meaning it's even harder to kill them next time, however this can allow you to level them on purpose

Conclusion: Vevy cool game that predicted the recent AI trend in gaming and is actually good

After diving into this game, I felt like I was on a journey longer than Frodo's, but with less walking and more orc-smashing. At first, I was hesitant, like a hobbit trying to leave the Shire, but once I started, I couldn't stop. It's like finding the One Ring of entertainment – addictive and precious.

The UI felt like trying to decipher Elvish at first, but once I got the hang of it, I was slaying orcs like a pro. Just remember, this ain't "Shadow of Mordor," it's a whole new beast.

If you're a Tolkien fan, consider this game a second breakfast – you won't regret it. Just be prepared for some bugs that make Shelob's lair look like a picnic spot. And watch out for those pesky uruks – they're more hacked than Sauron's social media.

Graphics? Good. Gameplay? Good. Audio? Good, but be careful, you might end up deaf from all the orc screams. And let's not forget the PC requirements – it'll eat up more space than a Balrog in a hobbit hole.

As for difficulty, it's easier than making a hobbit-sized bed. And the grind? Well, let's just say you might need more than one life to finish it.

The story? Like a hobbit tale – good but not exactly epic. But who needs a story when you're building your own orc army?

Overall, it's a game worth playing, even if it means neglecting your responsibilities like a hobbit avoiding second breakfast. I'd give it an 8/10 – just watch out for those pesky bugs and hacked uruks!

Destiny-fied Arkham City, but worse in every way. Whatever the potential there was in combat and nemesis system was squandered by shoe-horned in terrible item progression, where the only worthwhile stat is item level. It makes it so either your number is big enough and you can engage an enemy, or your number is too low and you will get one-shot no matter what. As such, what could have been a decent "yet another open world action game" was turned into a lazy "live service-like" product with all of the downsides of being such and none of the merits. Adding to all this is very poor, fanfic-level story that you will forget the moment you turn the game off. 

Just play Arkham City instead.

This game is joining the very short and exclusive list of games I've given up on. Loved the first one, but this one just isn't there. The only way I can think to summarize it is that this game does everything in its power to pull you out of the experience.

The combat is basically just spam left click until it tells you to counter with a right click. Five hours in, and I still can't figure out what the story is actually about. The nemesis system is a cool idea and felt great with the first game, but, with this game, it's wildly annoying. It gives you unskippable, overlong cutscenes that interrupt the already non-engaging combat every three seconds to introduce yet another orc you'll forget five seconds later. Oh, and if that orc has an entourage, all those orcs get to rant and extend the cutscene, too. 

Do you like menus? Because you're getting menus. A LOT of menus. The menus have menus. Seriously. 

The game might get better later on, but those first five hours were horrendous enough to stop me from ever finding out.

Here's what you can expect from this game if you decide to check it out

2. A lot of great laughs from the silly Orc's & Wacky Physics
3. And if your so inclined, this game will give you a difficult challenge of your Skill, Patience & Critical Thinking skills if you choose to play on Brutal or Gravewalker difficulty

Sadist simulator. Combat is engaging except for the scripted boss fights.

If you're on the fence about it, just buy this game. Across Console, and Steam, I've got countless hours in it, and you're really not required to play one way or another. You are free to use combat, stealth, ranged, or some combo of all of them. You're also free to rely on your captains, or banish them if you'd like.

[b]Defining Feature (10/10): [/b]
The Nemesis System remains the game's crowning achievement, compelling me to return even after completing the main storyline. The endless battles of Act 4: Shadow Wars offer a infinite loop of randomly generated orcs to defeat. Each orc captain, with their unique blend of strengths and weaknesses, presents a fresh challenge that demands strategic consideration, significantly influencing the outcome of every encounter.

[b]Combat (9/10):[/b]
The combat system offers an unparalleled level of satisfying brutality. Execution animations are exquisitely designed, setting a high bar for action games. The variety of combat strategies enriches the gameplay experience; whether it's storming into battle atop a dragon, employing stealth to ambush your foe, poisoning enemy provisions, or unleashing monsters upon orc gatherings, the possibilities feel boundless. My sole critique lies in the health allocation on the brutality difficulty setting. Despite equipping level 80 legendary armor, certain orc captains possess the ability to defeat you with a single blow, but typically as long as you don't get hit then you'll be the one dealing serious damage to your foes.

[b]The Quests (6/10):[/b]
While the quests themselves are well-crafted, featuring engaging cutscenes and gameplay, my grievance lies with the portrayal of non-orc characters. Their selfishness and questionable decision-making have led to a disconnect, making me empathize more with the orcs—my intended adversaries—than with these allies. This irony detracts from the narrative's emotional engagement.

[b]Conclusion:[/b]
Overall, the game stands out for its innovative Nemesis System, exhilarating combat mechanics, and a diverse approach to gameplay. While the combat experience is nearly flawless, offering a variety of thrilling ways to engage with the enemy, the difficulty balance on higher settings and the characterization of non-orc characters in the quests could be improved. Despite these minor setbacks, the game delivers a rich and immersive experience that keeps players engaged long after the main storyline concludes. It's a testament to the game's depth and the developers' creativity, making it a must-play for fans of the genre.

The story is shockingly flat. The best things about this game are what was already present in Shadow of Mordor and the worst things about it are things that were added for the sequel. Honesty, the Nemesis system is still fun and it's entertaining to besiege fortresses. However, the quests are so utterly dumbed down that it feels like working off a mindless to-do list. The characters are so utterly bland that it's often a pain to hear them speak and the direction they took the overall story is insulting to Tolkiens original work. Quite frankly, every single writer should be fired and banned from the profession. Mechanics are good, graphics are not up to today's standards and while I'm not much of a graphics connoisseur, it looks like they didn't age well either.

[b] HİKAYE [/B]
Oyunun hikayesi ilk oyundan direkt sonrasında başlıyor. İlk oyundaki amacına ulaşan Talion'u daha büyük bir görev beklemektedir. Artık yenmesi gereken kişi Sauron'dur.  Hikayenin skalası yani en azından konu olarak ilk oyuna göre daha büyük ama sadece konu olarak. Bu konuyu oyunda iyi işlediklerini söyleyemem. Daha doğrusu diğer oyunlarla kıyaslarsak bunu söyleyebiliriz. İlk oyunla kıyaslarsak baya seviye atlamışlar. Hikayenin başı ortası ve sonu var en azından ufak tefek kırıkları olsa da. Bu seri için güzel gelişmeler olabilir ama ortalama bir oyunla kıyaslarsak vasat kalan bir taraf. Başlarda hikaye güzel açıldı. Baktım herhalde saracak bir şeyler yaptılar dedim. Sonra oyunun ikinci kısmı başladı ki bu oyunun yüzde seksenini kaplayan kısım. Oyundan bir anda koptum. Oyun aynı ilk oyun gibi açık dünya da şunu yaptan bunu yapa döndü. Bunun sebebi belirli bir ana hikaye çizgisi olmaması. Oyunda bir sürü ana görev çeşidi var ve istediğiniz zaman istediğnizi yapabiliyorsunuz. Bu da en sonunda ana hikayenin yarım hisettirmesini sağlıyor. Final ise şaşırtıcı. Kesinlikle beklemediğim bir finaldi. Öyle çok muhteşem olduğunu söyleyemem ama beni şaşırttığı için çok kötü de diyemiyorum.

[b] OYNANIŞ [/B]
Oynanış temel hatlarıyla ilk oyunla aynı. Savaşması ve gizli gitmesi hala eğlenceli. Vuruş hissiyatı çok çok daha iyi olmuş. Özellikle yeni bitiriş hareketleriyle çok güzel olmuş gerçekten. Arkham mekaniklerini kullanan dövüş sistemi akıcı ve güzel. Özellikle karakter geliştirmeyle açtığımız yeni yeni özellikler ile çok daha çeşitli ve eğlenceli oluyor. Sadece yakın savaş için değil ok ve gizlilik için de var rpg tarafında değineceğiz. Gizlilik ilk oyunla aynı. Güzel hoş. Öyle yine bir hitman dishonored değil ama zevk veriyor en azından. Canavar sürme seçenekleri arttırılmış. İlk oyundan bildiğimiz Caragorlar dışında ejderha falan gelmiş oyuna. Ki kontrolleri aşırı kötü. Bu kadar kötü hayvan sürme mekanikleri yapılamazdı. Sadece ejderha için değil genel anlamda bütün sürüş mekanikleri için. Parkur mekanikleri ise değişime uğraşmış. İlk oyuna göre çok daha akıcı ama bildiğin Assassin's Creed olmuş bu sefer. AC oyunlarının o insanı kanser eden parkur mekanikleri aynen var. Sağa basarsın sola atlar aniden damdan düşer falan. Akıcı olmakla beraber bu sinir bozucu kontrol saçmalıkları duruyor. Ancak en büyük eksi animasyonların aşırı robotik olması. Akıcılığı doğru düzgün animasyonlarla sağlamak yerine öylesine uğraşıp geçmişler. Normal şartlar altında yapamayacağınız zıplamaları karakter havayken bir anda kendine +20 Speed basmış gibi bir anda atlıyor. Bunu yedirememişler o kadar bariz zorlama olduğu gözüküyor ki baya batıyor. Şahsen daha hantal ama daha iyi gözüken ve hissettiren ilk oyunun parkur mekaniklerini tercih ederim. Kısacası Aksiyon tarafı daha iyi olmuş. Gizlilik aynı. Parkur kötü değil ama ilk oyunu tercih ederim.

[b] AÇIK DÜNYA [/B]
Açık dünya güzel değil. Aynı ilk oyun gibi. Oyunun ilk kısmında oyuna bir şehirde başlıyoruz. Dedim herhalde bu defa boş boş çayırda koşmak yerine daha doğru düzgün, açık dünyaya benzeyen bir açık dünyamız var diyordum. İkinci kısım başladı ve oyun yine çayır çimene döndü. Bu seferki harita çok büyük. Galiba bütün Mordor var. İşte karlı harita var ormanlı var çöl olan var bir sürü harita var. Bu gibi taraflar dışında hissiyat olarak hiçbir farkları yok. Hepsi birbirinin aynısı. Sadece kostüm değiştirmiş hali gibi hissettiriyor. Haritalar bu defa ilk oyuna göre daha dar olmuşlar. Saniye başı düşman görüyorsunuz. Bu sürekli bir top sesi bir savaş bağırma çağırma arkanızdan koşan 600 kişi demek oluyor. Sadece sizin olduğunuz yerde de değil. Uzaklardan da top sesi duyuyorsunuz. Yani bu insanı 40 saat boyunca aşırı yoruyor. Salında azıcık nefes alalım diyor insan. Tipik açık dünya elementleri bu oyunda da var. Çok tekrar ediyorlar. Görevler kısmında detaya gireceğim. Canlı da değil açık dünya. Oyun alanı gibi hissettirmeye devam ediyor. O görevden bu göreve koşup durduğumuz bir oyun havuzu. Genel hatlarıyla ilk oyunla aynı olan kötü bir açık dünya var ancak bir etken var ki çok iyi olan. Yine Nemesis sitemi. Nemesis sistemi ilk oyuna göre daha iyi olmuş. Daha detaylı, daha çok taktik içeren daha doğal bir sistem olmuş. Artık sadece siz gidip şefleri öldürmüyorsunuz. Onlar da size aniden saldırabiliyor, esir alabiliyor ya da size ihanet edebiliyorlar. Çok daha iyi olmuş ve bu beni baya eğlendirdi. 7-8 saat boyunca aralıksız bu nemesis sistemiyle uğraştığım günler oldu. Aslında ilk oyunla hemen hemen aynı şeyleri yazdım. Açık dünya kötü ve nemesis sistemi eğlenceli.

[b] GÖREVLER [/B]
Görevler kötü. Yine. İlk oyuna göre daha iyiler. Yani görevler iyi olduğu için değil verdiği ödüller yüzünden. 200-300 XP almak yerine legendary item alıyorsunuz ondan insanın hepsini yapası geliyor onun dışında vasatlar. Yan görevler dehşet derecede tekrar ediyorlar. İlk oyun kısa olduğu için baymıyordu ama 40 saat boyunca aynı şeyi yapmak o kadar baydı ki bir yerden sonra oyunu bir saat bile oynayamıyordum. Tek iyi yanları ödüllerinin çok daha iyi olması yoksa ilk oyuna aynılar. Ana görevler de aynı. Hiç güzel değiller. Yani arada farklı şeyler yaptıran görevler var ama onlar da öyle muhteşem değiller. Tek iyi olan ana görev içinde doğru düzgün bir boss savaşı barındıran görev. Oyundaki bosslar kötüler. İlk oyunla aynı ama orada çok batmamıştı. Burada baya battı. Doğru düzgün bir tane var. O da öyle çok muhteşem mi değil. Ama çeşitlilik açısından ve en azından bir tane boss savaşı var olması açısından iyi. Görevler yine ilk oyunla aynı derecede. Bir de oyuna bir kale ele geçirme ve savunma görevleri var. Yani ilk duyduğumda o kadar heyecanlandım ki. Kaleler kocamanlar çünkü. O kadar epik saldırma savunma görevleri yapılabilirdi ki... Yapamamışlar. Baya hayal kırıklığı oldu o kale ele geçirme görevleri. Oyunu yapanlar arasında hiç kimse Yüzüklerin Efendisi filmlerini izlememiş olsa gerek.

[b] RPG [/B]
Artık bu tarz oyunlara RPG deniyor. RPG tarafını konuşursak. Yani öyle sıradan bir RPG oyununa göre baya az RPG var aslında oyunda. Sadece karakter geliştirme ve armor setleri, item toplama falan var. Bir de orada burada bir şeylerin seviyesi var. Gelişim güzel ilk oyundan iyi. Itemlarda fena olmamışlar dediğim gibi görevleri yapma isteğini uyandırıyorlar. Ancak onun dışında bir pısırık kalıyor RPG tarafı. Dying Light bile bundan daha çok RPG olabilir.

[b] TEKNİK[/B]
Buglar mevcut. Çoğu grafiksel. Bir keresinde oyunumu kıran bir bug ortaya çıktı bütün bölümü baştan yapmak zorunda kaldım. Optimizasyon fena değil.

[b] SONUÇ[/B]
Oynanışın sağlam ve Nemesis Sistemi'nin oyunu dinamik tutması dışında oyunun hiçbir iyi tarafı yok. Hikaye , açık dünya tasarımı, hissiyatı, içeriği, ana ve yan görevler rezalet ötesi. Biraz da ilk oyunla çok benzemesi durumu var. Yani meh.

[b] 6.2 / 10[/B]

I wanted to like this game so badly after loving shadow of mordor, but I just couldn't do it.
The major reasons:

-The game suffers from imprecise controls: this is incredibly important because most important attacks are directly targeted. Sometimes you might be trying to assassinate/dominate an important target and instead sprint 20 feet to drop off an edge or target an orc that is so far to the side they aren't even on your screen. 

-Unfair targeting/autofocus: The game has a lot of autofocus events, like when a captain of any allegiance dies. Enemy captains can target you during this autofocus, and while they can't damage you during the autofocus, they can hit you the exact moment you come out of it. This isn't typically an issue until late/post game, like during the shadow wars. Assassins have the no chance ability and can one-shot you in the late game, leading to incredibly frustrating and unfair deaths.

-Garbage AI in fight pits: This isn't really something that affects the main storyline until the shadow wars or postgame/online, but is frustrating nonetheless. You can pick the best counter to the enemy orc in the fight pits that's 20 levels higher, then be forced to watch helplessly as  he stands there doing literally nothing for a minute and a half until he dies, or he will miss every shot if ranged. It doesn't happen every fight, but it feels like a 50/50 after you've chosen the best possible counter. For a game that emphasizes picking your engagements based on strengths and weaknesses, it's pretty pathetic.

Shadow of war is a good game and is an improvement from shadow of mordor in terms of the nemesis system and combat. now allied orcs have a chance to betray you and trolls are now added to the nemesis system. also there is new abilities orcs can have depending on class and clans witch is new to the game. there is couple issues with this game one is the games open world which is divided into different regions that you have to fast travel in order to get to. another issue is that yet again the same open world design from the first game is here and it seems kind of worse in shadow of war. The biggest issue is that the regions in this game feel exactly the same just re-skinned and in shadow of war they are much harder to navigate since the layout of the open world regions are more poorly designed. another major issue is that the open world is mainly populated with orcs and trolls and there is no humans, dwarfs, elves, or even hobbits in the open world. also there is no additional save files even though this was a feature in the first game. also why isn't there a new game plus. I also hate that you can mind control orcs that are a higher level than you even though that was possible in the first game although orcs in the first game.  also the game kind of looks graphically worse than the first game. I still highly recommend the game because of the improve nemesis system and the combat.

Best way for me to describe this game is that it's similar to the previous game Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor in the sense that Middle-earth: Shadow of War is a fast paced 3rd person melee/archery combat, action-adventure based upon the Lord of The Ring franchise, with the lore working with the films and books. 

The game is very fun & double the size of Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor, which for me,means double the play-time.
Although the game can be repetitive in some places, it's in no way tedious. You won't help but feel immersed in the story, even if it is a bit slow to start off with. 

The story itself is very long, and completing the main story (plus side quests/fortress defence/relic collection) has taken me 50+ hours. The game can also be absolutely hilarious at points, making me laugh when I least expected it.

Even if your not much of a fan of the Lord of the Rings films or books like me, this game is still very fun to play, but I do recommend playing the original Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor to get more of an understanding of the backstory for this game. 

100% Completionists will find this game to be a challenge, but in no way impossible, just very time consuming.
I do however think that the game lacks replayability, but that's just down to the slight repetitiveness of the game itself and shouldn't be looked at badly for it.

(This review was written before completion of DLC's, so there is still plenty to do after 50 hours of game-play).

Shadow of War is very of its time. My biggest issue with the game is pacing, in a variety of ways.

Everything in this game takes too long. Areas feel slightly larger than they need to be, making traversal feel like a chore. Nemesis introductions can often go for 30 or even 60 seconds, completely destroying the game flow (especially if one of these wordy idiots shows up in the middle of a combat encounter). Ground finishers take so long they're basically useless unless you spend a point on a skill to speed them up. These and other problems are all small on their own, but together they combine to create an experience that just doesn't feel as fun as it should be.

I had some fun with this because I'm weird, and -might- play the DLC's.  But I cannot in good faith recommend it to anyone. [I purchased this on sale for 7 dollars, paying full price is a rip off in my mind.]

So here we go, my time with Lord of the Jank: Shadow of Bloat

Bloated as hell. Not the good kind either, lots of quests are super repetitive and feel like zero thought was put into them. Three quests in a row in the Carnan storyline have you run around spamming E to destroy totems, just one of countless examples.

Worst keybind optimization I've seen in 20 years of gaming, you change one bind and it'll assign 6-7 other things to that keybind. Designed for a controller, mouse/keyboard is a complete afterthought.

Weird sounds, example: Elven rage, sometimes there is just no sound, bunch of weirdo "swoooooosh" animations that feel incredibly janky. When Caligrimbor is talking during gameplay it sounds like a whisper, can barely hear it even with my volume up to max then other times it's fine. Like, ???

Often times the game won't even react to the button you press at all.

Mechanics/skills given to you overwhelmingly fast with no time to master any of them. And of that endless list of skills, less than half of them feel actually fleshed out / useful.

Fight pits are a boring joke, you just watch two NPCs smack each other with underwhelming attacks.

Can't skip any dialogue in Orc encounters. [Trust me, after awhile you'll want to.]

Character frequently gets stuck trying to vault over tiny objects, or when you are in a sprint you will sometimes automatically latch onto a random wall.

Targeting executions is almost impossible during group fights, I cannot tell you how many times my character just killed a random NPC instead of the damage sponge I'm actually trying to kill

Difficulty has absolutely zero consistency.

I've seen a lot of praise about the Nemesis system but honestly the game throws so many of these npcs at you, you'll be hard pressed to recognize any of them much less actually like/hate them.

Story is all over the place, I'm no LOTR lore expert but I know a mess when I see it.

After 23 hours I safely assure you that the jank never goes away, it'll stay with you for the entire game.

At least the Balrog fight was fun.

Ended up watching the final cut scene on Youtube because of how needlessly grindy the game is.

As good as this game looks and as good as it plays I cannot recommend it. Everything is tedious and confusing.  The PC controls are all over the place.

Failure is too punishing. It feels like time spent failing is time wasted.
Success is easily undone and often seems impossible. The army system makes it seem like it's worth fighting captains, commanders, and war chiefs but they just keep coming back.

The gear is boring. There are no damage numbers and everything takes the same amount of work to kill regardless of what I seem to be wearing. 

But the main reason I cannot recommend it is the unskippable orc monologues. You can't get into a flow of combat because every 5 seconds some orc captain or commander somehow pauses the entire battle to give a 20 second speech. The story is pretty bland too. I really wanted to like it but after playing all day I feel like my character is weaker and the things I like doing (collecting things, fighting) are less relevant.

I really want to like this game but after the story the system gets so boring and repetitive. You run into the same traits constantly and combat becomes a mind-numbingly boring affair. It boils down to 3 issues the fact that theres only 2 or three ways to play combat late in the game because of the "adaptation" system, horrible enemy targeting and the huge disparity between captain traits. 

Enemies can "adapt" to half the attacks in the game while the other half of attacks have no such stopping mechanic. So things like dodging by jumping over an enemy captain or stunning an enemy captain can suddenly become unusable mid-fight. Combine this with the fact that many of the counter-able attacks in the game are listed as the ONLY reliable method to deal with certain enemies (stunning for savages and jumping over them for shield captains) makes me feel like the devs are punishing you for learning and using the mechanics that THEY added to the game. Its frustrating, uninteractive, and should really have been a toggle-able feature because it kills diversity of playstyle.

On the captain disparity front it a matter of fun dialogue based captains often being worthless as opponents. The weakness traits can just completely ruin a captain as an opponent or as a follower. The terrified trait being the biggest one, and on the other side of the game captain fights, which are one of the primary replayability aspects of the game, usually boil down to who has a trait that only a player can trigger (mogwai flies, stealth, fear of higher level). 

The main thing this game has going for it is the incredible pokemon-like system of followers. I cannot emphasize enough what an incredible job the voice actors, art designers, and visual effects team have done for this game. Characters feel interesting and dynamic and the only issues with them (long, unskippable, repetitive monologues) are entirely on the shoulders of the gameplay design and coding team.

As is often the case with newer games from big companies it feels like the game design team is abysmal and makes such arbitrary lazy balance decisions while the art and story team have made an amazing product. Because of this the only way I can justify this game to someone is to buy it during a sale as its a triple A art title but a worse than overwatch balance title.

One of the best game i have ever played. Even when you are not big fan of Lord of the Rings you can really enjoy this game.
Many enemies with various strenghts and weaknesess of warchiefs and captains lead you to create some tactical aproach. Stealth in game is amazing and combat system breathtaking. Even when you are surrounded by enemies you can fight through them. Skill tree is pretty good, when you choose/buy skill then you can buy some "upgrade", for each skill is 3 possible upgrades and pretty significant one. Armor sets you collect via gameplay, bonuses and change of player appearance from theese are big plus. Gems have basically same atribute from start, you can upgrade them for bigger bonuses but thats all. Where i spend many hours is arena, where you can pick one captain from your army to fight against some enemy captain(probably random generated). Even when you dont control this fight it is very funny watch theese. Conquering fortresses were great experience, amazing big battle that i can say is unique. For each fortress you have to capture few control points, which are guarded by few enemy captains and you cant face a warlord(owner of the fortress) until you dont defeat other enemy captains. I might describe it little confusing but it is really easy and enjoyable.
About story-i cant say a single bad word on it. It was absolutly amazing story line,  Maybe little long but i definetly enjoy it. Didnt play such a great storyline a loong time ago. They did amazing job.
About DLC:
Blade of Galadriel: story related short DLC, skill three is different from base game. It was fun, but base game with Tallion is simply best.
Desolation of Mordor: just bad dlc,story isnt bad but not great either, pain to play sometime. Torwin from 1st game=Shadow of Mordor, amazing hunter and great character is here empty and inventor some gadgets for you. If this dlc wouldnt be in game, it would be better experience for me.

The game stands out for its innovative Nemesis system, which creates a unique dynamic in each match, where interactions with specific enemies can generate rivalries and personalized stories.
The game offers a vast and detailed open world, full of side quests, fortresses to conquer and secrets to discover.
The Middle-earth setting is faithfully recreated, offering a deep immersion for fans and new players alike.
The graphics are of high quality, with impressive landscapes and a detailed visual representation of the characters and creatures from Tolkien's universe.
The gameplay is refined, combining elements of stealth, combat and strategy. The combat system is fluid and rewarding, with a variety of skills and weapons at the player's disposal.
The strategic aspect of building and leading armies to conquer fortresses adds an extra layer of depth to the game.

Extremely Bad: [b]Unskippable dialogues[/b] with enemy captains. The taunting, humiliation, or cutscenes of defeat or victory are enjoyable at first, but after a while they become somewhat tiresome. It would be ideal if there was either a menu option to permanently disable them (as some other people have suggested) or just a key to skip them -- the most sensible and common option. Unfortunately, neither exists at the moment of writing this review.

Bad: [b]Glitchy and intertwined run/jump/dodge mechanics[/b]. A sad side-effect of assigning multiple vital (normally discrete) actions to the same key (SPACE for keyboard players). I understand that this smooths out -- to a degree -- the learning curve for new or inexperienced players, but at the cost of granular player control and a more sophisticated gameplay.

Bad: [b]Poor targetting while fighting a mob[/b]. While targetting individual orcs for shadow striking or arrow shooting works like a charm and is super accurate, picking individual enemies to dominate or drain from a surrounding mob proves to be very problematic and usually you will end up picking the wrong target.

Good (or bad, depending on your OCD levels): There is a [b]multitude of collectibles[/b] that will excite hoarders and collectors alike.

Good: [b]Socketable gear[/b] and [b]upgradable gems[/b]. Your armor and weapons can be enhanced by inserting different types of gems into them, which drop randomly from enemies. Moreover, you can combine lesser gems into greater forms (Diablo-style).

Good: online vendettas where you take revenge for other players' deaths and gain treasure chests

Very Good: Allies that fight on your side and command them

Very Good: challenges on inventory items to unlock extra properties on them and make them more satisfying because you feed that you earned them rightfully.

Extremely Good: Multiple locations where you can unleash your killing sprees.

Extremely Good: Great variation of enemy traits, ranks, personalities, even clans.

All in all, a good purchase in general and a must-have during steam sales. It will leave a slight bitter taste for players who have tried the superior combat mechanics of SoM, but will promptly wash it down with ample Orc blood.

So, this game is not good. In fact, it's bad. The game is trying to emulate the Assassin's Creed formula but it falls flat on a number of features. The main character is clunky as hell. He often gets stuck in the environment and has trouble locking onto an orc captain. I can't tell you how many times I've tried to stealth kill a captain but an orc grunt gets in the way to take the hit. The main character is flat out terrible at combat. The skills needed to fight are slow or take time to charge the might meter to actually use the attack. Often times, the orc captains are immune to many attacks so it's annoying to even fight them head on. The story is lackluster and the management system is interesting, but unrewarding for the time commitment to raise your orc army.

With all that said, this game has one redeeming quality - slaying orcs. That part never gets old. This game should just be called Orc Slayer.

Easily one of the most enjoyable single player games I have ever played. It's super easy to stop playing for months or even years and pick it right back up. There are plenty of side quests, lots of cool hidden artifacts, and always something to do if you're just bored and only have a few minutes to play. It takes forever to progress but doesn't get boring because the difficulty increases dramatically which I love. If you like games like assassins creed, elden ring, or even Destiny or Destiny 2, you will love this game. You DO NOT need to enjoy the Middle Earth books or the Lord of the Rings series to play this either. I hate both of them and love this game. BUY IT!

This game expands on the nemesis system from the first game and focuses more on large scale battles, managing captains and keeps, and gives you regions to conquer. Regions are slightly diversified offering a nice change in landscape but overall its the same orc strongholds repasted into a different biome. The world is much prettier than the first game, it's enjoyable to run around freely in the world and having a nice backdrop no matter where you're at. Even with the expansion of the nemesis system and the world conquering stuff, it didn't lose what made the first game fun, which is the combat and the interactions with orcs and the world. You'll run through the areas you dont have markers at and streamline the quests and interesting parts. It's well balanced, sometimes you will feel overwhelmed against certain strongholds or bosses if you didnt take the time to plan out your assault earlier. You can still solo everything in the game by parkouring away into stealth and cheesing most of the time, but its alot easier to isolate targets in advance and craft a plan of action. Its good fun for a while but like the first game the story is a bit too long. It's worth a buy but the formula gets old after a while and the story is mediocre. 

TLDR buy on sale expect one playthrough and 100% it

I have fully 100% this game on console and now I wanted to try it on my new PC and I just love this game and will be 100% it here on steam too. This game I think is a masterful blend of both canon and non canon from Tolkien's works. I love the story from when Talion's story begins to its end. The nemesis system keeps me coming back for more never truly making me tire from the fantastic orcs you meet in the game. Although it may be frustrating at times I strongly recommend you playing the game on Gravewalker difficulty so you can fully experience the nemesis system at its best, the other difficulty's feel too easy and I don't feel like i'm getting all it can give on them. Yes the combat can get slightly repetitive, but the awesome ability and powers you get from the wraith side of it make it a thing I can overlook. I absolutely love this game and recommend it to anyone who wishes to give it a try

[b]Pros[/b]
+ Beautiful graphics, cinematic cutscenes, and immersive world
+ Fluid combat (including animations) and modern skill progression
+ The Nemesis System guarantees unique allies and enemies 

[b]Cons[/b]
- Main campaign becomes a long grind at the end
- Missions become repetitive, as there are only a few categories
- Movement is clunky at times

[b]Conclusion[/b]
I recommend this game to everyone! [i]Middle-Earth: Shadow of War[/i] has an immersive open world, fluid combat mechanics, and unique story arcs that will leave you wanting more.

Wonderful story-line, fantastic game. The nemesis system to this day is still unique and my only gripe is that it hasn't been used (to my knowledge) passed this game. I've heard ramblings of a Wonder Woman title?? But I Digress. I recently did a run through 5 years later and the graphics still hold up. Would definitely recommend. Because it is a sequel to Shadow of Mordor, you may get a little confused with the story at first but doesn't detract from the game at all.

I did not think I would enjoy this as much as I did. The gameplay loop is fairly simple and repetitive - you fight Orcs and a few kinds of beasts, run and jump around and later build your own army, with a bit of story sprinkled in. But the combat and movement are really smooth and satisfying, it does a great job of making you feel like a true force to be reckoned with as you progress. The Orcs are fun and interesting, both personality and combat wise. Nemesis system is the highlight, and along with the possibility to manage your own Orc army and conquer fortresses it provides for a unique experience. Area design is solid and each one feels distinct, at least visually. Story is serviceable.
My only advice for best experience would be not to hard-press yourself to finish the epilogue grind and simply just play for however long you're having fun - it's not ideal, but consider looking up the final cutscene online instead if it becomes tedious.

[h3]How you think you'll die playing this game:[/h3]
[list]
    [*]Enemies using clever tactics to outsmart you.
    [*]Enemies playing to their advantages.
[/list]

[h3]How you'll [b]actually[/b] die playing this game:[/h3]
[list]
    [*]You'll be screwed over constantly by the parkour system, examples:
		[list]
			[*]Talion will sometimes decide to randomly jump off buildings into groups of enemies, instead of the nearby beam you were aiming at.
			[*]Talion likes standing still in the middle of combat and temporarily ignoring player input every now and then.
			[*]Talion will sometimes keep running back up the wall you dropped down from when you're trying to run away from it, the only way to stop this is to wait for Talion to slowly turn away from the wall then hold space again.
			[*]Talion likes to climb up buildings when you're not even aiming at them, so archers can hit you easier, or so fleeing enemies can get away.
		[/list]
	[*]The combat is pretty broken too at times:
		[list]
			[*]You go to drain an enemy and the game refuses to do anything and they hit you.
			[*]Enraged captains travel 50m in one sword swing somehow and hit you.
			[*]A captain may have an unblockable and instantaneous special attack which is literally impossible to dodge.
			[*]You use Wraith Stun on a Captain and they completely ignore it and hit you.
			[*]You use Shoulder Tackle on a Captain and they completely ignore it and hit you (in this case the game will sometimes even outright ignore your key presses so you cant do the move).
			[*]You blow up a barrel next to a captain and go to ground takedown him, what does the game do? Targets the grunt orc thats like 20m away instead. Applies to executions sometimes too.
			[*]Ranged and melee attacks with zero prompt at all (no I wasnt stunned or poisoned), this is actually the most annoying for me since this issue was never in SoM at all (not that the other issues weren't, but SoM was so mind-numbingly easy I might've never noticed them if they were there).
		[/list]
[/list]

Played this game for probably 100-200 hours on play station when it first came out and I wanted to buy it again just to experience it again, the story is sub par and as someone who hasn't watched lord of the rings I understand none of it, but the game-play. The game-play is so good I can sit here for hours just playing the conqueror mode or going through online vendettas slaying orcs and preying on their weaknesses (or lack of) It's just so good I can't recommend it enough! The only problem is that conqueror mode has kinda gone to shit. When it first came out you could sit there for hours slowly fighting harder and harder enemies, but now, you fight a fortress of level 20s, go up to 40s, then are straight to 60s and 80s meaning that unless you are max level you can't really fight past a certain point (without sacrificing basically your entire squad). Along with the fact that everyone just bought or cheated in the best people with as many immunites as they can and enraged 24/7 with nothing to prey on, kinda ruins the point of the game system. Still really like it though would recommend despite how much I just complained.

This is easily in my top 10 favorite games of all time. I've easily clocked over hundreds of hours on this game on console, bought it on here again because I loved the game that much.

I know the story wasn't well recieved by some, but I quite liked it. Plus, the storyline that game offers you is only half of the storytelling ability this game provides where the other half is made up from the various uruks you encounter in your travels. 

There is one particularly story that I will remember forever from my experience with this game. For some context, I played Shadow of Mordor before I even had Shadow of War, in that game there was this specific uruk with a shield and spear which had become my nemesis because I had no way to beat them since they countered my specific playstyle in every way and when I tried something new they would eventually adapt. At one point I gave up and left the area, deciding to just let them go thinking I wouldn't have to deal with them again.

Cut to my time with Shadow of War where I was dumbfounded to find, partway through my playthrough, that exact same uruk return in my game to rub it in my face one last time. Recounting how cowardly I was to not finish the job. Once again I was met with a roadblock, except this time I couldn't just go around because I had to defeat this uruk to progress the story. That fight felt like it took literal hours to beat, everytime I would fall this uruk would send me back to my last save with another batch of insults to rub salt into my already sore wounds. But when I did beat him, it was the one of the greatest triumphs I felt in a video game of all time. Absolutely unforgettable.

Highly recommend this game, who knows, perhaps you can discover your own story.

I think Shadow of War was a bit of a step down from Shadow of Mordor; not that anything was "objectively" worse, but it wasn't much better either and got repetitive kinda quick, especially having already played the last game. The Nemesis System, however, once again shows its value and is mostly what kept me playing. Taking over forts was fun as hell.
When this game was released, there were also quite a few problems with progression and micro-transactions, but those issues haven been largely resolved since then. 
Overall, It was still fun, and I do recommend it, but if a sequel ever comes out, it would have to bring in something really new to get me interested.

Only get this game on a heavy sale.

Quite liked the game. Main story line does drag on too long. The main story in itself is okay, padded with a lot of open world filler and a few side-quest lines of varying interest to me.

Game looks good with decent sound and music. Controls work fine, with a bit of getting used to. Combat is what you can expect from the 'Batman Arkham combat system': it's decent, not stellar.

Main attractor for me was the Lord of the Ring theming and the unique orc bosses you encounter. They have their quirks, lots of unique dialog and visual stuff. There were a couple that really grabbed my attention, while most in the end still were kind of forgettable in the end. But I like how events in the game, at times come back. 
Got defeated by an orc? He gots promoted. Encounter him again, and he'll rub his victory in your face. Defeated an orc? Maybe, like super hero villians they make a surprising return and scars to remeber you by. Some may take revenge for a sibling you killed, or ambush you or perhaps a stranger who saves you from certain death. These situations did create the lasting memories, for which I'm recommending this game for.

I can't recommend this game enough. 

- Excellent story line brought to life through great voice acting, beautiful visuals and lore.
- Fluid combat mechanics that are a pleasure from the beginning, yet takes time to master. 
- Side quests are a blast and add to the lore and depth of the game. I happily played about 65 hours before I decided to press towards the finish of the main story line. 

I have not played through the story lines of the other characters, so I can't comment on them.

The first Game that is Shadow of Mordor was way better in all aspects, Shadow of war may have bigger maps and a few new mechanics, but it's predecessor had fluid combat mechanics, Way better graphics, Especially Colours as well as the detailing, the colours are very dull and drab in shadow of war, and a major drawback is the combat as well as the abilitites, a lot of the abilities that were the very basic things in shadow of mordor have been removed entirely or downgraded in some way, something that didn't require a single ability point now requires 3 ability points and only one of the effects can be active at one time. the worst thing is the might meter, the thing takes way too long to charge, and even though the addition of wrath meter and elven rage was nice, it was not even minutely enough to make up for removing the storm of urfael, flame of azkar and Shadow of Acharn. although the new added gear and sets is a nice touch of rpg, the effects of the set are very bad and the legendary set have effects that don't even qualify for common rarity of item, i.e they are extremely bad they don't deserve to be called legendary set effects, all in all the game is a heavily downgraded version of the original and the only saving grace is the story, the nemesis system may provide some interesting gameplay mechanics but it doesn't nearly make up for losing the better graphics which were downgraded, the orcs in shadow of war are very common and identical, shadow of mordor orcs looked way better and had better abilities as well, this game is the best example of Developers ruining a perfectly fine game trying to fix something that is not broken and adding so called new things while removing existing perfect things that should never have been touched in the first place. People used to say that Shadow of mordor gets repetitive after a while, I agreed with that but even though it got repetitive, SHADOW OF MORDOR NEVER GOT BORING, NEVER, While Shadow of War gets super repetitive and Super boring very fast and there is nothing you can do about it. And you can never run out of worst thing to say about the game because there are tons, I keep coming back to this review to keep adding new stuff again and again, like why don't we get any xp for killing regular orcs now? are they npcs? or are they not part of the game anymore? just fill the world with only captains then, why even bother to put regular orcs in the game if they serve no purpose and if they don't provide any xp then they serve no purpose at all. But I can still let all this go but the BIGGEST MISTAKE THEY MADE WAS KILL OFF THE VERY HERO IN THE WORST POSSIBLE WAY, THE STORY IS ABSOLUTE GARBAGE AND I ABSOLUTELY HATE It, it is inconsistent with the original and it conveniently forgets things from the first game. WE TOOK NO DAMAGE FROM FIRE BEFORE, SO WHAT HAPPENED NOW? WE DIDN'T HAVE THE RING BEFORE AND YET COULD DOMINATE AND BRAND ORCS, BUT NOW WE NEED THE RING TO DO THE VERY BASIC THING? THE RING WAS SUPPOSED TO MAKE THE CHARACTER EVEN MORE POWERFUL! BUT WHAT DID THESE IDIOTS DO? THEY FORGOT THE THINGS HE COULD DO WITHOUT THE RING AND MADE THE RING DO THOSE THINGS EXACTLY! SHIT DEVELOPERS AND STORY WRITERS THAT'S WHAT!

An interesting title in the LoTR universe.

**First of all, don't make the mistake I did when choosing your character - only start with Talion, the ranger. The game wasn't intended to be played otherwise.

Shadow of War takes the liberty to rewrite a bit of Silmarillion-ish history, having you actually recruit armies of Orcs and work toward the beginning of the eye of Sauron. If you don't mind the non-canon aspect of the game, I can likely recommend this game to you!

The gameplay is solid, building on the legacy Batman-style combat. Controls are solid. Enemies, though sometimes wordy, are varied quite a bit, including both combat style, strengths, weaknesses, and personality. You can more-or-less customize your character's play style using the likes of poison, fire, frost, etc. Online nemesis missions to avenge others who have died is pretty neat (as well as rewarding). Death in this game IS punishable (and sometimes comes quickly), though you are usually afforded some saving graces, which is also a really intuitive feature in this game. The struggle to live is really done well.

The voice acting is good, the story is (like I said)... original (it's not bad). Besides Celebrimbor's conversation volume being at around 15% normal often times, I experienced very few bugs. When the grind starts to hit you, the game is pretty easy to complete.

While the expansion(s) don't provide much, they are there to finish-out the story. You should enjoy this title!
One of the best LOTR RPGs ever

Forewarning, despite giving it a yes, Shadow of War is a game that I have a hard time recommending much to my anguish given my initial hype for the game fresh off of replaying Shadow of Mordor, so I would suggest skimming below depending on your various interests in this game whether it is for story or gameplay.

I could write volumes about my experience good and bad but I'll try (keyword, try) to keep it short and concise. Just for the record I did purposefully play on the hardest difficulty across all campaigns as I feel these games are quite easy by default so that could play in part to how bored I got as difficulty in a lot of these games just means more health for foes, less health for you. These games have great upfront presentation and once you get into the flow of combat it honestly feels amazing, the only problem is everything becomes extremely repetitive after that initial exposure, especially in this game where many upgrades force you into picking one or another so you never get a "true" variety of arsenal tricks without having to stop and reset your skills every other fight. Also a great deal of these skills are just augmenting the damage types of abilities or are clear no brain choices that are better than others. Because of this picky skill tree you can easily max out your character in the first quarter to half of your playtime because nothing else is appealing, and not worth the grind just for rare flexibility you probably will never use anyway. There are actually not very many segments in this game that make up the bulk of the "story" and that which is there usually are incredibly monotonous missions where you attack or defend a fort for the 12th time. The side content (aka majority of the game) is where most of your playtime will be spent if you care to explore. If you beeline the story you could probably finish the main game in the span of 10-15 hours maybe which goes to show just how much bloat there is on the sideline so unless you're dedicated and don't like to drop games halfway through like me, I would understand if you did completely, it is very warranted as there were many times during the many unskippable monologues where I begged for the end to come much sooner than it actually did.

Besides that, I would say the nemesis system, which in theory and practice has such amazing potential for story telling, also cripples itself with the problem of contradictions that should not be there in the first place. It is an honestly astounding thing to witness when it's doing it's thing, but it is completely miserable when you run into what I would like to call "problematic orcs". These are orcs that have no clear counter play because they rolled traits that completely remove any of their class weaknesses. My most infamous example would be a defender captain, they have a big shield and a polearm and are generally the most annoying enemy you will fight in this game. They are however generally weak to bows and stunned with your punch that freezes, however especially as the game goes on, captains get more and more abilities and you will run into situations where our example captain has resistance to frost and is arrow proof, and you can NEVER attack them without them being stunned or sometimes you can get behind them and attack a few times where you hope to get them into a stagger loop OR in absolutely dire cases (which happens more than it ever should in this game) you have to resort to running away while pulling the enemy across the map until you find explosives, animals, or various traps as there is no clear way to fight them otherwise. One fight like this took me 20 minutes because I was in the late game and the captain had so much HP it took at least a dozen fire barrels to defeat him (even with a vulnerability to fire, his only weakness). This and the completely demoralizing "Death Defying" trait that orcs get leads many combats to a coinflip chance of just being a miserable gameplay experience through and through which is really sad with how much narrative potential and unique experience the nemesis system adds to the game as a whole.

All and all my best summary of this game would be to simply follow what your art desires. I think this game is honestly extremely skippable minus the rare funny or amazing moments that come from the nemesis system when it's actually pulling off what it sets out to do. I also am not a giant Lord of the Rings fan however I do really like the story of Talion (the main character) and how it comes to an end, I just really dislike the bulk majority of the game in between those events sadly. Some closing remarks in regards to the expansions, the 1st dlc with the elf girl is completely skippable and felt like a waste of my time. However I highly enjoyed the last dlc with Baranor that lets you feel like in some extremely esoteric way that you're playing Mount and Blade: Warband for the 900th time even though it is nothing like that whatsoever (not sure what I meant by this). If it wasn't for his campaign I probably would have come off of this experience with a negative not recommended review, so thanks Baranor! 

Final Verdict: Unless you really are a completionist, don't mind lots of inane loot that does next to nothing outside of better stats, love unskippable cutscenes and extremely gimmicky challenges that make you replay them 20 times to get it right, really love Lord of the Rings, or just really, really love the feeling of eternal, unending war that pits you versus endless hordes of foes, than I would say this game is probably not worth your time unless you played it on an easy difficulty simply for the experience.

This game is very fun, but it crashes too often. Their website suggests turning off CPU Turbo Boost and removing any overclock from GPUs. Once doing that, crash frequencies went from once every 5-10 minutes to about once every hour. (at least that was the case for a few days, it's now back down to every 10 minutes)

My Specs:
i7-4790
EVGA gtx1080ti
16GB RAM

You should never have to disable turbo boost and overclocks to play a modern PC game.

Edit: turning graphics to medium, changing max framerate to 74fps, and changing vsync to match 74 fps seems to have worked.

Edit 2: I've done more testing and it seems like turning the graphics settings up to ultra while keeping the framerate low, along with the 200MHz gpu underclock and disabling CPU turboboost are stable.

Edit 3: Works great now with max everything. Changing this to a thumbs up

Slightly confusing at first, I would very much recommend just playing the story missions as much as possible until you've unlocked most of your base skills before you start exploring the open world, as you can end up making the game less focused and less efficiently progress your character.  I wish I had only stuck with story missions so that I'd've had access to more of the features before I started just going after captains.

Stealth is forgiving and incredibly gratifying, the combat is visceral and brutal, and it is very easy to fight large groups of enemies and stay alive if you pay attention to the reaction prompts.

My one complaint is that, while there are additional skins, only the main character will show armor and cloak upgrades, the others only show new swords and daggers.  Also, the main character sometimes shows up in cinemas even if you're using an alternate skin, and even if your alternate skin does show up, the voiceover will be that of the main character.  Minor gripe, though.

If you loved the God of War franchise and something like Ghost Recon: Wildlands or the later Far Cry games, this is perfect for you.  And if you are simply a Lord of the Rings fan, the lore and story will be more than enough to keep you engaged.

8.5/10 so far, but I know it'll be even better when I unlock more of the game systems.

Controls are terrible and unresponsive.  What you press is more like a suggestion.  Most fights just turn into watching cut scenes and listening to the enemy give speeches so the AI can reset the circumstances of the fight if you are winning.  Great concept as a game overall, but not well done.

Right before you kill your targets a cut scene will play that shows them running away.  These cut scenes always interrupt play and are not integrated into the fight, so it gives you less control and makes the game more rng based as it is constantly resetting the circumstances of the fights.  It's like trying to play a kid at chess that keeps moving the pieces around when he thinks you aren't looking.  If you try to chase them it is likely you will jump all over the walls or try climb any nearby pillars or obstacles as the sprint button is the same as the climb button.  Want to run down the hallway in front of you?  Too bad idiot, you're going to climb to the top of the tower behind you.  Want to climb up onto the ledge you are holding on to?  Sorry idiot, he will either refuse to climb up, hop around side to side, or launch himself down onto the ground.  The player has no control over this.  

Even if you get clear of any obstacles and get running in pursuit, it is also likely that another cut scene will play where you are forced to stop chasing again and watch another orc give a speech.  The constant cut scene breaks in the middle of fighting are followed up with immediately getting hit by any enemies that are around you.  The player has no control over this.  Even if you catch your target and get him down to 1% health and they aren't running, often an infinite block is engaged where you can no longer damage the enemy, until you are worn down by arrows or other orcs, or forced to run away.  Captains you get down to 0 health often suddenly reappear after a cutscene of them not actually dying, with full health in the place where you first found them.  There is no way for the player to control this.  rng.

Back to climbing, you have little control over where he goes but pressing the directional stick generally indicates where he might try to go.  You can have a clear path to stealth kill an enemy in sight, but you will be forced to climb to the top of the nearby obstacle instead, even if the obstacle is facing the opposite direction you are pressing.  Then even when you are trying to climb, he often jumps to a random ledge or rooftop that totally disregards the player's perspective or camera or what you are actually lined up with, or he completely stops climbing and refuses to move anymore, usually if you are getting shot at or making an escape.

The lack of control and constant unskippable cutscenes that give the enemy the advantage anytime the player starts to win ruin this game, and makes victories unsatisfying and deaths frustrating.

[h1] Middle Earth: Shadow of War [/h1]

Graphics: ★★★★★
The game features stunning visuals with detailed character designs and impressive environments. 

Gameplay: ★★★★
The combat mechanics are smooth and engaging, offering a variety of weapons and abilities. However, some may find the stealth mechanics a bit predictable.

Storyline: ★★★★
The storyline is well-structured and complements the game lore, immersing players in the world of Middle Earth.

Open-world: ★★★★★
The open-world design allows for exploration of vast landscapes, providing a sense of freedom and discovery.

Nemesis System: ★★★★★
The innovative Nemesis System adds a unique dynamic to the game, making each playthrough feel individualized.

Overall: ★★★★☆
Middle Earth: Shadow of War delivers an immersive experience with compelling graphics, engaging gameplay, and a captivating open-world design. However, the game's microtransactions may deter some players.

This game is the perfect example of what a sequel should be.

The first game, Shadow of Mordor, introduced us to the main character Talion, giving his backstory and motivation. This game took what the first game gave us and vastly improved it, including the characters. Talion is such a cool character; he's basically a really dark version of Aragorn. The side characters in this game are way more fleshed out in this game than the first. I loved his relationship to Celebrimbor, Ratbag (best character fr), Bruz, Baranor, and Idril. The world building is also fantastic, as the original only had two territories with brief story explanations, whereas this game has six territories with fun and unique stories to each one.

On top of the story being a vast improvement on Shadow of Mordor, the mechanics in Shadow of War are wayyy better. The ability to capture and defend fortresses/territories is brilliant, the traversal/exploration is better in literally every way (drakes, shadow sprint, climbing, etc.), and the combat mechanics are way more fluid, fun, and far less janky.

So yeah, it's Shadow of Mordor, but, like, way better.

Overall, a solid 8.5/10, would definitely recommend.

TL;DR - It's a Lord of the Rings dark fantasy RPG with fantastic traversal, world, and combat mechanics. You'll enjoy the story, the characters (both side and main), and the game as a whole. Give it a shot!

Spoiler Alert: The following review contains spoilers for Middle-earth: Shadow of War.

Middle-earth: Shadow of War stands as a testament to innovation in open-world gaming, notably thanks to its groundbreaking Nemesis system. This mechanic dynamically generates unique enemy characters with their own strengths, weaknesses, and personalities, creating a living ecosystem within the game. The Nemesis system adds a layer of unpredictability and personalization, as orc captains remember and react to your previous encounters, forging an ever-evolving narrative of rivalries and alliances.

One standout aspect is the game’s approach to the narrative, which, while not canon, masterfully weaves its own tale within J.R.R. Tolkien’s universe. The creative decision to focus on an unnamed Nazgûl as the protagonist is a stroke of genius. This choice not only delves into the lore of the Rings but also offers a unique perspective, allowing players to experience the transformation from a Gondorian ranger to a fearsome Ringwraith.

The progression of Talion’s story, interwoven with the intricacies of the Nemesis system, creates a dynamic and personalized experience. Each orc captain vanquished or dominated becomes a chapter in the player’s own saga, adding emotional weight to the conflicts within Mordor. The unpredictability of the system ensures that no two playthroughs are the same, enhancing the game’s replay value.

Graphically, Shadow of War delivers a stunning depiction of Mordor, capturing the grandeur and desolation of the land. The attention to detail in character design, animations, and the iconic locations from Tolkien’s works contributes to an immersive visual experience.

In conclusion, Middle-earth: Shadow of War successfully takes the innovative Nemesis system to new heights, creating an open-world dynamic that feels truly alive. The narrative, while non-canonical, cleverly utilizes the unnamed Nazgûl to provide a fresh perspective on the lore. This game stands as a remarkable testament to both technological innovation and creative storytelling within the vast and treasured universe of J.R.R. Tolkien.

The game with so much potential but awful execution

Pros
1. Good/ok graphics with HD textures installed (8Gb video card memory required). Without them everything is wishy-washy
2. Batman-game style fighting

Cons
1. Advice when you start - ignore EVERYTHING, just do main missions. Attacked by a tracker/ambusher - ignore them and run away. Nemesis mission, army general, enemies attack the castle or allies - ignore them and run away. There is no tactics, your actions on the map do not matter. Run around from marker to marker, that's what this game is about. 
2. Killing enemy generals is pointless, they respawn at the same rate as you kill them. Therefore, collecting intel about them is pointless.
3. Enemies are infinite, they respawn after 3-5 minutes. Arrows / mounts are not respawnable, at least nowhere the same rate.
4. Enemies are only orcs. Really? You had such a huge universe, and chose to make only orcs the enemies
5. Controls are so laggy on PC. Cannot correctly target enemies to restore health from, constantly enters stealth instead of attacking downed enemies, killing mount and collecting loot is the same button (why would one ever need to kill a mount?) etc. 
6. Flying on the drake controls are horrible, especially during missions

Now everything feels the same both dialogue and combat wise, not many unique interactions with enemy captains, and not much that’s really interesting. The overall combat and system of this game is enough to keep me wanting to play it, but I wish there was something more to make the late game fights against captains more interesting instead of it just being a copy and paste of early game just with higher level enemies. Despite this I would definitely recommend this game to anyone as I feel like this is a hidden gem that does not have as much recognition as it deserves.

Before you play this game, I highly recommend playing the first game, Shadow of Mordor. The story, original design/intention of the nemesis system, the slower pace of combat and the world setting was much better designed in the first game. The sequel added more variety into the nemesis system but butchered and watered down everything else in order to push a Pay-To-Win system (Legendary, Epic and common orcs are a thing and a ranked system similar to predatory mobile games). The Middle Earth lore got ignored (Shelob the spider is now an attractive woman), the combat flow is faster (encouraging a reflex heavy gameplay instead of the methodical one from the previous game). These design choices dumbed down what made the Nemesis system great and 1 legendary orc can just overpower your playthrough. Although the lootboxes were removed, the game only patched it by reducing the grind; players can get legendaries easier and enjoy the single player content but the god tier legendaries still break the game balance and disregards the nemesis system.

Only play the sequel if you enjoyed and can fully take advantage of the nemesis system, something you can see in the first game. With it, you can make a randomly generated orc as deep and more complex than a boss fight you will encounter. You can create unique stories never done in a video game before. But all of this requires you to know how to play around the nemesis sytem and it has unique rules that differs from normal gameplay (You need to make enemies, not kill everyone you see. Dying a lot is part of the game and makes it more fun. You should get outnumbered and overwhelmed at times feeling frustrated and swearing revenge on the orcs that made you angry.) If you want an action game, there are better games out there. This game is about making frenemies with randomly generated orcs and once you can play around this gem, you will have a game like no other. WB knows they have a gem but wasted its potential patenting it and watering it down for a greedy microtransaction (that got patched but its remnants can still be felt.)

After the micro-transactions and scummy business practices were taken out of this game, it is honestly incredible. 
The nemesis system could sell almost any game on its own. The ability to have enemies that are unique to every player adapt and morph across every interaction is one of the most thrilling elements in any game I have ever played and makes every run in with an orc exciting and tense, especially when two high level captains ambush you on what was supposed to be an easy assassination. Taking fortresses is also super fun and leads to high octane bursts of excitement that keep me on the edge of my seat from the first arrow fired. Not to mention as well the soundtrack which is very thematic and elevates the combat tension and atmosphere. 

The only complaints I would have with this game is that the world can feel a bit small, especially alongside other epic open world adventures. Additionally, while there are also a ton of unique traits and titles for orcs, some tend to pop up more commonly than feels appropriate, especially if you plan to primarily ignore the story and run around getting into as many nemesis events as possible.

Overall amazing game, well worth a play for anyone interested in lord of the rings or adventure games in general just to experience the nemesis system at least once.

I love the Nemesis system and building Orcs becomes a whole side job. I really enjoyed the build diversity and options for taking on some real challenging orcs.

A terrible console port filled with jank and bugs. The space bar is used for sprinting, jumping, rolling, vaulting, climbing, dodging, and leaping while climbing. Guess how well that works. This is not an issue unique to the spacebar.

The balance is often terrible, it has a pointless online integration, a bland and boring equipment system which results in forever trading out one set of numbers for a slightly better set of numbers which also defies the game's established narrative. Talion's (the protagonist) dagger is the broken sword of his murdered son, but this random knife I got off a dead ork is better so I guess that matters more than any kind of sentimental value. The previous game saw Talion inscribing his weapons with his great feats, but again they just suck so random trash off a corpse is what is used instead.

The game constantly breaks from the action with pointless long interactions with ork captains and such. When meeting them in battle either on their sudden spawning or the player's attack, when they flee or enrage or die or do just about anything the game stops so the ork can give you his fucking unskipable dissertation on why he's so cool and how much better he is than Talion. I've had fights with these orks take less time than their monologues do.

Overall just a frustrating broken game that mainly just wastes the player's time. If you want to play a fun game about killing orks and fighting evil though a nemesis system, just play Shadow of Mordor instead. While it still has some of the same issues, the game is much better and much more fun.

There's at least a lot of content to play through, though most of it is repetition.
