[h1] MANSWINE! [/h1]

This was the last thing I heard before being embraced by the sweet release of death.

It all started during my journey to capture the fort of Seregost. I was out journeying the snowy plains when all of a sudden, a blunt object had struck the back of my head. Gathering my bearings, I looked upon my assailant, it was an orc—an uruk to be precise. He had been hunting me for a while now, or so as he says. The uruk proclaims that he will move up the ranks once he has claimed my head.

Thinking to myself, "such is the behavior of an uruk who wants to join the pile of dead uruks around me." so I engaged in combat with the uruk, who proved to be a tough opponent than I expected. He has a pack of caragors awaiting at his command, he seems to relish in the pain of being burnt by my enchanted blade and, he also has savages who obey his every order. It seems I'm in for a fight.

And so our weapons clashed. With every uruk and caragor I slay, he summons more. Every opening I could find, every uruk and caragor I slay, I grow weary. Then, at the end. I have done it. It was over. His head, decapitated, his troops, fled, and his caragors? Dead.

I thought of it, he would've been a great captain for my army, but alas, his Iron Will made him loyal only to the Dark Lord himself. Regardless, I picked up my sword and my dagger, and immediately fled the scene, hoping to avoid further conflict as I feel my strength fading.

Then a familiar voice had called out...

"MANSWINE!!!"

How? How did this happen? I had clearly decapitated him, it was supposed to be over! Then, I saw his face... Sutures all over the neck, indicating that these uruks might be smarter than I initially thought. He exclaims once more that he will move up the ranks even more once he had known he survived our initial encounter as well as taking my head.

This. Was. Bad.

I was severely injured from our last encounter, was struggling to find any weak uruk I could dominate to regain my strength but, it was all for naught. A single strike from his mace and-

It was over. My body could no longer go on. Laying on the snowy fields, lifeless. Was my quest to stop the Dark Lord all in vain? It ended as It had started. With a death. It feels poetic in a way. A cycle perhaps, from death, to death.

Then I respawned and seeked out the uruk who killed me.

Say what you will about the microtransactions, but this legend is very well playable without them and is a of is a masterpiece of its own. It isn't exactly lore accurate, nor without some misconceptions of the lore, but still one of my favourite games. I absolutely recommend it.

Shadow of War is an open-world action game in the Lord of the Rings universe. It is a sequel to Shadow of Mordor, and it features an improved nemesis system that lets you forge rivalries and alliances with unique orcs. The combat is fast and fluid, and the game offers a variety of regions to explore and conquer.
However, Shadow of War also has flaws that may affect your enjoyment. The story is weak and inconsistent with the lore, and some of the characters are bland and uninteresting. The game also had microtransactions that allowed you to buy orcs and loot boxes, which was widely criticised by fans and critics alike. Although these were removed in a later update, they still left a wrong impression on many players.
Overall, Shadow of War is a fun game if you enjoy fighting orcs and building your own army, but it may disappoint you if you are looking for a faithful adaptation of Tolkien’s world or a compelling narrative. It is a game that shines in its gameplay, but not in its story. 9/10 for me!!!

[h1]Middle-earth™: Shadow of War. Where do i start?[/h1]

Picked up this game when it was on sale for 3.99€ after hearing good things about it and seeing some gameplay. It BLEW my expectations out of the water.

[i][b]I want to clarify that i have yet to finish the game, i'd say i'm 30% into the story, i'll update the review if there's anything interesting worth pointing out down the line.[/b][/i] 

[h1]COMBAT:[/h1]
So now,  let's start with the combat, fluid, fair, tough and challenging but not hard! what i liked about Assassin's Creed Unity's combat is how realistic and fair it is even though it felt VERY clunky at times. you're up against 2 enemmies? better be careful to not attack and leave your back open to an attack? you're against 3+ enemmies? you're probably going to get outnumbered and overwhelmed, so it's better to stealth your way to the target location, and either reduce the number  of guards stealthly and fight them at smaller numbers, or assassinate your main target and leave. 

It gave great importance to strategic approach so you can't just do whatever, you actually have to THINK before approaching a fight. Shadow of war adopts the same gameplay concept of AC: Unity and makes it better with the smooth gameplay, the fights against hordes of orcs while 3 captains are trying to mow you with their special moves is very challenging but not impossible! if you play well and utulise your abilities well you can win the fight, but most of the time it's too much with the Cougars (idk how it's spelled its the cat thing) and the orcs with the shields charging at you, the big guys trying to crush you and ESPECIALLY the archers. 

So you either have the option of playing stealth, mix stealth with all out combat, OR just play all out combat which could be difficult but as you acquire skill points you can adapt your build to your playstyle, i'll talk about the Abilities tree later. As for the actual combat, it's fluid smooth, and very fun, attacking, then parrying an attack just to jump over a charging enemy and execute them or use an ability to blow the enemies in the area up is cinematic, absolutely beautiful combat, i can't stress this enough.

Only downside is the fact that the only weapon you can actually fight with hordes of ennemies, is your Sword (i don't consider the Glaive a weapon it's basically an ability, and the bow has limited shots so..), which is unfortunate, i would absolutely love to mow through shit ton of orcs with a mace or an axe, but the game makes up for it with other amazing features.

[h1]ABILITIES:[/h1]
Shadow of War offers versitility in the way you play the game, you can put all your [b]skill points[/b] into the combat category and be an absolute beast in combat, or you can invest in stealth abilities to sneak around orcs and stealthily take them out, i don't know if the "Necromancer" build is that viable, but sometimes you are forced to enter combat, so i'd say the best way to enjoy the game is to max out combat and stealth categories then branch out slowly to the other abilities in the subcategories and choose the ones that look fun to play with, don't force yourself into playing a specific build.

As for the gameplay, the abilities are so fun play with, from upgrading the elven smash the ground thing to produce fire on the explosion to the chain stealth kills, the abilities are so well made and there's always something new to play with so you don't get bored with the same attacks/abilities from the start of the game. 

[b]The might bar:[/b] is very interesting, rewarding, and at the same time punishing, if you get hit you lose the might bar and you'll have a hard time charging it up and winning the fight, but if you pull it off the abilities do alot, and it gives you alot of options, you can either use an execution on a captain to try and kill him quickly, or use the elven smash the ground thing to clear out orcs and 1v1 the captain, or drain an enemy, heal and have him fight with you, the options are many and it's so hard to get bored when there is so much versitility and actual strategic planning in fights. 

As for [b]Elven Rage[/b] there is not much to say, once you stack it, it's so satisfying and fun to use, makes you feels so powerful, without being TOO broken.

[h1]ORCS:[/h1]
In Shadow of War, there are the normal orcs, orcs with a specific class (shield orc, archer exct), then there's [b]Captain orcs[/b], which are Orcs with a class on steroids with unique names, looks, abilites, and weaknesses.

Once an Enemy captain is broken, you can either [b]Dominate[/b] him or kill him, if you kill him, he drops loot depending on his class, level, and nemesis points, if you dominate the captain, you can either [b]Recruit him[/b], or [b]Shame him[/b], shaming him will decrease his level which will allow you to recruit him in the future if he's too high level, it also makes him weaker.

Other orcs that are not that important are [b]The treasure orcs[/b], they drop the ingame currency to buy army and gear upgrades, then there are the [b]Slave orcs[/b], which from my experience they don't do anything except for pissing their pants and running away when they spot you.

There is also another type of Orcs, [b]Worms[/b] which are Orcs with information on captains, once dominated, you can extract information on a certain captain to know his weaknesses and what his powers are, which makes them easier to fight as you know how to approach the fight.

What i find fascinating about captain orcs is how everyone of them is unique, be it their looks, voice, name, abilities, or personality, listening to the captains talk to you in a stand off when you engage them is always amusing cause everyone has something unique to say, and once recruited you can hear more voice lines from them.

And i haven't even TALKED about how an orc will remember you and make comments about it if they survive the fight with you or if they kill you and you come back, there's also the fact that These captains can ambush you at random times, be it at the start of a fight, when you're sneaking around, or when fighting other captains! I'll talk more about the Captain Behaviors in the Nemesis System section.

So much effort went into making the game not repetetive and making it feel like it's a dynamic non scripted experience which i greatly appreciate, not alot of games put so much emphasis on small details like this nowadays.

[h1]NEMESIS SYSTEM:[/h1]
In this game, Orc captains in different regions have different rankings, i'll list them in order there's the [b]Grunts[/b], the generic orcs, [b]Captains[/b], which can be found in their camps or fortresses, [b]Warchiefs[/b], they have to be baited out by killing a captain that is associated with the warchief, then you unlock a quest which gives you an objective to do to bait out the warchief, these missions take place in the fortress of the region, then theres the [b]Overlord's[/b], the highest ranking Orc that rules the region, he can be fought once you attack and raid the fortress after building your army.

There's also the fact that Captain orcs will be fighting/raiding/ambushing/assassinating eachother as a background event, the cool thing is you can join the fight and ambush them yourself. You can also send one of YOUR Captain orcs to kill an enemy orc and you can assist them in their task.

This system is so fun and allows for a more engaging experience by making the story as you go, Middle-earth is known for executing this system better than anyone else

[h1]QUESTS:[/h1]
You have the main story which mainly revolves around saving Gondor, then there's the sidequests which include random sidequests, return to the past quests, collectables quests, and Orc Captain quests.

Most of the quests are interesting but frankly i enjoyed the Orc Captain quests the most, but the other sidequests are okay, as for the story i don't want to rush it so i can't say much about it, but for now i've been enjoying it.

In the mid 20th century, two young oxford professors bonded over their love of GK Chesterton and their childhood inspiration by Frances MacDonald's book "Fantastes."

Both agreed that the cost of henry viii's tyranny was most easily felt by the destruction of all Monestaries: man robbed of God, the poor robbed of help,  children robbed of learning, libraries burned to prevent Catholic History from being known, and all tales of Chivalry destroyed to prevent people from having Hope against the regime.  Both agreed a new fantasy would have to be created for young and old, to fill the void of wonder left by the absence of long-lost tales that protestants and freemasons burned for 500 years.  Both realized england was going to die any minute, and that a Truly Good series to inspire wonder (all while injecting Catholic Capital into civilization like hiding medicine from dogs with cheese) and give england at least 50 more years of life.

To this end, CS Lewis decided to make the "Narnia" series for children and the "Space Trilogy" for adults. 
 Tolkien, annoyed that his friend was being too obvious with his references, decided to make the "The Lord Of The Rings" and "Hobbit" series which basically give a scene-for-scene retelling of The Book Of Revelation hidden behind the terms and aesthetics of "Beowulf" and wagner's "niebelung" and "twilight of the gods."

With this in mind, "middle earth: shadow of war" is not a "Lord Of The Rings" game: it's your typical "light vs dark" gnostic claptrap with the same smattering of "necromancy keeps 'the balanceᵀᴹ'" that blizzard's "diablo" series has.  Vague uses of LOTR sounding names are used, but that's where the similarities end; you could make this a tie-in to every single media property in a high fantasy world over the past 30 years by just moving around some terms.  I honestly half-expected nazghul to name-drop arthas and the lich king from world of warcraft because this game's story takes its cues from blizzard more than it ever does Tolkien.

So if you are a hardcore LOTR fan or Christian, look elsewhere if you want a faithful adaptation of LOTR.  If you like Good stories and don't care about LOTR (shame on you), that's not here either.  This game's narrative starts nowhere and ends nowhere, simultaneously takes too long to tell you what it wants to say and speeds through it to the point it is always having to cut its thoughts short.  Characters reference motives that that were never shown, conflicts that did not occur until the very end, and reference scenes that either were never written or cut from the game.  Every inch of the game feels like a tutorial section for a bigger game that was not made.  I am not entirely sure anyone at monolith software is aware of the nature of any of the characters they name mention in the game, with the most egregious being the fact that they present sauron as just being an elf and present Galadriel as some kind of angry political leader instead of a reference to The Blessed Virgin Mary.

So the story is bad, even by game standards it's bad, even by student book reports would this story be bad.  The story wouldn't matter if you were not forced to do it to unlock basic abilities needed to enjoy the orc politics minigame.

So what about the gameplay?  There isn't much of it.  Talion (the player character) is constantly locked into cinematic sequences.  Every weapon hit, every jump, every animation is just a mini cutscene.  enemies constantly invalidate core parts of your kit.  enemies hit you from offscreen all day.  every difficulty but easy has you dying in seconds just to show off the game's inch-deep "nemesis" gimmick.

Want to do any of talions tricks?  Prepare to have every orc on screen zoom to your side and attack you.  Every action that might give even the slightest bit of enjoyment is immediately punished with a "counter this enemy" quicktime event.  The game does every single thing it can to have you rhythmically mash the attack button while hitting the counter button, and any attempt to be creative will have an enemy teleport to you so they can interrupt what you are doing.

This game might be a novelty if it could just get out of its own way.  If it had a lock on button with a combat system closer to the legend of zelda, it would be great just for the silliness of dismembering orcs.  Instead you must play the game as the developers want, when they want it, and you just feel DRAINED having wasted your time playing it.

Ironically, the final dlc added a "roguelike" mode that fixes a lot of the games problems by just removing most of the story and letting you run around a desert killing orcs with gadgets.  Still just a boring, "cinematic" mess though.

This game caters to my 100% completionism very well. Even though the game is openworld, everything is partitioned in rather bite-sized story and side missions that come with an actually impressive lore coverage. You feel engaged and your actions feel like they matter all the time.

That said, the nemesis system breaks immersion significantly when difficulty ramps up, as the game tends to do this by throwing more and more captains at you simultaneously; with more and more bodyguard captains as well. You get locked into captain intro and captain death cutscenes for about half the duration of combat. This obviously gets extremely obnoxious, while during the early game it's nice to get such custom attention to a captain you face one-to-one.

Also, the gearing system: I wish the entire game was gearing like the Baranor DLC Desolation of Mordor; it is so much better than the base game gearing system, by miles. If they make another game, I hope they inherit this system with the addition of skins, and not the original system that I felt no ownership of my gear for.

A Legendary Journey Through Middle-earth

Embark on a thrilling odyssey through the lands of Middle-earth with the "Middle-earth" series, an action RPG that beckons gamers into a world of power, intrigue, and warfare.

The immersive experience begins with an enchanting blend of thrill and engagement, offering an adrenaline-fueled escapade. Despite the series' age, its graphics stand the test of time, enveloping players in a visual spectacle that complements the rich narrative.

"Middle-earth" doesn't just promise fast-paced action; it delivers it in spades. Perfect for those who seek short bursts of gaming pleasure, it's a title that fits snugly into the interstices of a busy day. Imagine having 30 minutes to spare before catching a train—this series is the perfect companion for those moments.

At its core lies an intriguing storyline, a narrative tapestry that keeps players invested, drawing them deeper into the mythical world of Middle-earth. However, the journey through these lands is not without its challenges.

The series' crowning glory is the Nemesis system, a stroke of genius that sets it apart. This innovative system allows NPCs to dynamically adapt, learn, and evolve based on player interactions, resulting in memorable and personal adversaries. It’s a testament to the potential for unparalleled storytelling and character development in gaming.

However, it's unfortunate that this groundbreaking system is exclusive to the "Middle-earth" series due to copyright limitations. The missed opportunity for its integration into other games is a loss for the gaming community. It’s a reminder of how legal and financial complexities can hinder innovation that could revolutionize player-NPC interactions and storytelling in games.

Additionally, control system issues and AI frustrations slightly mar the experience, detracting from an otherwise captivating journey through Middle-earth.

Rating: 8/10

"A legendary journey through Middle-earth, marred by minor control issues and AI frustrations, but ultimately a thrilling experience for fans of this iconic universe. The Nemesis system, a beacon of innovation, remains exclusive, leaving untapped potential in its wake."

Orc killing simulator

Although from a gameplay and narritive perspective this improves on its predecessor and there are more tools (which are welcome compared to the frustration surrounding the limited tool, only one way to kill orc captains and warchiefs system of the previous game and the previous game having only one difficulty - frustrating), the devs made this game for the sole purpose to scam you out of money to get competitive allies in the late game to take down Sauron. Even though the loot boxes have been ripped out, the underlying punishing systems that entice the player to buy the now nonexistant loot boxes has not been rebalanced. If I were to rebalance this I would rip out the shaming system to change the pacing of the game progression predominantly; unfortunately there is no mod for that and most mods for the game have been lost to time or taken down. I also think that the leveling and grinding for weapons, armor, ring slots and all of your allies, especially on Easy mode (which I played on), was way too much. For those masochists that play games on higher difficulties I would think twice playing at a harder difficulty. Overall the gameplay up until you start building the army was great, but once you start having to interact with the borderline unfair game progression even on easy mode, which is not supposed to be this freakin' hard, makes me want to stop playing and never come back. Not Recommended!

Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor is an absolute masterpiece that seamlessly blends captivating storytelling, fluid combat mechanics, and an innovative Nemesis System to create an unforgettable gaming experience. Set in the rich and immersive world of J.R.R. Tolkien's Middle-earth, this game takes you on an epic journey as Talion, a ranger seeking revenge in the heart of Mordor.

The graphics are stunning, capturing the dark and atmospheric essence of Mordor with breathtaking landscapes and attention to detail. The combat system is a perfect mix of fluidity and strategy, making every encounter feel like a cinematic battle. What truly sets this game apart is the revolutionary Nemesis System, where enemies remember your actions and evolve based on your interactions, creating unique and personal stories within the game.

The open-world exploration is seamless, offering a vast and diverse landscape filled with secrets, challenges, and iconic Middle-earth landmarks. The ability to control and manipulate the minds of your enemies adds an extra layer of depth to gameplay, providing strategic options in every encounter.

Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor is not just a game; it's an immersive journey that brings Tolkien's world to life in ways we could only dream of. Whether you're a fan of the books, movies, or simply love action RPGs, this title is a must-play. Monolith Productions has crafted a masterpiece that sets a new standard for storytelling and gameplay in the open-world genre.

Oh, and I guess they decided that the world from Shadow of Mordor was a bit too bland (being Mordor and all), and apparently thought it was legit to add an ice region, a lava region, a desert region, and a forest region, all within Mordor. And I'm supposed to feel immersed??

Middle-earth: Shadow of War: An Unforgettable Adventure in Middle-earth

[Introduction]

"Middle-earth: Shadow of War" is a must-play for gamers who want to immerse themselves in the dark and epic atmosphere of Middle-earth. The game continues the story of "Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor" and takes players on a magical journey. The game's story follows Talion, a Ranger, and his vengeful spirit companion as they wage war against Sauron's armies in Mordor. The story reflects the richness and depth of the Middle-earth universe and is faithfully crafted with respect to Tolkien's works.

[Story]

The game's story evolves into an impressive journey where characters and events are richly developed. Talion's quest for vengeance takes players to different regions of Middle-earth and provides opportunities to encounter familiar characters. The story has depth that will satisfy fans of the Tolkien universe. Additionally, player choices have an impact on the story, enhancing the game's replayability.

[Gameplay]

"Shadow of War" is an action-role-playing game that allows players to control Talion, a character equipped with magical abilities. Players will need to employ strategy when engaging enemies. The game's standout feature, the "Nemesis System," enables players to influence and manipulate their enemies. Players can form alliances among enemies or use them for their own purposes. This dynamic element enhances the game's replayability and adds depth to the gameplay.

[Graphics and Sounds]

The graphics capture the visual splendor of Middle-earth impressively. The game's environments, castles, forests, and mountains are presented with attention to detail and atmospheric beauty. Character models are also meticulously designed. Particularly, the effects and combat scenes are visually satisfying. Sound design plays a crucial role in establishing the atmosphere of Middle-earth in the game. The music in the game creates an epic and immersive atmosphere suitable for the Tolkien universe. Character voice acting is generally well done and enhances the storytelling.

[Conclusion]

In conclusion, "Middle-earth: Shadow of War" is a game that stands out with its loyalty to Tolkien's Middle-earth universe and its impressive story, gameplay, graphics, and sound. It's a must-try for Tolkien enthusiasts and fans of the action-role-playing genre

Steam says I've spent 30 hours on this game, and I believe it, it's felt like 30 hours - and it feels only fair to preface this review by stating that I stopped playing this game, not because I beat it, but because I got *bored*, and according to the in-game completion percentage, I didn't even get through half the content the game has to offer.

so here's the thing: what if assassin's creed but lord of the rings? It's a solid concept, it's a fair successor to the first game. You can parokour your little gondorian heart out, you can dominate greenskins like nobody's business, you can ride the shit out of wargs and trolls and dragons, you can upgrade your weapons, you can fast travel, you can stealth, you can freeze time and shoot a million arrows at everybody, you can be BFFs OR moral enemies with the weirdest uruks you can imagine...

... but somwhere between level 30 and 40, the game loses all novelty. You've seen all the game has to offer, but the game somehow still isn't over, and won't be over for hours yet. Oh, do you need to do *another* quest, that requires you to "go to place, kill these guys under these conditions, fight these captains" again? Do we have to dominate drakes this time? Do we have to kill THREE captains at once? Are there Nazghul in the mix this time? Done, done, and done. It's all been done before, and if you're like me, you're going to inevitably reach the point where you just don't care about any of it.

Skip the cutscene. Run to the place. Do the thing. Kill the guy. Do some inventory maitenence. Oh, you leveled up? Who gives a shit, you already have all the abilities, and all the ability mods, and XP basically means nothing now. What, you want to hunt down another orc captain? You want to raid another fortress? You want to do another ringwraith battle? Boring.

The game should have been half as long.

BUT.

For the first half of the game, you *will* be thoroughly enjoying yourself - and honestly, I think it's worth it for that alone. Just don't expect that joy to carry you all the way to the end, it certainly fell fair short for me.

Painfully boring.

I think I can actually give this game a positive review: it was engaging, for lord of the rings fans the game actually involves more of the monsters - although I really wished there was more to it than capture the orcs, take the keeps and then kill the orcs.

The 2 DLCs of different characters makes the game a lot harder - this can either be good or bad depending on how "easy" you found the original game you will notice a lot of your followers will have buffs that make the fights bearable - my only tip I can give you if you are going to play the DLC is remember you don't "have" to fight every battle: your friendlies can fight as well.

Don't get too attached to your orcs as well: you are most likely going to kill one or two.

Shadow of War improves on Shadow of Mordor in a lot of ways: if they ever made a sequel: they should include some of the main characters and include a create your own character... if there was anything I could suggest: make it less like assassin's creed and more like Batman Arkham Knight.

Doubt it'll ever get made but here's hoping.

If I were to give it some criticism: the challenges are still a bit pointlessly done - you don't require the upgrades though most of the time it would have been nice to be given them rather than make us work for them as we have had to already march the Orcs up and down each fortress like it's some fairy tale kingdom.

For a lot of people wondering if they'll get to see a true ending: keep in mind that each DLC will give you different what if scenarios. So keep that in mind when you're playing these and don't worry about the spoilers (unless you play the elf's storyline in which case you will have some of the story spoilt for you - unfortunately)

One of these DLCs involve a more Batman-esk feel and makes you a lot more vulnerable (if you die you have to do the entire run again, yikes: story missions I was unsure of as I actually did become more like a commander in this one and just watched the AI do the work for me when I had the confidence they were probably as strong, if not stronger than me. Not saying you should - but It's strongly suggested to in this DLC specifically if you want to enjoy the start to end, which let's be frank is hard to do and honestly the ending is nothing much to write home about but you will probably feel like you just beat a very hard Dark Souls game because of the difficulty.

There are way more monsters in this version, though some of the Orcs are still missing I really wished they worked more on establishing factions of other civilisations beyond the black gate: maybe there's an Orc faction that is comprised of just minstels? maybe there's a faction of humans that are so bloodthirsty they've been accepted as Orcs? I don't know... it feels very much like the game could have those moments where it can branch out from just being strictly  Orcs I feel if they ever did make another game: they have those options to be more experimental with the content.

A lot of people will get annoyed that some of this cannot be cannon: and for that I can say - you are right, that shouldn't be cannon because the game is trying to be it's own thing while maintaining a connection to the original content. It would actually be better if it did branch off though in this case, as we know the Orcs themselves are not all serious when it comes to war.

The game needs to be able to step away from the Tolkein books if it is ever going to be able to make it's own mark but I do think there's a limitation here and that's causing the story to feel stiff and that's what I hope they would fix in the next game if they ever did.

I also wish to add that I did suffer a bit from burnout from playing the game as long as I did, this is one of those where you'll likely want to rush the content and sadly the game takes that away from you with the forts. There's a lot of random chance that can either be forgiving or really unfair I do think the difficulty is justified but for a lot of us: not many of us will be finishing this game sadly due to it's length and difficulty spikes.

Prepare to be transported to Middle-earth like never before. This game is not just an adventure; it's an emotional odyssey through the iconic world of J.R.R. Tolkien, where you become the master of your fate.

From the very first step into Mordor, I was captivated by the sheer magnitude of the game world. The landscapes are breathtaking, from the towering fortresses to the serene Elven woods. It's a visual masterpiece that resonates with Tolkien's vision.

But it's not just eye candy. The story is an emotional rollercoaster, where you forge your own path as Talion, a Ranger seeking vengeance. The relationships you build with your Orc followers are surprisingly moving. It's not often that a game can make you feel empathy for creatures typically considered villains.

The Nemesis System is the game's crown jewel. The way your interactions with Orcs shape the game world and your own story is a work of genius. Every encounter is personal and emotional.

The combat, oh, the combat! It's visceral and satisfying, making you feel like a true ranger as you execute precision strikes and unleash supernatural powers.

"Middle-earth: Shadow of War" is more than a game; it's a journey of emotions. It's a must-play for fans of Tolkien's world and action RPG lovers alike. It's an adventure that will leave you on the edge of your seat, your heart pounding, and your emotions in turmoil as you fight for Middle-earth's destiny.

Outstanding and truly one of the best titles for an action-adventure game. A truly satisfying single-player focused experience set in the amazing world of Middle-earth. It never gets old as every playthru has endless possibilities! You'll never sure about the outcome of every fight you start with all the chances to get ambushed, tracked or simply some random boss popping out of nowhere and tries to mix in with all the chaos. Simply a dynamic and fluid world, story and gameplay beautifully tailored to give you endless experiences and challenges. 

Dominating Orcs and pitting them against one another and eventually building your own dominion of orcs is a game within a game also. Build diversity has been improved as well as the overall combat mechanics from the first game. More diverse enemy types and just a whole bunch of great online game modes to interact with other peoples creation of a twisted orc army. There's just so much to do to satisfy your inner LOTR fantasies!

So, I have 373 hours of gameplay over the past few years. Never left a review for this game so I might as well do it now. The game is fun for the most part. Story is a little lacking in the sense that it is it's own story disconnected from the books it was inspired by. The game is challenging for new beginners, and I recommend two play throughs to really get the full experience. 

First to just rush through the story, do all the side activities if you want, and learn how to play. If you do that -which most people do- then you will be under leveled with pretty meh orcs, but a lot of stories of fun encounters. No two orcs are the same, and as long as you actually have a difficult time in combat, you can have a load of fun with their nemesis system, which I really wish more games would do, or have. The fort capturing is fun at first, and can easily get you lost. 

Second play through do all side activities while doing story, do not finish the story without the actual side stuff done, it causes bugs in my experience. Aside from that the game kinda becomes farming, looking for the best orcs, and necros, cause those are rare.

Boy it sure is good that a main mechanic of this game is how often the main character dies.

Because with this outright horrendous control scheme and his, frankly, worrying fascination with gripping his little fingies on everything, ever, as stupidly as possible...it's all you can do in the game!
Props to the dev team for creating the worst controlling game I've seen in my life.  At least Superman does what you tell him in Superman 64.  Whomp-whooooooomp.

To clarify, the game itself?  Pretty good, especially with all the micro garbage yanked out.  The controls and the combat design, however, absolutely drag this down to 6/10 or lower territory purely on their own failures.  And even without the micros in the game...the toll they took on design is painfully easy to see.  WHY can I auto attack my allies?  Why does Talion insist on doing so at absolutely insane opportunities?  When I have 2 enemy captains and 4 enemy soldiers nearby, yes, I want to go right ahead and attack my own allied captain.  Holy shit the stupidity.  And this is just one painful combat design flaw of many.  If you've never played, don't bother, the controls and design pull the game down way too hard to genuinely recommend.  If you did before and want to come back like I did...expect pain.  Lots and lots of pain, from horrid controls and worse combat design choices.  This game will frustrate, and it will frustrate OFTEN.

It is a tale of valor, treachery, and the indomitable spirit of the free peoples. This game, my dearest friends, captures the essence of our beloved Middle-earth with such brilliance that it earns the highest praise. How they ever managed to make a hack-and-slash not fun is insane

All of the combat abilities from Shadow of Mordor are locked behind higher level skill trees, you only get mobility skills in the early game so your best option is literally to run away, all the captains start with very annoying traits and can instantly adapt to every kind of attack you can do, the enemies all instantaneously attack which is realistic but offers you very few counter options gameplay-wise, there are bugs including: high-low contrast coming out of wraith vision, getting stuck on tightropes, orcs ignoring environmental hazards and seemingly becoming invulnerable to them. 

The lack of invincibility frames when doing executions and the quickness of random orcs donkey-punching you makes combat extremely frustrating regardless of style. Melee is plagued with steroid-crazed zerkers who have a shopping list of traits which overcomes any natural weakness they have, ranged attacks can be spotted fifty miles away regardless of cover and also suffers from a lack of arrows as well as a focus meter which cannot be upgraded anymore (what were they thinking?), and stealth is arguably worse than useless because captains who are not immediately killed take very little damage so you've effectively traded a superior position for 5% damage. 

I uninstalled the game around Act 2 because the constant grind and poor gameplay choices made for a constant slew of "HOW DID THAT HAPPEN" or "WHAT WAS THAT" or just straight up swearing constantly. 

I've never seen a studio be so categorically anti-player to the point that they give the NPCs every advantage and lock out player options for a brazen disadvantage. The game never gets better despite my copium, and it doesn't hold a candle to the first game at all.

If you bought this game, refund it and play Shadow of Mordor instead.

I am not a lord of the rings fan; I don’t even think I’ve seen all the movies to completion… but this game SLAPS.

I never played the first game, Shadow of Mordor, but I didn’t really feel like I had to. The combat is smooth and intuitive with a surprisingly high skill ceiling. I was always learning something new or discovering unique interactions with my abilities and the environment. There’s also loads of different gear-sets all with unique bonuses to change up your build/playstyle dramatically. The gear-set impact on gameplay is really important because the gameplay loop is the same throughout the entire game: find orcs, kill orcs, recruit orcs, take fort, repeat in next zone with higher level orcs.

I think the main reason it never feels like a drag is because the combat is fantastic. I’ve heard great things about the Nemesis system, but in 40 hours of gameplay I have yet to experience it at it’s full potential. I played this game on the “Nemesis” difficulty, so I thought I would get a lot of interaction with Orcs who I’d previously encountered; unfortunately, that’s not the case. Still to this day I do not have one of the most common achievements in the game: Nemesis – encounter the same Orc 3 times. I think to be able to experience the Nemesis system fully in Shadow or War, you must intentionally lose over and over… that’s sort of unnatural for a video game and doesn’t feel super great imo.

Regardless this game looks and feels great for a 6-year-old title and is a fantastic combat sandbox. There’s lots of collectibles and stuff to do around the zones, I think I’m on track to 100% complete the game in about 60 hours and for $5 for the base game + all the DLC… it’s 100% worth it.

I played this game the first time some 5 years back, and before I could beat the main story, I reached a point of frustration that it occurred to me that I simply wasn’t having fun with it.

Fast forward to now, where I was replaying games in my archives, remembering I disliked the game, but wanted to give it another chance to at least finish it.


Was perhaps 10 hours in before I fully remembered its flaws.

The story is fine for what it is.


There are characters that are memorable.


The voice acting and dialogue is truly great at times; though when you are in the middle of an intense fight, the interruptions for an Orc to introduce itself to you or invoke “I’m not dead yet” speech can be extra salt on the wound. 

The scenery and world you run around in is wonderful.  Though similar to an Assassin Creed game, when running around, it can become a battle over controlling your character when you want to drop down or climb up. The game is mostly on auto pilot and it becomes a bit clunky trying to take control back. 


—
The real bane of this game, as to why I personally know it's not for everyone, is its gameplay.
—



The game gives you abilities as you level up and spend points.  At first it feels empowering, as it gives you an assortment of tactics to keep the combat fresh.

Then it decides to take those away from you.  As the game continues to slap on immunities to the foes you face. Ultimately, it limits you to only damage them with 1 or 2 tactics.

It can make the later fights rather dull or agitating, just fumbling around to get damage in on some generic orc because their kit counters most attacks.   

Couple this with the fact that whenever multiple enemies are in one area, it quickly becomes a nightmare trying to maneuver around when that's not really the game's strong point.  You’ll notice in the middle of chaos that the game is quite ridged in controls and punishes you when you attempt to move around or flee in the heart of battle. 

Perhaps a counter point is this means you should be careful not to engage multiple enemies and to plan ahead and try to isolate the foe.

Yet going back to my previous point, when all you can do is 1 or 2 attacks to damage a foe, the combat in 1v1 is plain and loses appeal when many of your attacks simply don’t work.


Note that this is all accurate to EASY difficulty.  If you are a masochist, and try normal or higher, the enemies adapt to your attacks; I.E if you vault/leap over them too many times, they become immune to it and push you back.  So now those 1-2 attacks that work, get countered if you spam it too much on them.

Frankly, while elements to this game are fine to good outside of the gameplay; I can’t fathom why so many would hold this game fondly.   To each their own, but I caution anyone who is weary of my points on combat. Please hesitate to buy a game that may lead you to stress.  Games are to relax outside of work/school…not endure more headaches.

This game had a lot of potential, but at the end of the day it felt one step removed from UBISOFT trash. The nemesis system is interesting, but its now locked inside WB games never to see the light of day.

Middle Earth: Shadow of Mordor is a LOTR Assassins Creed simulacrum with no specific world identity or purpose than to pander to LOTR fans. 

The movement is clunky at best. I never know which way my character will leap after landing on a roof line or wall. This makes traversal a luck based process more than a skill based effort. This is such a shame as the verticality in combination with the level complexity would have made for some interesting pathing options. Instead, I am left with running around on the floor and climbing tall spires as the only certain options and hoping anything other climbs or jumps work the same way they did five minutes ago. 

Exploration is unrewarding because the map is prepopulated in the same way as other modern RPG trash heaps. Fill it up with generic samey items that give a little dopamine boost when interacted with and hope that is enough to keep the players coming back. Exploration should be about discovery and joy in finding new an unique items or areas. This game and many of its contemporaries make the fatal flaw of thinking exploration is deterministic. They believe for the player to want to explore they first must know what they will get out of it. In reality, knowing where you are going is not better than finding where the path leads. 

Finally, the story. What to say, its convoluted and difficult to parse. No I have not completed the game, but I do not care to know if the story eventually becomes more cohesive with clearer stakes. It's boring and no amount of great Golem voice acting can fix it.

Arkham Asylum and its consequences have been a disaster for gaming. The Nemesis system is amazing, but everything about the gameplay makes it just not worth it, and it's sad that the nemesis system will be forever locked to this mess. 

The movement is godawful, pressing the button for jumping, even when prompted, will more often than not throw you in the complete opposite direction. Hitboxes for corners extend for yards past where they visually end, impeding your attempt to run past anything. Climbing is a matter of whether the game is in the mood to let you move, or would rather freeze you in place for half a minute and then yeet you in the direction of the orcs you're attempting to sneak up on or escape from. There are countless variants of a few very basic attacks, but only a handful of those will ever respond to you pressing the buttons and even less will ever actually be useful, meaning most of the time the rest of the controller and context sensitive commands are just a crowd of liabilities. Prompts are inconsistent in showing up and even less thorough about giving you accurate information.

All in all, there are plenty of good ideas but they're tacked on to a downright dogshit core that has been sloppily copied and pasted dozens of times by AAA devs and then stuffed with other garbage to artificially inflate your playtime.

The major complaint I have about this game is the pacing. Before and after the obligated and removed grind for in-game purchases. I had to stop playing for years until this company could not milk the market no more so it could go back to "normal" game play.

Also, the story starts poorly removing everything you earned from the previous game.
Baldurs Gate, an even older game for the 90s managed to keep up with the story and not downgrading the main character, but I get it, you wanted more "padding" to extend the game and use the same copy/paste mechanics. Lame.

And the story also ends poorly, unsatisfying. Well a hard task to pull off, but it was going to be hard once the development team accepted to do it, so they failed.

Combat, I kind of feel they wanted to make a Batman kind of fighting game? It just doesn't feel right. By the end of the game, having everything unlocked the enemy "adapts" so they are pretty much invulnerable and boring. What the hell does the ring even do if you can't have true power?

Conclusion:
If you don't mind anything I mentioned and are a Middle Earth loyalist, then the game is all yours, as for me, I'm relieved there won't be another one of these anymore.

BUT THE FREAKING COMBAT SYSTEM IS AWESOME. The Nemesis system is something that should exist in every single combat pve game. It is so goddamn much fun. It is so damn immersive, you actually get attached to the damn orcs. 

Examples: I got myself a brain-damaged lvl 37 orc captain (no kidding, his title is "The Mindless") who kept going after other captains 30 levels above his. He didn't even fight right (ngl, that's what made him easy to catch in the first place). 

I made him Overlord because of how ballsy he is. 

That's how much fun this game is.

I wish there was an option to reduce/eliminate enemy captain introductions which sometimes drags on too long which takes away from the fun.  This is fun at first, but if you're in a battle, you wind up sitting in curscenes listening to orc trash talk for several minutes if there are several accomplices around....

Recommendation for New Players:
I would highly recommend leveling up as much as possible and hoarding as many dominated captains (normal/epic/legendary) as you can prior to completing the final primary mission for the game.  Once you finish the last mission, all orc captains that you encounter will either have a lethal weakness (die if they encounter a specific enemy/ailment/circumstance or run in fear when they encounter it) or will have an "Iron Will" train preventing domination to add them to your army.  For "Iron Will" orc captains, you can choose to "Shame" them to remove the trait and reduce their level, but as the result, the majority will gain one or more unfavorable weakness traits which will make them weak/terrible additions to your overall orc army--orc captains within your control.

yes

[h1]The Gameplay: [/h1]
The gameplay is an enhanced version of the original Shadow of Mordor which was already fun in it's own right. The Nemesis system is further built on to simulate a much more organic, delightfully random but overall consistent experience with your orc captains. Everything still gravitates towards taking over a fort, but they put in enough inbetween that it doesn't feel like decoration to the same gameplay, and rather enhancements to what worked. The additional moves added to combat and traversal really keep the experience fresh. Definitely a must get if you enjoyed the first game.

[h1]The Story:[/h1]
The story was actually pretty great. At first it seemed a little contrived (probably cause… well it was but..) it turned out pretty well. There was a little redundancy with Celebrimbor reapting himself about the Palantir 10000 times, but I suppose that was to make sure to cement his motivations and make them absolutely clear.. that he wants the Palantir. They manage to improve on their emotional tones and really make sure to hit home that Talion's situation REALLY sucks. They also threw in a delicious plot twist that had me excitedly giddy till the end and a little sad there wasn't more.

[h1]The Visuals:[/h1]
The visuals take a dramatic step up from the previous entry's and that was nothing to sneeze at either. Most importantly, the armor and weapons that you don look incredibly good. So much so that the alternate skins you can wear for fun just are overshadowed' by the Shadow of Wardrobe Talion has. The various envoirments especially Minas Ithil are also a pleasure to look at, along with all the little tiny details that Tolkein would take 7 and half pages to write about on a door, and absolutely there.

[h1]The Sound:[/h1]
The voice acting was superb and fits with what has been already established within the LOTR universe. In fact this is probably the strongest point since the captain's and their shit talking of you would not be possible without this. And it is almost the entire reason to play the game in my opinion. The music sounds good and now properly hits the right tones to enhance the emotional scenes along with that prior voice acting that I mentioned that truly hit me hard. It was done incredibly well.


[h1]The Experience:[/h1]
Mileage may vary, but in a good way with this game. Everyone's experience will both be curated and unique when playing this game, and this is why I love it. I am glad that whatever P2W mess was originally staining this game is gone and that now you can just play the game as it should have been released. The whole thing left me satisfied until the very end which a lot of games struggle to do. It was perfectly balanced, and while there was extra content to do should I chose it, I never felt like I had to play it like some sort of carrot on stick that a lot of other games like to do now a days. This is certainly worth a play whether or not you are a Lord of the Rings fan. Hell it might get you to want to see the movies if you never have.

This game was disappointing for me and a lot of friends ask me "Why" since Shadow of Mordor is my all time favorite video game ever and this is just that game but improved, right? I decided to re-visit this review, since I gained more experience on how to actually review things and the old one is pretty tantrum-ish. I will try to best explain, why I think this game is good, but inferior to its predecessor. 

Some keywords:
SOM- Shadow of Mordor
SOW- Shadow of War
BOG- Blade of Galadriel
DOM- Desolation of Mordor

[h1] The Bright [/h1]
Lets start of with the positives. First of, the thing this franchise is known for. The Nemesis System. It has been improved a LOT. The main gripe with older iteration is, your Orcs didn't have much personality, once they became your allies. This has changed. Umug the Bollocks Puncher stays the way he is. The Bollocks Puncher but on your side and not an automaton. The orcs overall, are even more vocal you could say. But here is a problem. SOM was VERY addictive to me, for these interactions. They were a balance of meaningful, threatening, funny and the appropriate amount. SOW is the exact opposite. In my first iteration of review, I said this gets very repetitive. Now my opinion has changed once it has finally properly digested. Its not, that they are repetitive. There is too much uniqueness. Too much humor. Too... empty. The orcs seem to have gained personality, only to somehow feel shallow. I don't know, maybe I am just crazy, but that's how I feel about this. Orcs are still fun, but... not like they used to be. Its still a good system. But for me, it has lost its charm, while SOM still keeps surprising me with its interactions, this one... I don't know. Its quantity over quality issue in my opinion but I shall move onto my next point before I get depressed over this.

DOM is a very good DLC. Finally, GOOD CHARACTERS AND STORY (more on that later). Definitely try this DLC.

Sieges are pretty fun. Not much else to say.

The Combat in this game is amazing. Its one of the few things I prefer over the SOM. The build variety is GREAT. One time, you can be a poisoner, who chokes everyone. The next, you are Ice Warrior, shattering all in his path. This is genuinely, one of the most fun combat out there. It helps that the AI is now smarter and adapts to your tactics which keeps it fresh and on your toes. The problem with combat is in its targetting though. Sometimes, the game just decides to take you on a ride and instead of using execute on that captain, it somehow takes you 30 meters away from him and is like "F this grunt in particular". But its still, pretty good I suppose. But that's it for the positives I think. 

[h1] The Orky [/h1]
First of, we start with one of the most crucial aspects in all the games. The sound design. I can tell you, SOM had one of the best sound designs out there. The flurry, the sword slashes and clings. Everything was top. So how does SOW fare in this? Weeeeeeelll... it reuses lot of these assets but seems to "remake" them a bit. Which I am not sure how, but it makes them sound duller and generic. Don't get me wrong. Some of them are still there, but it seems to have lost its edge a bit in this. Honestly, besides the old reused ones, the only new ones I remember are the punches from the ground execution. That's it. Music doesn't fare that good either. Besides the sieges, couple orc tracks and Orc Slayer, nothing sticks out. Its once again, forgettable. 

When we first heard about tribes, everyone went ballistic. A new unique feature orcs can have? Sign us up! Until their iteration. They are good. But some are way more interesting than others. The mechs, glowies and kitchen nightmares have the best aesthetic AND abilities to fight against. But others? Those are either mediocre or seriously lacking. Warmongers and Terror being the most forgettable ones. Doesn't help that 2 tribes are behind a paywall. I can understand why, but... Why? I honestly think it was bad decision but what can you do.

The new maps and environments are forgettable. Seregost is pretty much the only map that is genuinely good.

The post "first credits" challenge is a...meh. Its not bad, but I also wouldn't recommend it. The grind was toned down a lot from its first iteration but its still a big waste of time for few cutscenes. Unless you are sucked into the game, I don't recommend doing it.

My last point in the mixed feelings are the graphics. They are a downgrade in my opinion compared to SOM. They can look good, but most of the time, look muddy or as if drought has hit Mordor. The character models are a hit or miss. 

[h1] The Dark [/h1]
BOG. DO NOT BUY THIS AS A ONE OF. ONLY IN PACKS. ONLY ORCS ARE GOOD IN THIS ONE.

Multiplayer Sieges were one of the most interesting ideas on the paper. Fight someone elses orcs and rank up in difficulty? Heeeell yeee. Until you realize, people are generally min-maxers that do not try to make challenge, but unbeatable and most unfun experience ever for the attacker to quit and give them score rating in the difficulty for their fortress. Doesn't help, people use cheat engines. Its even worse once you realize, you have to use your overlord to get you additional fortress slots in duels against tf2 sniper bots. He can try, can kill them, but most often than not, he will miss and get headshotted unless he is berserker or defender. You cant even really swap the overlords, or I advise against it for the hidden mechanic of loyalty points/betrayal is a fickle mistress. I don't blame this necessarily on devs, but it is in the game and it is genuinely bad. 

And finally, the story. I genuinely dislike this story and its characters besides orc related stuff. They are sooooo boring or just straight up ANNOYING(F THE BLOND BIMBO, HER DAD AND THAT ASS ON THE GRASS HAT ELF). Celebrimbor and Talion are also huge downgrade in my opinion. Celebrimbor is BUMBLING idiot who goes "PALANTIRPALANTIRPALANTIR MAH RING TALION MAH RING" and Talion is goody two shoes. Shelob is passable. If she was made into pure spider, it would have been waaaaaaaaaaay better but what can you do (SCREW YOU HORNYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYY). But the worst of all, the Nazgul which are your main enemies. Why worst? They are EXTREMELY boring. Nazgul. The guys who gave me the CHILLS everytime they appeared in both the book and movies. They are BORING.[spoiler] Honestly, one good thing I can say about the story, is Talion becoming Nazgul BUT WHATS THAT? SOFT RETCON BECAUSE MISSUS ELF NEEDS A BOSS?! HEEEEEEEEEELL YEEEEEEEE! [/spoiler]

The bosses. Hear me out now. Were they improved? Yes. Compared to QTE final boss in SOM. Definitely. But they do NOT hold candle to The Hammer, The Tower, Sauron and Legendary Graug in first game. Its not always about the challenge. Its about the presentation aswell. The feels. The SETUP. And the bosses in SOM certainly had all of it. They did not appear a lot (basically boiled down to one-two cutscene appearance and then fight) but they felt like they were there ALWAYS. Nameless Nazgul are boring. Named Nazgul, while challenging, are also boring. [spoiler] The Sauron boss fight is a big let down from the one in the Bright Lord DLC in SOM. Thematic? Sure. Its 2v1. But that does not mean its good. The Balrog can be boiled down to "OH MY GOD IS THAT BALROG LIKE FROM MOVIES?!" eye-candy. Cool, but not much else. The nazgul sisters from BOG dlc are annoying at best. I genuinely feel like only Dark Talion was good. Genuinely good boss. But its BOG dlc. So ye. Get butchered by ugly ASS ON THE GRASS HAT ELF. [/spoiler]

[h1] The Finale [/h1]
All in all, this is a good game, yes. But for me, its not. For me its personally a disappointment and one of the games which made me be aware of pre-purchase. You should play this game, as it has been given love by devs. I was just hoping for something else.

The second installation in the series. Overall quite enjoyable and I sunk many hours into it. It expands greatly on the first game with more areas, more things to do, more mechanics, and a lot of other fun things. It also expands on the enemies, in particular, the captains. While overall enjoyable, I felt more frequently annoyed by the captains in Shadow of War than in Shadow of Mordor. I think a big factor in this is the adaptation that captains can do. On the surface it is a cool idea, forcing you to adapt as your enemies do and not spam certain things, however, as noted with defender captains in my Shadow of Mordor review, there is sometimes only one good way to damage a particular captain, and you will quickly find them gaining immunity to that thing, especially on nemesis difficulty. If the captains were more consistent in having multiple ways to tackle them, especially defenders, I wouldn't mind it so much.

A new addition, sieges, are interesting. There is one significant problem though. If you prepare well for the siege by installing your own warchiefs, you basically skip the whole siege as there is no resistance at all except in the final fight, which you essentially MUST over-prepare for by getting a lot of traitors in waiting guarding the overlord. This is because the overlord is usually full of all kinds of immunities and nasty abilities along with all kinds adds and you must fight him head on. There is no outsmarting here like hunting captains in the wild. You MUST use the combat directly which is annoying for a game in which you often have so many options, such as stealth and beasts. If you lose that fight, you could lose an hour of time reinstalling warchiefs and bodyguards. I frequently found myself sticking 6 traitors on the overlord just so I would be ABSOLUTELY sure I wouldn't lose progress by losing the annoying fight.

The fight pits are another sometimes frustrating mechanic wherein you essentially are left to the whims of RNG whether you can assign traitors or warchiefs. Eventually it stopped bothering me, and I'm not sure why, but I know it was frustrating to be almost ready to attack and complete a mission but you have three bad fights in a row and need to hunt captains for another hour.

The game is very long if you do all of the side content and felt a little boring at the end, but it took some time to get there.
The story is much better though it wasn't a high bar. It was at least interesting, but certainly nothing to write home about. Lots of the characters can be a little bland and its more of the plot that was interesting to me. The orcs, again, for some reason, have the best voice acting in the game, even when compared to the main characters and people you should care about.

As far as critiques go, I have the same beef with defenders in this game as the first game (see that review), and there are a few other types of captains and captain traits which are straight up annoying and tedious. Olog captains can be very tedious at times and in certain missions the game limits your choices more by intentionally throwing around a lot of immunities which makes this 'play your way' game a lot more 'find what one thing works well this time'. In general, however, things are fine.

Eltariel's campaign is short, but it couldn't be drawn out much longer without being boring.
Baranor's campaign is very interesting (though short), but also can be frustrating if you are used to getting many tries to do things as it is effectively a roguelike.

Overall, very good game, well worth the sale price.

As a dedicated LOTR Fan and almost 100 Hours into Middle-earth: Shadow of War, I can confidently say that this game is nothing short of a masterpiece. Monolith Productions has truly outdone themselves with this sequel, expanding upon the already rich lore of Tolkien's universe in a way that's both respectful and imaginative.

From the moment you step into the shoes of Talion and Celebrimbor, the depth of the world is apparent. The attention to detail in recreating Middle-earth is staggering; every nook and cranny feels like it's steeped in history and significance. The environments, from the fiery depths of Mount Doom to the lush forests of Nurnen, are not only breathtakingly beautiful but also immersive, making every step of the journey feel like a genuine exploration.

The Nemesis System, which was groundbreaking in the first game, has been refined to near perfection. The dynamic relationships with orc captains, the personal vendettas they hold against you, and the way they evolve and adapt to your actions are nothing short of astonishing. It adds a layer of unpredictability and depth that keeps you on your toes, creating truly memorable encounters with every foe you face.

One of the most noteworthy improvements in Shadow of War is the combat system. It's fluid, responsive, and incredibly satisfying. The addition of new abilities and the expanded skill tree allow for a level of customization that caters to various playstyles, making every battle a unique experience. Whether you prefer stealthy assassinations or charging headfirst into the fray, the game accommodates it all seamlessly.

Now, let's talk about the DLCs. They are a true testament to Monolith's commitment to their player community. The expansions, especially the Desolation of Mordor and Blade of Galadriel, not only add significant content but also manage to maintain the high quality and attention to detail found in the base game. They introduce new perspectives, characters, and gameplay mechanics that breathe fresh life into the experience.

Moreover, the story arcs in the DLCs feel like genuine extensions of the main narrative, seamlessly weaving into the overarching lore. They provide a deeper understanding of the world and its characters, offering a more comprehensive Middle-earth experience.

Finally, Middle-earth: Shadow of War is a triumph in every sense. It's a testament to the dedication and passion of the developers at Monolith Productions. With its stunning visuals, refined gameplay, and the incredible depth brought forth by the Nemesis System, this game is a must-play for any fan of Tolkien's universe. The DLCs are not just add-ons; they're essential chapters that enhance an already remarkable journey. As a dedicated gamer, I can't recommend this title enough. HORRENDOUSLY clunky controls. Like, unplayable clunky. Want to escape a battle, well good luck my mate. The run button is also the jump button, so you EITHER walk away from combat at an impossible pace and die, OR you hit the 'run' button, but instead of running you vault over an opponents head, or sprint up the nearest wall. Either way, there is no key combo that will simply let you run away, so you jump around willy-nilly until you die. There is no target lock, instead the game just auto-targets whoever is closest to you, making it almost impossible to actually kill a single target as your character dashes around single-slashing every opponent in range. You'll never actually execute the opponent you want to target, Instead you'll hit anyone else near your target. Usually a lowby NPC, certainly not the NPC you actually wanted to damage. Trying to chase an enemy down? Good luck. As stated, you will hack and dash and slash and jump at anyone near you, constantly missing the only person you are trying to hit. Want to stealth? Good freaking luck my dude. Alt constantly breaks so you can't attack. Plus keys are bound to tab, so you end up holding alt and hitting tab.... Course we all know what alt+tab does, but not WB apparrently. I'm surprised they didn't bind anything to alt+f4

This game is such a mixed bag. 

The first 10-15hours playing it were amazing. I honestly cant remember the last time I had as much fun playing a game. 

But then the issues started getting to me – and started piling up. For the more mechanics the game throws at you, the more it breaks. 

But let me quickly go over the issues – and why I can’t endure more than the ten hours I have had with the game:

- Controls: The controls are… lackluster. 90% of the time, you do what you want to do, but the first time I encountered issues was during the prologue, where I could not get my character to jump through an insanely large hole in a whole I just jumped through. Took what seemed to be 10 attempts and pure luck. And I came very, very, very close to dying because the game really doesn’t like you jumping off walls or over ledges during combat. So you may see your character to ten rolls into a wall instead of jumping it, while enemies pile up on you. 

- Lack of control: It suffers from the same issue as many other games of this type with the game having its own will. Want to run op to an enemy and slash them – you might end up jumping overthem/vaulting them. Want to jump off a building mid combat, you might find yourself rolling on the edge with your character refusing to jump. 
The targeting system of the game is also awful. For example, if one orc attacks you, you can dominate it. Then another orc shows up behind it and you then try to dominate it, you will often target the one you just dominated. Or when fighting a horde of enemies, you might auto-target a character that will actively be impossible for you to damage at that moment, instead of the ten other guys you wanted to target. 


- Unfair and actually broken: This game is honestly fundamentally flawed. Some spots in the game, from what I experienced, are bound to spawn endless enemies. So much so that, and I am not shitting you, 30+ (maybe 50) archers spawned right on top of me. I took a screenshot as proof. This is how unfair the game is at time. 
It will also damage (and potentially kill you) the second a cutscene ends. So that is FUN! 
And this gets even worse when you can try to dominate captains, but they keep spawning enemies. Endlessly. Meaning that you just don’t get a chance to do so and have to finish them off instead. I spent 25 minutes trying to dominate a captain this way and it just didn’t happen. 

- Terrible story: The writing of this game is so bad it is at times funny. I do not care about anything or anyone in the game as it really gives you no reason to. The character development is bad and you are really given zero reason to get invested because the overall story – and writing of it – is, at best, one big cliché and at worst actually bad. 


So what does the game do well? 
- When the combat is fun, it is very, very, very, very fun. (It is mostly fun in the first 10-15 hours. Then it is partly broken by the above-mentioned issues. 

- The orcs are so well designed. They are very well written and acted and I loved encountering the various orcs the game throws at you. This is insanely good! 


But because of all the issues with the games mechanics, I just grew tired of it. I should also mention that once you can dominate orcs, you are told to dominate captains to lead a charge. I spent more than 3 hours trying to get the orcs necessary (think you need at least four) and I managed to get two. Too many of them were too high level and could not be recruited, while I could not recruit several others because of the issues mentioned above. 
That means that the game has you do the same kind of fighting again and again. Nothing new. Same thing. Repeat. Repeat. Repeat. And that is another reason why the game gets VERY stale once you are ten hours into it. Some things do change such as you getting more powerful which is cool, but it is just not enough.

More is not necessarily better. A far departure from the original. So much more trash, much more useless spells, a WoW knockoff gearing feature, With all the trash and captains you can be at it for hours trying to just off them all. Because of this, its a bunch of mindless button mashing. So so busy. Nothing methodical. They should have just kept up with DLC's for the original, added difficulty modes, perhaps made the bosses a bit more difficult, added more regions. Despite it being 3 years older, Shadows of Morder's graphics look better. The lore of the original is much better. This one is silly/childish. Hope the make a remastered version of the original with all the aforementioned features I mentioned.

This game provides such a unique and fun experience all which is owed to the NEMESIS SYSTEM. This patented system ensures that players experience their own unique side story while building armies of orcs and conquering fortresses apart from the main game. Every interaction a player faces with enemies is truly unique and what's astounding is how the nemesis system enables you to form a bond with each orc based off your previous interactions with them. 

- Graphics are superb
- Main story is compelling and has a satisfying end to the duology
- Side quests are fun and repetition is voided somewhat thanks to the nemesis system
- If you've played Shadow of Mordor - then you'd certainly love this game. If you haven't, then this game is definitely worth a try just to get a glimpse of the capabilities of the nemesis system.

Shadow of War is a beautiful and if you let it, challenging game, amazing sequel. The nemesis system is back 20 times as great as it was in SoM, and I loved every hour of it. While the story is not the most innovative thing ever, and doesn't exactly delve deep into Tolkien's lore, it is engaging and the characters are interesting. As soon as I opened the game I fell in love with the soundtrack, the main theme hooked me immediately and I knew it was going to be a unique and epic experience.

The nemesis system is amazing and once again it is truly sad WB licensed it to never use it again, with it you can make your own stories and make your true nemesis immune to most of your attacks making you truly strategize a way to either kill or dominate to join your ranks, another upgrade I felt is that this time Orcs have more fleshed out personalities, which might make you want to keep a few of them forever, yet if you hate one for whatever reason you can just shame him and with some luck he'll stop bothering you.

I've read that when this game came out, it was plagued with micro transactions and long grinding, however, as it is now, I did not feel the need to grind anything to 100% the game, maybe online conquests but those are really fun so no problem there. Speaking of gameplay, feels very similar to SoM with tons of abilities and upgrades to mix and match any build you want, fast paced combat with satisfying finishers. 

A must buy along with Shadow of Mordor, and make sure to play it on at least Nemesis difficulty to experience the most of this masterpiece.

Middle-earth: Shadow of War – A Worthy Successor

Before you make the plunge, consider watching a video or two (or maybe a hundred, your choice!) to ensure it's the game that truly resonates with you.

Middle-earth: Shadow of War - Where Orc-Slaying Is My Full-Time Job, and I Love It!

This game is like that job you never knew you wanted - becoming a professional Orc-slayer! Forget about resumes and interviews; you're armed with swords and bad puns, ready to conquer Mordor.

The game's protagonist, Talion, has one mission: making orcs extinct, one snarky comment at a time. He's like a grumpy gardener, but instead of pruning roses, he's pruning the orc population. He's got a lot of issues with these guys, and he's not afraid to share his feelings. "Nice helmet, did you make it yourself?" - a classic Talion roast.

Speaking of orcs, they have personalities as varied as a bag of mixed nuts. Some will threaten you with bodily harm; others will offer you career advice. It's like being in a job interview with a particularly aggressive HR department.

Then there's the Nemesis System. It's like a soap opera, but with more decapitations. Orcs remember every time you hurt them, and they come back stronger, angrier, and even more determined to make you their personal chew toy. It's like playing a never-ending game of Whack-a-Mole, but the moles are seven feet tall and want to disembowel you.

Don't even get me started on the wildlife. Caragors, graugs, and drakes - oh my! The animal kingdom in Middle-earth is like a mythical zoo gone rogue. You'll ride these beasts into battle, and when you're done, you'll feel like you've just auditioned for a 'Lord of the Rings' remake of 'Jumanji.'

In conclusion, Middle-earth: Shadow of War is an epic journey filled with humor, chaos, and more orc-gore than you can shake a sword at. It's like a rollercoaster ride through Tolkien's wildest dreams, and you're the fearless conductor. So, grab your sword, prepare some clever comebacks, and get ready to slay, laugh, and conquer Mordor, one orc at a time!

If you enjoyed the Batman: Arkham series and/or Shadow of Mordor, this is more of the same. The graphics are a bit better—though the others mentioned are still beautiful looking games—and the enemies are a bit tougher.

They've added a deeper RPG-like influence to the weapon and skill upgrade systems, which is neat, but at least early-on in my game play is also kind of annoying because it's more detail than before. It's just change, and I'm already starting to get used to it. These types of level-up scenarios are always an issue within sequel games because you have to re-earn and sometimes re-learn abilities that you already earned in the first game—it's simply the nature of the beast. Complaint: At least as I'm starting, arrows are tough to come by, so hopefully there's some upgrades to, 1: carry more of them; 2: recharge them in other ways than finding arrow stores (i.e. draining life like the first game.)

The improvement of enemies is also double-edged: the captains are now more intelligent, have additional abilities like surprise attacks, poison disorientation, a sort of teleportation, ability to sweep you off your feet while prone, and are a bit more nuanced than, "Here's another tank you need to beat up." They also have a more robust combination of strengths and weaknesses, so instead of reading one or two traits, you have to spend more time studying and memorizing their attributes.

There is also an element of fighting along side of allied troops, and what appears to be a nemesis engine for your allies, too. I'm yet to see much of this in play, but I assume I'll need to protect them and help some of them rise in their ranks at some point.

I'm sure that I have a lot more to discover within this game and the revisions to the engine, but over-all, so far I'm enjoying the story, the visuals, the audio, and the game play. My desire for mindless destruction of Orcs once again has a purpose!

Awesome game. So much fun.

Rush past Act I as fast as possible because Act II is where it's at. The standard gameplay feels very Arkham and Assassin's Creed-like, but the Nemesis system feels like where all the production value went. Nothing feels quite like slowly building an army of funny lil orcs who say funny lil things. 

Stuff like difficulty balancing and the gear system feel a little poorly designed, and the combat is rough when there's always 50 orcs on the screen doing random stuff. It honestly feels more jank than it should, and cheesing with stealth sometimes feels required.

There are also a fair amount of glitches that will probably just never get patched out. Some are fun like switching skins allowing you to fast travel in combat. Others are not so fun, like captain orcs just disappearing.or your missions just not registering as completed.

That being said, I dealt with that for 40 hours to hang out with the funny haha orcs, so I think it's still worth the pickup, especially with how cheap it gets on sale.

I can't get enough of forcing my followers to fight to the death in the fighting pits for my amusement. Also it never gets old infiltrating 6 spies in a fortress and watch them all gang up on the warchief 10/10 would shame my nemesis again.
