Played a lot on all platforms and I really love this game. One thing that separates this game from others is the nemesis system. This system makes the game unique for everyone. What this system does is it makes every captain you will face in the game random in a wide variety of areas, such as names, skills, weaknesses, voice. Another thing that this system does that I love works somewhat like this. The character you play as is banished from death, meaning every time you die you come back, so any normal ork that kills you becomes a captain and will remember that he killed you and will point it out during your encounters. The game remembers if you run from a fight, if the captain runs from a fight, if the captain kills you, and if you kill the captain. Another thing that can happen is that a captain you killed can come back from death with a scar that relates to how you killed them such as cuts, burn marks, messed up skin from poison and so on. They will remember everything. Something else that you can do later on with captain is recruit them into your own army. This can make for some more interesting encounters such as being saved from death by a recruit or even being betrayed by a recruit. This game is truly awesome and stands as my favorite game of all time and I hope to see even more done with the nemesis system in the future.

What an amazing game!

I love everything from the improved nemesis system that originated in Shadow of Mordor to the improved combat and skills system that can really make you feel like a total badass. I'll just say that I like the changes and improvements that they made here in this game, and compared to Shadow of Mordor's gameplay, it is like putting peanut butter on toasted bread. Though I wouldn't say that it is a balanced game, for me, I just think of it as part of why I feel like a badass playing as Talion. I did encounter some visual and graphical glitches in the base game (e.g., Talion's cape acting weird; Shadows just seems to flicker sometimes, especially on Seregost), but overall it is a good time.

For the story, I would say the beginning (Act I) is decent; it has its ups and downs and didn't really sell me the Gondorian storyline, but it did its job of setting up a foundation for the later acts. In my opinion, the story is much better in Act II, Act III, and Act IV because it introduces other characters, and that's where it picked up its momentum and became interesting (especially the Carnan, Shelob, and Bruz quests), though again, I didn't like the Gondorian quests because the story told is bland for my taste. The epilogue, though, is my favorite part of the story because it expanded, explained, and ended Talion's storyline. Overall, a decent story that gradually went from good to great

This is where I will say that if you have any interest in buying this game, then buy it at a discount because then you can get the bundle, which has Shadow of Mordor and War with all of its DLCs. I really think that just buying the base game will make you wish that you'd bought the DLCs for it too.

The game has it's moments and even fun, but the way too much grind [i](even with the cut-out pay to win)[/i]

At the 21st hour of gameplay, my character is at level 26. Most of the time, I engaged in side quests and building my own Mordor while it was interesting.

The Nemesis system itself is quite interesting and diverse. The enemies have a wide variety of clothing, character traits, and, of course, voices. There are different orc families and initially, it's even engaging. You recruit captains, turn them into spies, conquer leaders, prepare sieges, and level up your commanders... then you repeat it all again. And then again.

As a result, I abandoned the game after capturing the second fortress.

The character level increased very slowly. There are various weapon upgrades and types, but after 10 hours, I rarely bothered to check my inventory to change anything. There is also rare legendary gear, but I came across something useless - to upgrade it, you had to capture an orc of level 40 from a specific tribe. And I realised that I wouldn't play this game for so long.

I can't say much about the whole plot, but the beginning turned out to be childish and disjointed. Some girl guardian, some relic that will help win the war. Spider madame! Most of the time, you're trying to figure out what relates to what. And this is considering that I'm somewhat familiar with the universe, and if needed, I read additional info with interest. But I didn't like the prologue with its naivety and fragmented storytelling.

So, among the positives, I would highlight:
- Still enjoyable combat system
- Captivating Nemesis system
- BRUZ
- A large number of activities

But they have their downsides:
- Ranged weapon enemies will irritate you
- Essentially, apart from invasions and captures, you can't do much else
- Which I've seen only about 7-8 times
- And you'll have to repetitively perform it

The question is only about how much you'll enjoy doing this [i](and spending your free time on it)[/i]

Definitely worth trying with discounts. It's "Shadow of Mordor" on steroids, but I was left rather unsatisfied.

Shadow of War tries to do everything at once and in the end it trips over itself with how many things that it attempts to juggle. As with the previous game, the lore and story is an infuriating fanfiction mess written by an edgy teenager. I'm no Tolkien purist but it's insulting how the world and characters are treated; Shelob is a gothic edgy Galadriel, for some reason Sauron keeps going back to his elf form and it's stupid because why would he, giving all of the Nazgûl identities sort of ruins the point, and then there's the whole Celebrimbor/Sauron ship. Oh and the constant reminders that this is a Lord of the Rings game, how does it do that? By dropping random quotes from the books and movies, the writing itself thinks it's so clever but I only found myself dying inside each time, much like Aragorn Talion.
And that's not all of it, but outside of all of the trashy lore changes the gameplay is actually fun - to a point. Creating your own army, spreading chaos wherever you go keeps being addicting and fun, even sieges are enjoyable.
Then you get to the final part of the game, and guess what? You're at the opposite end of that siege and everything turns into a chaotic, poisonous, burning, exploding, no chance mess.
In all of it you might get four or so orcs going on about how they're going to kill you, and by the end of it, it's tiring because you can't skip any of their monologues. Even the ones that got nothing to say and just stare at you.
Fun gameplay, but it probably will upset you in some way.

I tasked myself with finishing some of my single player games that were gathering dust. This is not the game to do that with. The gameplay loop is quite repetitive, and it gets stale after a little while. Right around the time you're completing what feels like the last story mission, there's the terrible realization that there's still an entire 10-12 hours of grinding left in order to get the actual ending of the game. By the time I reached this point, I was so burned out from the loop that I decided this was one I'd never finish. I think they should've wrapped up the game with the penultimate Act instead of hiding it behind war objectives more obscure than America's military objectives in Afghanistan. There is a bit of a shotgun blast of plot here that does satisfy, even if it is rushed and unpolished. The last "endless" section of the game is perfectly fine, but I really wanted a definitive completion of the game at what I felt was the proper finish line in its storytelling. It wasn't so much a period on a very long, grindy story with lots of distracting side missions and events, but more of a semicolon.

Overall, it's a great game for the money, and the voice acting is on par with the best in the business. All of the casting is perfect.

I played this game back in 2018 originally and I loved this game, has a fantastic story, great endgame loop and an enjoyable multiplayer experience with Conquests If you ever see this game on sale I would pick it up as its honestly a blast. I had recently gone back to the game as like i said i have pretty much always adored this game and going back through it and 100% it reminded me of why i loved it so much.

Without touching on the story too much in order to avoid too many spoilers but i can honestly say that its a fantastic continuation on both the original game and in general for the IP as this is a game that ill admit i had played without having really watched the movies allowing you to enjoy the game and it will tell you what you really need to know. And there are also a number of different collectables scattered around the game which also work to add some more story and general information about the world. And especially when you get into the final act and begin to unlock the new ability to [spoiler] raise the dead [/spoiler] it makes the game so much more awesome and enjoyable. The only flaw id maybe have is with the prologue where the story and the dialogue can be a bit mcguffiny "we need to get this" sort of stuff but that's honestly probably the lowest point of the game in my opinion.

[h1] The Nemesis System [/h1]
[hr][/hr]

Id be doing a bad job reviewing this if i didn't even mention the nemesis system which is single handed responsible for making the endgame as enjoyable as it is if you don't know this is a system which pretty much makes you unique enemies to fight in order to do this every captain has their own weaknesses and strengths which will cause you to change your strategies each time you go to fight one of them.

Like i said this system is pretty much entirely responsible for making the endgame fun as it allows you to be always be facing something new and different the only problem that i have with it is that as of writing this WB games has trademarked the system and haven't used it since.

[h1] The DLC's [/h1]
[hr][/hr]

There are 2 dlcs for this game [i]"Desolation of Mordor"[/i] and [i]"Blade of Galadriel"[/i] these are both dlcs which take place at different points of the game from characters which we dont see the end of throughout the campaign being [spoiler]Baranor[/spoiler] and [spoiler]Eltariel[/spoiler] these take place at different points with [i]"Blade of Galadriel"[/i] taking place first during the main campaign.

[h1] Blade of Galadriel [/h1]

I'll be completely honest i wasn't really a big fan of the dlc it kind of seems to play off like a diluted version of the main game where the nemesis system doesn't really exist and all your doing is these mission which are pretty much fest quest but for captains until you get a finale mission in each of the 4 regions. Although again without saying much for spoilers sake the ending i think is quite good and does make the main story even better as it explains what happened to her.

[h1] Desolation of Mordor [/h1]

Now on the other hand we have [spoiler]Baranor's[/spoiler] dlc which i had really enjoyed, essentially this is a bit of a time based challenge dlc whilst there is a story which i had quite enjoyed after you've done that you're then able to play it for time scores. Although there is something unique to this dlc and that is that he doesn't have a ring of power therefore making him a mortal so if he dies you start at the beginning whilst it may sound very daunting there isn't actually, you pretty much just have to take over 1 region.

But also unlike the previous one theres a number of different abilities as he doesnt get any powers from the ring which change up the ways you fight battles in the mode allowing you to be more creative with what you do. And to close i will mention the replacement for the nemesis system, you use mercenaries these guys look so cool and it also does break up the monotony of fighting with [spoiler]uruks[/spoiler] all of the time and they also look really cool.
One of the best games I have played in years  and my only regret is that it has an end.

For me it's just not a good game. It does not know what it wants to be. Is it stealth? No not really but kind of. Is it a single combat game? Well sometimes it wants to be but again the mechanics are not quite there. Is it a hack and slash where you can kill hordes of enemys? Again, sometimes it wants to be but still isn't just that. Climbing? Yeah sure but not really controllable. Other games just show how to do all of it better. 

Also if you like to be able to be in control you our character and gameplay this game isn't for you. You want the stealth kill the hightlighted target? Well unfortunatly the game decides to jump on an orc outside your vision. You are in the middle of a battle and you're about to recuit a new captain? Well here comes a quick, unpromted, cutscene that resets everything. The gameplay aspect of this game is horrible. The game wants you to fail so the nemsis system makes any sense. While in dark souls you fail all the time but get better and start leaning into certain builds. 

The game mechanics are all over the place and the "nemesis system" is not so great that it can carry the whole thing. 
Story (so far) is also meh and not (quite coherent) *edit* not at all coherent. 

For me not worth 5 bucks in sale but that would certainly the time for anyone to try this game and see if you like it.

Absolutely in love with the detail given to the Orcs in this game. There's so many of them, each with their own names, skillsets, and personalities. My personal favorite aspect of this game are the hundreds of voice lines given to the Orcs. Some of these lines are only heard when specific parameters are met, creating a powerfully immersive atmosphere when interacting with them. For example, in my experience, Orcs have: [list] 
[*]Commented on my ability (or lack thereof) with things like stealth, archery, and poison
[*]Referred to other orcs by name
[*]Recalled their previous encounters with me
[*]Challenged me personally after I had destroyed grog or killed warbeasts
[*]Tracked me down from one edge of the world to the other
[*]Returned from defeat through various means, ready for a rematch
[/list]
And many more, creating Incredible, unique experiences to enjoy on my own and share with others; you will likely have read about some from other players in their reviews. I played the initial storyline for approximately 40 hours and enjoyed every single one, and much of that time was spent admiring the thoughtful development that went into creating our beloved foes, the Orcs.

This may be one of the finest real time strategy action open world RPG there is. The Nemesis system creates organic and dynamic stories about characters that you meet and how you impact their lives and those changes and outcomes then have direct outcomes on game-play, and none of it feels engineered as these events happen naturally during normal play. The game is not flawless, there are occasional issues with combat such as selecting and targeting a specific enemy when trying to use abilities. But beyond that would be getting petty.

[h1]An epic journey through Middle-earth's vastness[/h1]

Middle-earth: Shadow of War is an awe-inspiring continuation of the acclaimed Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor, taking players on an epic adventure through the vast and captivating realm of J.R.R. Tolkien's legendary universe.

From the very beginning, it becomes evident that the developers have put immense effort into crafting a world that not only respects the source material but expands upon it in compelling ways. The attention to detail in the environments, character designs, and lore is commendable, and it's evident that this game was made with a profound love for Tolkien's works.

The story is well-crafted and engaging, offering a captivating narrative that feels like a natural extension of the events in the previous installment. Players assume the role of Talion, a ranger possessed by the elven wraith Celebrimbor, and the journey of their intertwined fates is filled with emotional depth and personal growth. The way the story weaves together with the larger events of Middle-earth is masterful, making players feel like they are an integral part of the grand saga.

The Nemesis system, a standout feature from the first game, is expanded and refined in Shadow of War. This dynamic mechanic creates an ever-changing world where the consequences of your actions ripple through the ranks of enemy forces. Building relationships and rivalries with the Orcs adds a unique layer of immersion, making every encounter feel personal and memorable.

The combat system is fluid and satisfying, offering a diverse range of abilities that can be combined to create impressive and stylish takedowns. As you progress, you gain access to various upgrades and skills that allow for deeper customization of your playstyle, enhancing the sense of empowerment as you become a formidable force in the fight against Sauron's armies.

The world of Middle-earth itself is an absolute joy to explore. Each region is distinct and filled with secrets, collectibles, and side quests that add hours of meaningful content to the game. The attention to detail in recreating iconic locations like Minas Ithil and Mount Doom is a testament to the developers' dedication to authenticity.

Performance-wise, the game runs smoothly, and the visuals are breathtaking. The attention to visual fidelity in capturing the essence of Middle-earth showcases the level of care and craftsmanship that went into making this game.

In conclusion, Middle-earth: Shadow of War is a marvelous experience that transports players deep into the heart of Tolkien's world. It's a celebration of the beloved source material, masterfully executed with a captivating story, engaging gameplay, and stunning visuals. If you have a love for Middle-earth or simply enjoy action-adventure games with depth, this is an absolute must-play.

This review is written on the year 2023. And I still recommend this game for those who enjoy a sort of medieval-themed RPG or people who follows the LOTR series.

Do note that I do not follow the LOTR story or series. The only reason I play this game is because it "looks cool" and people says that the "nemesis" system is good. This review is also written after my first playthrough with Talion on the highest difficulty setting (Gravewalker).

[h1]Story[/h1]
I think the plot is very good yet I think you do need to play Shadow of Mordor first to understand the story since this game is the sequel to Shadow of Mordor (I did not play Shadow of Mordor). The game tries to give a sort of role-play, where the game really tries it's best to immerse you into the world. From grunts talking about you, to enemy captains talking about how many times they've killed you. The nemesis system do gives a sort of role-play experience in a good way.

[h1]Mechanics / Gameplay[/h1]
The movement is a little bit clunky, it's not as fluid as other games but I guess it's good enough. Sometimes you may get scammed by the movement system, but I guess it's fine. 

For the combat mechanics I would say it's good but depends on how you perceive it. For starters there are no "combos", so you would only spam left click to attack which I guess due to the nature of the game (You vs the whole world) does fit perfectly. I dont think most people who are average par gameplay (read: has skill issues) would want to have like 12 attack combos against 12 different people with different mechanics. And you can counter infinite attacks from infinite enemies, though I've never had more than three enemies attack me simultaneously. So as long as you can counter the enemy''s attack you would be fine. 

The game mainly revolves through enemy mechanics, where you need to know how to counter different type of enemies. For example, tanks cannot be countered you can only dodge their attacks. As you progress through the game, you will unlock new moves for some or all types of enemies. So you would have multiple moves to deal damage to that type of enemy.

I also forgot to mention that the stealth mechanic is average, gameplay wise it's fine but if you are looking for that "realism" or "role-play" I guess it's a meh. Imagine running to the front of a grunt and he's just "huh?" and you slit his throat like Ezio from Assasin's Creed. Well I don't know about orc's anatomy but I dont think orcs are that blind to be honest. 

The only thing you would need to grind is probably the orcs. You must want to have an orc who does things exceptionally (read: bashes the brains out of other orcs faster than other orcs). I do spent a lot of times in terms of grinding out orcs since the game also let you fight other people's orcs. 

[h1]My Gameplay[/h1]
Since I am not your average person, I started the game on the Gravewalker difficulty which was the hardest difficulty according to google. At the first stages of the game, I die a lot which I thought was due to picking the hardest difficulty but I guess it was just me figuring the game out. In the mid-game of the story after you unlock some new moves / skills, the game becomes a lot easier. But later on near the end, I guess you will find enemies that are immune to almost everything ? I had a captain who was Immune to Fire, Poison, Curse, Frost, Arrows, Vaults. Had a crossbow that deals curse damage and had the sniper trait (They don't miss and can shoot at long range) and they keep one shotting me and my captains. Spent like 3 hours on the captain and just gave up, luckily it was an overlord of a fortress that I don't need to conquer.

[h1]TL:DR[/h1]
It's a solid 8/10. Eventhough sometimes the mechanics are clunky, and sometimes the game's bugged a bit or even the orcs just literally said "you will die" due to me dying to the same orc about 12 times in a row the game is still pretty solid and I do think you should try the game out.

Middle-earth: Shadow of War is an action-adventure game developed by Monolith Productions and published by Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment. It is the sequel to 2014's Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor, both of which are based on J. R. R. Tolkien's legendarium.

The game received positive reviews from critics, who praised its gameplay, Nemesis system, and visuals. However, the game was also criticized for its microtransactions, which were later removed.

Here are some of the pros and cons of Middle-earth: Shadow of War:

Pros:

Excellent gameplay
Innovative Nemesis system
Stunning visuals
Great voice acting
Tons of content to explore

Cons:

Microtransactions (later removed)
Can be repetitive at times
The story is not as good as Shadow of Mordor

Overall, Middle-earth: Shadow of War is an excellent game that is well worth playing. It is a visually stunning game with engaging gameplay and a great Nemesis system. However, the microtransactions were a bit of a letdown, and the story is not as good as Shadow of Mordor.

Here are some of the things that I liked about the game:

The gameplay is excellent. The game combines action, stealth, and RPG elements in a way that is both challenging and rewarding.

The Nemesis system is innovative. The system creates unique and memorable enemies that can rise through the ranks of Sauron's army.

The visuals are stunning. The game is one of the most visually impressive games I have ever played. The environments are beautifully rendered, and the character models are incredibly detailed.
The voice acting is great. The voice actors do a great job of bringing the characters to life.
There is tons of content to explore. The game world is large and there are many secrets to discover.
Here are some of the things that I didn't like about the game:

Microtransactions (later removed). The microtransactions were a bit of a letdown, as they allowed players to buy in-game currency that could be used to purchase items and upgrades.

Can be repetitive at times. The game can be a bit repetitive at times, especially the combat.

The story is not as good as Shadow of Mordor. The story in Shadow of War is not as good as the story in Shadow of Mordor. It is still enjoyable, but it is not as engaging.

Overall, Middle-earth: Shadow of War is an excellent game that is well worth playing. It is a visually stunning game with engaging gameplay and a great Nemesis system. However, the microtransactions were a bit of a letdown, and the story is not as good as Shadow of Mordor.

[b]Middle-earth: Shadow of War Review[/b]

Middle-earth: Shadow of War is a stellar sequel to a surprisingly great game. The Nemesis System remains the real star of the show in all of its expanded glory, and while its dynamic brilliance threatens to make the main story missions seem boring by comparison, there's enough heft to the overall package that you can look past its shortcomings.

[b]A Good Match For:[/b] LOTR or nemesis system fans, people who'd rather do side missions than save the world, and those who can't resist dominate orcs instead of the main quest.

[b]Not A Good Match For:[/b] People who believe in happily-ever-afters, those who think elves are overrated

Kill orcs, make army, good life

The shadow of Mordor and shadow of war games are hands down the best LOTR video games. 


The game features:

- high action combat

- many skill trees and abilities

- the ability to recruit orcs to your army or to be bodyguards

- large variety of quests and side quests to complete

- fortress raids that require you to use your army and recruited orcs to raid and end with a difficult boss battle, once completed you take control of them and place your own orc gerenerals inside to control it.

- the nemesis system keeps unique orc and orc general combat spicy. Giving each encountered general or special to have specific strengths and weaknesses. 

- enemies can adapt to overused tactics while fighting them, making them immune to said tactic. This provides a good challenge and is interesting to experience mid battle.

- multiple character skins to choose from if you have the dlc

- multiple areas and maps to explore

- encounters where two orc generals fight eachother

- occasionally orcs you killed will reappear stronger then before with a message saying they cheated death

- when an enemy kills you they gain levels and become stronger gradually

- orcs you recruit can be trained and given abilities or weapons using the garrison in your army menu

- there is an equipment system with a wide variety of items and legendary special equipment you can collect by completing challenges in each zone

Overall I would say the shadow games are the best in the LOTR franchise and I highly recommend them.

Rating: 10/10

Combat in this game is a mess. It feels clunky, unresponsive and spam inducing. There are a lot of types of enemies, but all you do against all of them is just smashing your LMB until everyone dies. There is an attack that lets you execute downed enemies, and this attack looks cool at first. But after a couple of hours of playing you will get absolutely bored of it, because there are only around 5 animations for this attack. And lack of animations is not the biggest problem, the biggest problem is that every time you attempt to execute a downed enemy, you will almost certainly be interrupted by another nearby orc, which makes this attack absolutely useless in any fight that involves more than 1 enemy. Yes, there is a perk that allows you to block while executing an enemy, but this perk is locked by a considerable character level requirement, and it still has no effect against the ranged orcs who will just throw their shit at you from a 20m distance, without any visual cue. It is a playable game if you are not too demanding towards melee combat mechanics, but for me, this game is just too shallow in it's combat system to be enjoyable.

Much like the first but more skills, expanded nemesis system with more crazy orcs, and some more interesting missions. While the first feels a little basic outside grinding the other orcs, the story gets a lot longer with more interesting mission ideas. I'd still say the first gives more context to the revenge plot and has some more likable characters (I don't mind Shelob as a character, but not like this) but they certainly expand it this time around. Biggest problems: the Nemesis system is expanded meaning you can get trapped grinding against a stronger orc with no weakness or forces you to coordinate with the AI to poke at them, also the microtransactions have since been removed for a better experience but might still feel grindy. It still forces you through a tutorial before you can really start up your own army, that's fine and all but especially after coming off of the prequel I think people might want to just start branding their own army. While there can be some fun orcs across the game it feels like you rarely see the very fun ones or they never spawn as legendary elites and can be short lived. So you might end up getting a nemesis with someone who just likes to skin people while the bard, skull armor design, or even the explosive crossbow type don't make as big an impact as you'd like unless you do brand them and slowly level them up to prevent losing them.

While the first felt half finished but had a really cool feature, this feels like it was working towards being a full game around that feature and making the most of everything else the player can do. The ranger fantasy is stronger as you unlock skills and get used to using almost everything you've got as orcs adapt more often, and there are a few homages to LotR as a series as well as a few interesting ideas the first didn't feature. Some have less heart, I still love the dwarf from the first game but he does feature in the DLC one life challenge run and there are still other interesting characters with the expanded story. Get it on discount or you might even justify full price.

Some orc captain named Ugol kicked my ass so hard i could taste my own cheeks. He levels up and hides in his lil orc camp like a bitch. I get some intel on him and find out hes allergic to poison. Now i'm a bit butthurt about my butt hurting so i sneak into his camp and poison the local watering hole. Five orcs in the area (including Ugol) drink it up and die horribly. i do a little jig on his corpse and go on with my day. Just as i'm about to execute a random orc captain, lo and behold Ugol arrives looking like a chewed up piece of bubblegum to ambush me. He laughs about cheating death and says many things that hurt my feelings. He also has poison attacks now but he is still allergic to poison... Luckily my bow has a chance to apply poison, so i gun that bastard down until he looked like Nickelodeon slime on the floor. I thought that was the end of his heroic tale until he shows up YET AGAIN to ambush me as i'm attacking another orc captain. At this point i lost my shit, this fetus monster cheats death TWICE and is still allergic to poison. How many times do i gotta teach you this lesson old man? I poison his frail body for the third time and watch him spaz out on the floor. I wish i didn't though, because he never came back after that. I'm sorry Ugol, i wish we could of had a proper fight instead of cheesing you three times in a row. I miss you buddy.

The game isn't canon to LOTR universe, but the story is really good (except some strange plot twists) and Nemesis system REALLY nailed it here. SOW is better than SOM in many terms except atmosphere and character design IMO (Talion in SOM looks WAYYY different than in SOW). The game is so UNIQUE and the feeling of being immortal half elf half man hybrid who can't die (obviously as i said ''immortal'') makes it really fun. You basically make your army ALONE by dominating orcs minds by making them on of your own and capture fortresses. However they can betray you and you can shame them (pretty cool option) which leads to making them weaker and in some cases crazy (literally). I forgot to say that the orcs have very funny personalities and every one of them is UNIQUE (Uniqueness is the thing that makes this game so good)
The DLCs are also fun especially the DESOLATION OF MORDOR DLC

Overall i give it a solid 8/10

This is in my personal top 5 of my most favorite games of all time! Its so engaging and fun that I've put in over 500 hours of gameplay on my xbox! The environments are gorgeous, the combat is engaging, the story keeps your attention, and the variety of uruks you can recruit are nearly limitless! The highlight of the game is of course the nemesis system, in which you can make your own arch nemesis based on how many times they kill you or cheat death. The more unique uruks appear early in the games story so after an amount of time the captains get dull unfortunately. But the pit fights and fortress attack/defense are always a blast! I highly recommend if you are a big fan of Batman:Arkham style combat, and the Lord of the Rings universe. 5/5!

Do you like constant, disorienting zoom-ins? Blades going right through enemies without hitting? Getting stuck on flat terrain, CONSTANT PAUSES IN ACTION FOR YET ANOTHER ORC TO GIVE A SPEECH or retreat or be enraged, all coupled by a zoom-in that leaves your perspective in that direction, even when they're only in the general vicinity? A lot of work could have been done to improve this game, and unlikely to be worth a purchase even at this late date. Definitely won't be paying for any DLC. After a second playthrough with a total of almost 222 hours entire, I can safely say that this game was a significant disappointment. I do not recommend buying it, though I will say that the premise of the Nemesis System is pretty neat. If only those QoL improvements could have been made. Oh well, they got their cash-grab. Uninstalling for the final time.

Middle-earth™: Shadow of War™ is an epic action-adventure game that immerses you in the rich and captivating world of J.R.R. Tolkien's Middle-earth. With its engaging storyline, visceral combat, and innovative Nemesis System, it takes the gameplay to new heights. The vast open-world environment allows for exploration and discovery, while the strategic depth of building an army and conquering fortresses adds another layer of excitement. The attention to detail, stunning visuals, and seamless integration of the Lord of the Rings lore make Middle-earth: Shadow of War a must-play for fans of the franchise and action RPG enthusiasts alike.

Don't know who still wants this but just in case, I don't recommend. Time and money is precious and that is why I am telling you. Don't be like me and waste it on this P - O - S.

Basically Ubisoft open world with Assassin's creed style movement and Batman Arkham series combat without anything that makes that combat great. Tack on a 'number go up' RPG system and this is what you get. Funny considering both this and arkham were made by WB but then again no wonder MTX ridden, pointless cookie cutter crap was still making the cut given it's WB what with their recent Gotham S - h - i - t - e - s.

Quests are generic pointless kill dudes or kill dudes with special conditions like not breaking stealth, find dudes, cut and use dudes nut - sacks. Story that is part of this or otherwise is also pointless. Don't know what happened to half of the nut - jobs including Idril and Baranor. 'Twists' are not memorable and a minor footnote. The rest is just Kelly Bimbo wanting to kill Sauron and rule. Don't know what else there is to it. Side quests are just as bad. There is nothing to think about, nothing to chew on so it really doesn't have story going for it which would be fine if the rest didn't s - u - c - k.

Army building is a fine idea but the execution is just drawn out busy work with individually fighting and recruiting a bajillion dudes. Doesn't help that the nemesis system spits out dudes all too often that can be immune to everything but one tactic so you have to abuse it or cheese them some way else. More so if they have the 'attack sponge' trait. Made all the more worse in the 'epilogue' where every other orc is 10 levels higher. Again worsened if they 'adapt' and render your tool useless as well. Also doesn't help that in higher difficulties they can one or two shot you if they are the same or higher level. Thanks for so much grind and busy work.

Arkham works by not just giving one dude immunity to everything but giving a little bit of something to everyone and then mixing it up and stacking the odds just ever so slightly again and again so you have to form a strategy on how to take your enemies down. Same in good games like Doom/Doom Eternal. You learn the basics and then learn how to master your tools. Here every so often they'll give you a wall and tell you to break it with your teeth. 

The skills seemed cool and would have been fun to play around with. It just doesn't help that your guy will target whoever he pleases as opposed to who you want. That is one of the most obnoxious things about combat in this game. Some others I can remember is domination, you know the main thing you do against orcs, is just painfully useless in combat save for one perk allowing some use. Of course you give up being able to shoot arrows more than a few times for it. Also nothing has been done to help you navigate the cluster eff when there are like 50 orcs on screen back to back and you can't see which one next to you is moving to attack you let alone how many there are to begin with. Sure there is the indicator but I personally don't find that alone helpful especially in that visual noise. That also hurts the combat a lot.

The above is compounded by another favorite of the industry, 'number go up' RPG mechanics. It's all about reducing damage taken and maximizing damage dealt. You'll find lots of things you could use to strategize with cool effects only to realize you've outstripped it very soon. Get ready for more busy work to 'upgrade' it by finding 'currency'. And on top, you have to complete challenges if it's special gear like play 5 games of whack the orc captains that far exceed your level. No cool builds for you! You have to grind for it!

Speaking of currency, you require it for other things as well such as siege offense/defense. It isn't too bad until the epilogue where you'll be attacked by level 300 forces and to get your defenses there you'll have to spend all the 10 - 20 k on one defense that you might have spent your entire campaign building up. And this whole attack defense thing you will have to go over at least half a dozen times to complete the story. I don't care to find out beyond that. And just to be clear, this is done once you have built your army in each region to being your assault.

Collectathon also plagues this game with collectibles in every region. The rewards are nothing remarkable from what I've played. Just wood for the 'number go up' fire.

I think I've spoken enough about the main thing, the nemesis system but to add a little more, I don't think it really does much other than add more busy work by spitting out new dudes for you to kill. It does not really feel well implemented.

And that's all that I can think of. I hope you found this review helpful. I certainly believe the fun per unit time in this review is more than in the game and if nothing else, this review is certainly less of a time waste than the game.

I really wanted to like this game, especially after finishing Shadow of Mordor. The nemesis system was fun, the graphics are good for 2017, and the pre-rendered cut scenes are great. But the negatives that I found were way too apparent and lasted THROUGHOUT the game. The in-game cutscenes were buggy and lacked any sort of consistency. The characters were all boring and flat aside from ratbag and Bruz. The controls were terrible, it felt like you could never jump to the spot you wanted, and sometimes would launch off a ledge. Too many re-used quests but in different areas. I could go on. 

Overall, it felt as though they innovated the nemesis system but fell short everywhere else. After the first couple hours, you've basically seen everything. I hope you enjoy doing the same "save you men tied to a pole" quests or "follow some dumb character to an ambush" mission.

Argh. Yes, I WILL keep playing this game, it's not THAT bad. But no, I DON'T recommend it.

2 reasons. 1 important, 1 just an annoyance. 

The important one first. While they've certainly made some extensions and improvements since Shadow of Mordor, like variety and in captains etc, they've messed up something fundamental. Somehow, the quests and story don't flow at all. In SoM, while you were relatively free to wander around, do things at your pace, you still felt driven by a coherent story and things moving you forward. This one, however, has none of that. Actually, there's no flow at all. You can pick any quest, do any thing. but I didn't feel a driving level of coherence. It's hard to explain, but when you play it, you'll probably get it. This is just a lesser game where somehow you don't feel as invested in the character, the journey, it's somehow hollow. THAT'S the reason I don't recommend it.

As for the second thing, once again, lazy-ass companies not fixing their **** on PC is just getting annoying. This game was released 6 years before I write this review. 6 years. And the memory cut scenes with Shelob, for example, STILL don't work. Which means they never will. Do a search anywhere, you'll see just how long this problem has been flagged for. I refuse to believe this would have been that hard a bug to fix. But PC plays second-fiddle to consoles once again. And I struggle to see how that makes sense - PC gaming is far from dead, and is still and incredibly rich source of cash. So **** you guys for treating us like this, once again...

[h1]These are hard times for the forces of good in Middle-earth...[/h1]

I decided to play this game because I watched a lot of Lord of the Rings and The Hobbit movies. I liked the game very much. Interesting storyline that tells of Talion's struggle with the forces of darkness in the vastness of Mordor. 

Quite interesting character progression with different skills and equipment. Possibility to fly a dragon, take over fortresses, recruit orcs of different classes and abilities, you can arrange orc fights in the fighting pits.

Good graphics for its years. The developers also introduce free DLC, which improves the textures and story clips in 4K.

Cool character voice acting. It was nice to listen to the English voiceover.

Cons:
1. intrusive dialogues that take place with orc captains. It was tiring and annoying more than anything else. At first it was interesting to listen to what the orc was saying and thinking about you, but in the process it starts to get boring. The problem here is that you can't skip these dialogues in any way and have to listen all the time. Maybe I haven't found how to turn it off.
2. After passing the game, it is unclear what happened to Idril next. If the story Baranor tell us in one of the DLC, with Idril is unclear.

In general, I really enjoyed the game and had a desire to pass it 100%. Very sad at the end for Talion and his fate. It took 105 hours (or 47 days) to get through 100% of the game, including the two DLC and all the achievements.

You will spend more time trying to find a way around the bad programming than actually playing with the games mechanics. 

I feel like even the game sometimes doesn't know how it killed you.
Just as an example, standing afk at a fast travel point(a literal safe zone), never entering combat is a valid way to kneel over and croak. You can imagine how fun that is when it unnecessarily loses you a scripted fight and resets your progress. Ressources are also not restored if you retry a mission.

Less noticeable on normal difficulty as you can recover most of the time or just replay the mission and be done with it, but when I restarted on high it really became apparent how much the game just screws you and how much you actually fight against the game instead of the enemies.

So yeah, the game could be really fun, if it actually worked. Graphics are good though.

This is one of the best games I have played...ever. Something I can get back to and start playing any time. The Nemesis system is really one of the most radical innovative ideas in modern RPGs and guarantees engaging encounters during gameplay.

Imagine this, you've been stalking an enemy for a while and weakening him piece by piece. You've killed his captains, turned his commanders against him. And when you're about to finish him off...you get ambushed. By one...no, two...no, three powerful enemies and suddenly you're completely outgunned and outmatched. Would you hold a grudge against those collections of pixels and data who derailed your hours of planning and work? That's what the Nemesis system does to you as a player. Turns what would be just another enemy into a memorable character.

Just the other day, I killed a Captain...an Orc who had deathly fear of Morgai flies. But he didn't die. Instead, he returned. A half eaten but still alive corpse who had suffered such extreme PTSD (having been burrowed into by the objects of his biggest fear) that his mind broke. And now he embraced the flies. And preached that dying and rotting was the destiny of all.

Naturally, I killed him again!

But he survived. Once. Twice. A third time. The fourth time I was sure that was the end of poor Lord of The Flies.

Nope. Sure enough, he returned.

So here I am, decapitating an enemy I've killed four times before a fifth time. And I realize, that's exactly how the Orcs feel about "Gravewalker", the character we play. They may succeed in killing us once, twice, twenty times. But we always return with a vengeance. And that must give them sleepless nights.

At this point, I don't know if I'll see Lord of The Flies again...but I hope I do. I have...sort of...gotten attached to this enemy Orc who keeps coming back as a familiar face, more deranged each time.

All in all, 10/10 recommended game. Can't give enough praise to the makers for making this amazing duo of Middle Earth games. And I hope they make more!

It deserves his title as a successor and finished up the game storywise quite nicely. The authors tried to keep the books in consideration and do not change any outcome for movies and books.

As for the gameplay, well, you have your basic talion things, all in all the fighting is as to be expected. It is not hard, as most fights come down to reflexes, and pushing the right buttons that appear on the screen. But the AI is one of the most predictably annoying things there is:
while unlocking some skill, you will have e.g. the freeze ability. If an enemy is frozen, you can attacking him with high frequency and finish with a huge swing. During your attack, every orc around you will charge you and start attacking you -> you either stop attacking the frozen enemy and counter others or you get hit and staggered and stop attacking. This will happen multiple times as long as other orcs are around you. Same goes for taking over orcs, the enemy ai always tries to interrupt you no matter what.

This is also best played with mouse and keyboard. Most of the default key settings fit, but aiming with a controller (as you have to shoot with your bow quite often) is as expected very annoying and slow.

Solid 7/10, should be bought if on sale.

[h1]This is yet another game that I have very mixed feelings about. On one hand, the good parts of this game are REALLY good, but on the other hand, the bad parts are REALLY bad.[/h1]

The worst part of this game by far is the story. I'm sure most people aren't even playing this game for the story and I don't blame them - it's total trash. There is not a single well-developed character or plot point throughout the entirety of what I have seen, with the only possible exception being the questline with the Mother Nature character. The Gondorians are very underwhelming, having no proper development, but still acting as if they are the most important characters in the game. Throughout their questline, the main character essentially spends half the time standing off to the side. Shelob is also meant to be an important character, but she purely exists to serve as a plot device and might as well not even be in the game at all. The questline with the female elf features her constantly degrading and talking down to the main character, even though she does little to contribute to the story, herself. All of this is combined with a general lack of direction - the main story is supposed to be about the main character taking down Sauron, and yet every quest feels like a sidequest, with little coherent focus on that primary objective. The best writing this game has to offer unironically comes from an orc who returns from the first game and has some genuinely enjoyable banter with the main character. However, the fact that this comic relief character has the best writing in the game just emphasizes how bad all of the serious writing is. I've heard that this game doesn't even have a good ending and I'm finding it difficult to motivate myself to see it all the way through.

However, like I said, this game does have some genuinely great elements to it - more specifically, the gameplay. Basic combat is similar to that of the "Batman: Arkham" games, but it works very well here. Aside from the game's auto-targeting sometimes causing you to attack the wrong enemy, combat feels very fluid and provides just enough challenge to keep you engaged. There are multiple ways to mix up your playstyle if you want, you can seamlessly transition back and forth between stealth and combat, and there are many ways to incorporate parkour and ranged attacks into your gameplay.  Furthermore, I think most people can agree that the main selling point of this game are the orcs and the conquest systems. It really is a lot of fun dominating orc captains, building your army, sabotaging enemy warchiefs, and slowly taking over regions of Mordor one at a time. Sometimes things go well and captains can be recruited easily, sometimes things go wrong and you get ambushed or a captain you killed comes back to life. Regardless, the game's "Nemesis System" does a good job of rewarding strategic planning while also throwing in some surprises to keep you on your toes.

Ultimately, if you played the first game and just want an excuse to fight and dominate more orcs, this game will definitely deliver. The gameplay is an absolute blast, but I am really fed up with the abysmal level of writing that this game consistently churns out.

[h1]Overall, its fun and fast paced.[/h1]

[b]Good -[/b] 
The Nemesis system can and will turn a simple quest into a "skin of your teeth" fight when more than one captains show up at the wrong time. This doesn't happen constantly, but is surprising when it does. 
The combat and movement is largely well done.
Castle takeovers are a fun and somewhat customizable for what they are. 
The music fits, not bombastic, but goes well with the atmosphere. 
The graphics are surprisingly good for being a little old.

[b]The Bad -[/b] 
There are a couple parts in the Life-Tree/Balrog questline that are obtuse and frustrating.
Your captains seem to have a slight tendency to betray you, which is fine, but it happens maybe a little too often, especially if they happen to get killed in an arena. 

Its honestly a fun game, that has some funny dialogue in it. Some parts actually have heart. Did not expect that from this game. 
I don't know how soon I will replay this after finishing it for the first time. 
I recommend it if you're looking for an interesting and unique game.

Can't bring myself to finish it. There's so much promise - huge open world, the nemesis system where orcs will come back and harass you later is brilliant. All the orcs chanting the name of the boss before you fight, then shrieking "He's killed Grok the Skewerer!" after you win, with seemingly endless permutations, is a gift that just keeps on giving. The story is well-woven and original and the voice acting is top-tier. Gameplay is fluid and fun, and gory and gorgeous.

BUT
There's not enough character progression after the midgame. The leveling system basically allows you to craft your character early on, and then you have to sacrifice a perk to take another. I'm happy with my character config, so now leveling up is a waste of time. The item system is decent, but it's not Diablo or Borderlands level of loot. So the story is the only reason to keep playing. It's an open-world game so the story is only a bonus, really - it's not worth grinding for.
Can't bring myself to finish it.

Assassin's Creed for middle earth might be an interesting concept, but the story sucks and the makers of the game have no respect for your time at all.
Every time you come across an enemy captain they will give a 10-20 second  UNSKIPPABLE dialogue.  They can be interesting, because they say different things based on what is happening or has happened, but they get old pretty quickly.  The choice to listen to them isn't there, you HAVE to listen to them.   The makers of the game decided they didn't want to make the ESC button (or any other button...) simply end it.

The Shadow of War/Mordor games are examples of how to do a non-canon story right. The games are clearly intended to tie into Peter Jackson's film trilogy more so than Tolkien's books, as they use very familiar portrayals of certain locations/characters shown in the films. They do a good job of respecting the films for the most part, with a few glaring exceptions. Despite not being canon, the story serves as a fascinating "What If" scenario depicting if [spoiler]Celebrimbor survived as a spirit and launched a war on Sauron.[/spoiler] Most importantly, it feels like a Middle Earth story through the great use of Tolkien lore and source material. Playing these games was like therapy after watching Rings of Power.

Beyond the story, the Nemesis system elevates the game by turning what would be mundane and repetitive Orc enemies into interesting characters with unique stories. The world reacts to your actions in the game - if you run from battles, install a spy in enemy ranks, kill or recruit certain captains, other captains and even random orcs will comment and discuss these things dynamically in the world. Orcs can ambush you, betray you, cheat death and try to kill you, or your own followers can save you in a critical moment or betray their own warlords. It's a shame that WB has patented this mechanic so we are unlikely to see it in other games any time soon.

The game that's so incredibly good that even I, Mr Larson, the man who never replays games even played it again some years later after I initially finished around the release date. 

Obviously what carries this game through and through is the nemesis system and all the games various orcs. When game companies try to market their games as multiple choice and that it is YOUR own unique adventure, it usually just boils down to making a few choices here and there that's scripted, however here in shadow of war you truly make your own unscripted decisions ALL the time. You get your own personal stories and relationships with all these different types of orcs ( except for a few story scripted ones ). You hunt and roam the lands and try to find the best and coolest looking orcs that you like the most. You'll get rivals that manage to kill you and every time you fight them they talk about your latest battles, it is truly a great, living and immersive world. 

The combat is a bit like the Batman games, but I think it is way different enough here though. You truly feel like a god in this game at times, you are EXTREMELY powerful, however the orcs can be extremely powerful as well. You can kill thousands of orcs on your own, however, one single orc can kill you as well if you don't pay attention. I heavily recommend playing this game on BRUTAL difficulty. In this mode you won't meet a lot of bullet sponges ( i guess in this case sword sponges ) and you'll do a lot of damage, but you gotta remember that you can get two hit by a lot of orcs as well, even one hit at times, but you will automatically start with a perk that lets you survive one death, you can upgrade it later to being able to survive twice, however some orcs just say screw you and completely ignore that perk. (It's an in game feature.)



The story is really awesome as well, I have never really been super interested in the lord of the rings universe, I watched the movies as a kid but not much more, but I really think that the lore and world in this game is amazing and interesting. You play as Talion who's binded with an elven spirit, the bright lord who try to claim back Mordor from the dark lord. More then that I won't say but it's a great story which will keep you hooked. I also appreciate that you can get some cutscenes only by getting some collectibles, never have I seen better collectibles. Usually I feel like collectibles in games are always quite useless and are just there to push lore they were too lazy to include in the main story, however I do not think that applies here.

If they were to make another game I'd say there are some issues that they would have to fix. 


1. Online battles are pure jokes. All orcs you're going to fight from other bases or avenging are just going to be max leveled and all of them have been made in a lab (aka made in cheat engine) and you won't be able to best them, all of your orcs are probably just going to die in a battle. 

2. The meta with all orcs is just that you will have to try to make them immune to everything and have them get enraged to everything. I think there's way more interesting stuff that you could use for orcs to make them unique rather then just having them be completely resistant to fire for example even though that orc has NO armor on him and he is just naturally resistant to it which makes no sense.

3. There should be more voices on orcs and more variety. The more you play you will soon realize that there are about... I'd say maybe 15 different types of orcs who all just wear different kinds of armor. It's also extremely immersion breaking when you meet an orc and kill him for example, and then in the next fort you go to you find the exact same orc but under a different name. Same armor, same voice, same build, same everything but just a different voice. They should really add more of a variety factor on it.
 
4. The fact that Nazgul are WAY too easy. Nazgul in this game are supposed to be the controllers of orcs and shown to be extremely powerful in cutscenes and lore. However, when you fight them time literally slows down when you have to counter them, they're a damn joke in actual combat and it sucks because then it becomes this classical thing of actual gameplay being totally different to the cinematics. A random commander orc with a bow who has the right stats is more powerful then the dark lord himself which makes no damn sense and it's quite funny yet sad when you think about it.


All in all though even with those problems I think this is a super great game with a good story, combat, systems and general gameplay. 9/10.

Genuinely one of the best games I've ever played. It starts out a little boring, since the only thing to do aside from the main story is killing orcs, but once you reach Act II, the game really picks up, since it allows you to have many interactions with the same orc captains, and form relationships with them.

The combat is fluid and fun enough to keep the typical person entertained through Act I, but it's not really what the core of the game is. The core of the game is the Nemesis System. Basically what the Nemesis System does is that when an enemy kills you, they get more powerful, but more than that, they remember that they killed you. Not to mention that your enemies can occasionally cheat death if you kill them, and they'll remember that you killed them, so they'll come back with a figurative axe to grind and a literal axe in their head. I feel like the best aspects of the Nemesis System could best be demonstrated through stories.

One of my late-game nemeses was Zoruk Runnybowels. Yes, his name referenced his diarrhea, trust me, he was more intimidating than he sounds. He was the bane of my existence throughout Gorgoroth, but eventually I got together a team of 3 of captains that worked for me, and sent them all to murder Zoruk dead. We succeeded! Then he cheated death almost immediately, and went right back to kicking my ass, except now it was personal for him.

He killed me, and that's when I discovered that he had killed me so many times he got promoted to Warchief. I could draw him out in a warchief mission, but instead I continued building my army. I eventually had an army whom's strength I trusted, and we went to capture the fortress. This was where I finally put an end to Zoruk Runnybowels. We captured the first of 4 victory points, guarded by Zoruk, and he began running to protect the next point. I would not allow this.

I shadow-strike pulled him back to me, and we participated in a 1v1 battle. I actually even killed some of the grunts who came to help me, because I felt that would be unfair to Zoruk, and I wanted him to know he lost. In a video game. I felt like I had something to prove to an NPC.

Since we'd already captured the victory point, no grunts came to help Zoruk either, and I managed to bring him down to zero health. He fell on his knee, and I was prepared for the coming QTE to land the finishing blow, when he started giving a speech. I don't recall exactly what he said here, but I'm just gonna say he quoted Thanos and said "You should have gone for the head." He got back up, revealing he had the Death Defying trait, and by now he had adapted to most of my different types of attacks, so he kicked my ass.

I tried a second attempt to capture the fortress, and things went similarly at first. We captured the victory point, I got a 1v1 duel with Zoruk, but instead of bringing him down to zero health, once he was broken I grabbed him. Since we were in Gorgoroth, there was a river of lava running right down the streets of the fortress, so I tossed Zoruk into the lava.

I went on to capture the fortress, and finally breathed a sigh of relief, knowing that Zoruk was finally gone... Until he cheated death again, coming back as Zoruk the Flame of War. But that's a story for another day.

I might have an infatuation with the LOTR universe but hey, the games still an amazing piece of work, I havent researched or looked up if theres going to be another but if there isnt, I still will always have this amazing piece of art to come back to and enjoy as literally everything in this game is put together so beutifully

I have over 100 hours in this game and I have really enjoyed it and I hope to keep having fun playing it. The unique Nemesis System allows for creating a story between you and orcs. With the Nemesis  you can have really memorable relationships with an orc. I still remember some of the orcs from when I first started playing the game, and I still have some from when I first started. The game can get a little boring and grindy after you finish the story missions and if you are not getting a good rivalry with an orc, best way to fix that is to play on Brutal or Gravewalker difficulty, those are definitely the difficulties you should start out with. It can feel so fun commanding an army to take over a fort too. Overall this game is pretty fun even thought it can get boring and stagnant at times, but that makes getting an actual nemesis more interesting.

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
Buy game on Sale (I say $30 bucks max)

[h1]Summary[/h1]
My time with Shadow of war felt like a chore.  It features a highly repetive system that veterans from shadows of mordor, like myself,  hated from the first game.  At the time of writing this review I have pretty much done 100% of the game within 30 hours of gameplay.  I bought this game for $30 bucks so that traslates to $1 for every hour of semi-entertainment.  There is not enough content to buy at $60. DO NOT BUY IT AT $60!!!!!  

[h1]First lets talk about what I enjoyed,[/h1]

- Combat System makes your character look awesome (very assassin creed like)

- Had some cool lore

- The Nemesis System was improved upon from the previous title by adding new traits

- Fort sieges were really fun in the beginning of the game

- The addition of mounted drakes was awesome

- Implementing an online system so you can challenge other player's overlords, avenege 
them from a captain that killed them, and take over forts they own.

- Spoiler: [spoiler] Becoming a Ring Wraith was awesome in my opition. Being able to raise the dead and summon soldier wraiths was fun [/spoiler]

[h1]Now lets look at the many things that made me want to throw my chair out the window,[/h1]

- The targeting is absolute trash, the game defines where you want to go based on where your character is facing (like older assassin creeds) instead of where your character is looking (which made assassin creed origins so great). Many times I found my self doing a stealth attack on the wrong character or jumping off a tall building when I was trying to jump to another.  Parkor on a mount is even worse.  It will climb ANYTHING you walk near.

- if too many normal enemies surround you while fighting, it is very easy to get chain attacked and lose all health before you can do anything.

- It is very hard to form any attachment to any NPC.  Though I really want to,  I find it hard to love any of the characters in this game

- Once you got the combat system down the game was way to easy.  I found my self killing captain in about 20 seconds even if they were a much higher level than me.

- I didn't find pit fights very entertaining.  I just used it to kill off all the captains I did not want to spawn new ones

- Spoiler: [spoiler] Act IV is so lazy you literally go around upgrading you forts and defending them for hours on end with no real objective or story to it.  The game really ends on act 3 which I achieved around hour ten of my game time[/spoiler]

- Spoiler: [spoiler] the game ending was absolutely terrible.  You can tell the developers were in a time crunch and needed to end the series to make sale dates [/spoiler]

- Game was way to short in my opinion.  If you knew what you were doing you could finish missions in a couple of minutes

- Enemy Monologues can range from a few seconds to what feels like hours plus they are unskipable.  It gets worse when you engage more than one captain at a time. Just another way they try to cram there fancy system down the players throats. 

- I felt there was very little customization options in the game settings.

One of my favourite Triple-A releases in the modern era of gaming. Endless replayable fun in one of the most engaging combat and war sandboxes in perhaps all of gaming. It's a unique experience you can't get from any other game, and there's a reason I've replayed the entire game from start to finish three separate times over the six years it's been released.

And to take this even further, it's also set in the world of The Lord of the Rings, which gives it an added edge in terms of lore and intrigue. While the main story itself is nothing special; it's closer to fan fiction than anything else, the game is self-aware and doesn't waste your time. It knows that the story is just a vehicle to contextualise the game play, and it does this excellently with many surprisingly compelling characters. This game just wouldn't be as fun if it tried to tell a long, serious, cinematic story.

My only criticisms of the game are:
The initially scummy microtransactions WB Games forced into the experience, along with some especially mediocre DLC, Fortunately, the microtransactions have been completely removed, and instead all the benefits you could have gotten from that system are given out with an in-game economy with plentiful currency, so you never feel like you have to grind even on the hardest difficulty.
The game definitely isn't balanced or designed around "Gravewalker" or "Brutal" levels of difficulty, with enemies often attacking you during animations such as the captain intros or captain "fleeing/enraged" cutaways, causing you to immediately take significant damage, and getting one shot by captains in this difficulty isn't unusual. This also happens often; sometimes you could be executing an enemy and another orc is swinging at you during the i-frames of the animation, and you get frame-trapped into taking a hit afterwards.
Gravewalker/Brutal also makes stealth more difficult, making some of the stealth challenges in-game nearly impossible. This clearly wasn't tested.
Enemies can also be bizarrely aggressive sometimes, in ways that can feel inconsistent. Some enemies will unnaturally leap and lock onto Talion from great distances while they're attacking, particularly if they're enraged. This doesn't match their steps, causing them to unnaturally float or leap towards you in a manner that looks janky, unnatural and always catches me off guard. Also, when approaching enemies in stealth, enemies are supposed to be briefly surprised, giving you a chance to perform a stealth attack in this brief reprieve window. For some reason, this just doesn't work if there seems to be an arbitrary number of orcs, like three or more, spotting you simultaneously, causing you to just stumble around like a goof because you can't attack from stealth- which I'm not a huge fan of, and takes some getting used to. 
Sometimes this brief surprise window doesn't happen at all, and the enemy instantly locks onto you with a quick attack that comes out in 0.1–0.2 seconds. This type of hit often gets me the most because even if it can be countered, it's so quick and unexpected that I can't react fast enough.

Overall, Brutal and Gravewalker difficulty are still fun; you just really have to go into it with the perspective that the game is actively not being fair, and you should absolutely not play fair either. This does create a problem where you're encouraged to cheese encounters and only use the absolute strongest methods like Shadow Strike Pull or summoning a Graug, especially when the stakes are high. Playing like this isn't necessarily the most fun, though, so I recommend your first playthrough be on Nemesis difficulty; it's definitely a much better balanced experience with less severe consequences for the game's janky moments.
If you like to play open-world and sword combat, then this is your cup of tea

REWRITE

This game is best played as it was intended to be played; to abuse the shit out of the Nemesis System.

First and foremost, yes the game is awesome. The combat is flashy and satisfying, the story is mediocre at best but enjoyable enough to have enough bright moments to keep you playing for a solid amount of time, and the Nemesis System gives you infinite replayability so you'll never get bored of the game.

The improvements over Shadow of Mordor are countless. Animations are smoother, the artstyle is arguably better to promote a more lasting effect, there's an overall bigger focus on lasting impact and player expression than the last game could ever manage, and the whole scale is just so much larger than the first one could ever manage.

The DLC is ok. 
Blade of Galadriel is terrible as far as story goes, but it's fun enough to be worthwhile on a heavy sale. 
The Gondorian DLC (can't be bothered to remember the name) is actually pretty fun with a unique take on the gameplay formula, but unfortunately ditches the Nemesis System that makes this game so fun in the first place.

Overall, a solid 9/10 game that has been carried extremely well by a system more games should be allowed to use.

[h1]An Epic Adventure Through Middle-earth in Shadow of War[/h1]

As a fan of both the Lord of the Rings franchise and action-packed games, "Middle-earth: Shadow of War" has exceeded my expectations with its immersive gameplay, vast world, and satisfyingly combat. Developed by Monolith Productions, this open-world action RPG offers a thrilling experience in the realm of Middle-earth.

Pros:[list]
[*]The game's combat mechanics are fluid and satisfying, allowing players to engage in visceral and gory battles against a wide variety of enemies, including the numerous and diverse boss types.

[*]The Nemesis System, a standout feature of the game, creates dynamic and memorable interactions with enemy captains, providing a unique and personalized gameplay experience.  Some of their taunts are priceless and it takes some time before a repeat.

[*]The open-world design, complete with iconic locations from the Lord of the Rings universe, offers a breathtaking and immersive world to explore, filled with quests, secrets, and engaging storylines.

[*]The game's character progression and skill tree system allow for customization and strategic decision-making, empowering players to shape their playstyle and abilities.

[*]The inclusion of iconic characters and references from the Lord of the Rings franchise adds an extra layer of immersion and excitement for fans of the series.
[/list]
Cons:[list]
[*]Some players may find the game's story and characters to be less engaging and impactful compared to the rich lore of the Lord of the Rings universe.
[/list]


In conclusion, "Middle-earth: Shadow of War" offers an epic and gory adventure through the beloved realm of Middle-earth. With its satisfying combat, dynamic Nemesis System, and expansive open-world, it provides hours of entertainment for fans of the Lord of the Rings franchise. The game's thrilling boss battles and immersive world make it a worthwhile journey for fans of action RPGs and Middle-earth lore. Prepare to unleash your wrath upon the enemies of Mordor in "Middle-earth: Shadow of War."

Note:  I bought this on sale with all the DLC for around $40 AUS, a total steal !

Second part of the series.

In this game you're a godlike creature from the start which felt weird at first, because you had all those abilities you knew from the first game. But after playing the first 2 hours this godlike feeling went away and I was the same Talion as I was in the first game.

We have to talk about the obvious part though: This game was meant to be filled with microtransactions. Large stretches now feel weird because the microtransactions aren't there anymore. And those part you were supposed to spend money on are now hollow and lifeless.

I'd like to see a third part which isn't filled with microtransactions and is the perfect mix between Part One and Two of the series, without the, you know, predatory business practices that are disgusting and are battled rightly so. 

In this form I can recommend this game very much.

Buying this was probably the best decision I made this month. 
Pros
1) Good performance and stable fps 
2) Lot of tools available to tackle the orcs you can use ranged,stealth,poison,beasts,combat, un dead orcs or mind-control other orcs.
3) The nemesis system gives a orc hierarcy you have to dismantle, and you can mind-control other orcs to essentially play politics used your pawns to assassinate, ambush, spy on other orcs to eventually reach the overlord.

Cons 
1) The game gets exponentially easier with each upgrade so in the beginning and the middles upgrades are more important than orcs so the focus shifts there but once you get them it gets boring.
2) After the story ends i.e after the end of shadow wars, there is not much to do except conquer forts you have already conquered and do repetitive nemesis missions which is boring . 
Bottom line: If you get this on sale buy it, its good fun with lots of content for the price.

This game has an incredibly beautiful expansive world, a more well thought out and intricate nemesis system, and lots more to explore and conquer than in the 1st game. All of which would make for an fantastic and thrilling sequel if not for the huge oversight that all of the interesting features are locked behind 16 hours of slow unexciting story missions. You are essential stuck in a hamster ball until several hours of painstaking missions where you are often told which buttons to press and when, hugely taking away from the open world feel. Perhaps if you can suffer that you'll find an true gem but it's predecessor, Shadow of Mordor, stands as a much better game.

Middle-earth™: Shadow of War™ takes players on an unforgettable journey through the iconic world of J.R.R. Tolkien's Middle-earth. With its immersive open-world, epic battles, and innovative Nemesis System, Shadow of War offers a captivating and thrilling experience for fans of action-adventure games.

One of the standout features of Shadow of War is its breathtaking open-world environment. Exploring the vast landscapes of Mordor and encountering iconic locations from the Lord of the Rings universe is a treat for both fans and newcomers alike. The attention to detail in recreating the world of Middle-earth is remarkable, immersing players in a rich and visually stunning setting.

The Nemesis System is the game's crowning achievement, revolutionizing the way players interact with enemies and creating dynamic and personal narratives. The system generates unique and memorable Orc enemies that remember previous encounters, develop strengths and weaknesses, and engage in fierce rivalries. Building relationships with these foes, manipulating their hierarchies, and orchestrating betrayals adds a layer of strategy and depth to the gameplay.

Shadow of War's combat is fast-paced, visceral, and highly satisfying. Players have a wide array of abilities and weapons at their disposal, allowing for creative and fluid combat encounters. Whether you prefer stealthy assassinations or full-frontal assaults, the combat mechanics provide a variety of playstyles to suit your preferences.

The epic battles against massive fortresses and the iconic Balrog provide exhilarating moments of scale and spectacle. Storming enemy strongholds, leading armies, and taking down towering enemies deliver an epic sense of accomplishment and make you feel like a true hero in Middle-earth.

The story of Shadow of War builds upon its predecessor, delving deeper into the lore of Middle-earth and introducing compelling new characters. The narrative is engaging, filled with twists and turns that keep you invested in the fate of the world. The voice acting and cinematic presentation further enhance the immersive experience.

Monolith Productions has shown great dedication in supporting the game post-launch, with updates and expansions that expand the gameplay and introduce new content. The community aspect is also strong, with online features that allow players to engage in multiplayer modes and compete for rewards.

Pros:

Immersive open-world set in the world of Middle-earth
Innovative and dynamic Nemesis System
Fast-paced and satisfying combat mechanics
Epic battles and monumental boss encounters
Engaging story and memorable characters
Post-launch support and active community
Cons:

Occasional technical issues and performance optimization
In conclusion, Middle-earth™: Shadow of War™ delivers an epic and immersive experience in the beloved world of Middle-earth. With its breathtaking open-world, innovative Nemesis System, and thrilling combat, the game offers a captivating journey filled with memorable moments and strategic depth. Whether you're a fan of the Lord of the Rings franchise or a newcomer to the series, Shadow of War is a must-play title that will transport you to a world of adventure and heroism. Prepare to embark on an unforgettable quest to save Middle-earth.
