This is the prequel to the Shadow of Mordor game and completes the story of Talion as you finally get a Ring of Power to enslave orc and do your bidding. The gameplay is solid with upgrades for each ability and this time you finally get to ride a drake which is a mini dragon. The conquering camps are replaced by conquering Castles which you put a siege on and take your army to fight against the defender and vice versa. You can put spies and minions as well which can help you take over them in a strategic manner. The game finally gives you to fight Balrog but the boss-battle would have been more epic if it was not just defeating him by giving him acupressure. I like how they changed Shelob to a goth lady from a spider and enriched the story with her. After you watch the first ending of the game, you bring Order to Mordor which is very tedious process of conquering and defending the castles over and over again until you finally get the true ending. The DLC is great as you play with minor characters which come in the main story but have their own weapon system and gadgets which make it fun.

TLDR: Just go play Shadow of Mordor
Long version; its the same game, sure the spells have to be unlocked all over again, the story is new and there are more zones.
Its a grindfest
And has a single save slot
Wanna replay the story?
Too bad, all your grinding (and money from when lootboxes was a thing) is gone now.
It feels like shadow of mordor Reforged edition.
Not its own new game.
There are more zones, at the cost of each zone feeling way more shallow. You spend less time in each zone and through that you dont have the same connection as you had with zones in the first game. Or with that zones Uruks.
And (spoiler?) the endgame is a goddamn grind that only grinds down your uruks into nothingness.
The online PVP and Uruk vs Uruk AI fights all feel like they have a 75% chance of killing your uruk permanently with a very low (if you manage to win 10 times in a row) reward.
Oh and people hack, cheat and overall abuse the online elements.
Speaking of the Uruks, they are basically the same as the first game.
Same classes (normal, spear(throwing), spear(shield), crossbows or dual wield).
They come in Slim, Fat and Muscly.
Sure, there are Ologs now.
A single whole new class.
Where are the spellcasters (they exist in game but only in cutscenes and then its a guy with an axe)? uruks using both bow and sword (like talion)? uruks with two-handed weapons with telegraphed attacks that you must dodge or risk being split in half ?
Theres not like there is a limit to what could have been done.
Sure, they have Tribes now.
And that means they have a single ability tied to that.
Sometimes an almost unique dresscode.
Ferals dressed in leather and animal bone, Terror dressed in uruk bone, Mystic dressed in human bone, Outlaw dressed in bone, Slaughter dressed in bone and leather, Machine, Warmonger and Dark dressed in red, silver and black metal respectively. Oh and Marauders, dressed in gold, silk and scavenged human armor.
That it, those are the tribes.
The DLC ones are two of the bone ones, if you cant see which ones it is, i dont blame you (dont buy it)
Tribes dont affect their loyalties, its not easier to have a Feral infiltrate a Feral fort than to have an Undead Cannibal on fire do it.
Might as well have given them one of five hats and given them a unique ability based on that as well.
I remember my nemesis from the first game fondly.
He has immune to bows, swords, flame, poison, got angry from being damaged, regained health while angry, hit in an AOE, hit extra hard,hit extra fast.
Looked like a beast with his black skin, black armor, gargantuan sword and was nicknamed "the executioner".
He would have died instantly from a stealth attack.
But wheres the fun in that.
So i imported him to this game (which you cant do any longer???)
And he became Zorg the blue, a bard in golden armor and a lute as his weapon.
Still immune to everything except stealth.
And in the mission they appear you are locked in an arena with never ending spawning enemies.
I couldnt stealth.
Still more memorable than the nazgul endgame fights.
The zones in the game change marginally based on which tribe controls it.
By marginally i mean, if the Machine tribe controls it, there are furnaces scattered around that explode if you shoot them. If the feral tribe controls the same zone, the furnaces are replaced by Caragor cages...
That explode into furballs when you shoot them.
Different object, same effect.
The Machine wont start massive woodworking operations in the forest region, removing the trees.
The Dark and Terror tribes wont have a positive relation with Shelobs Spiders in Cirith ungol.
The Outlaw wont annihilate all other tribes.
The Marauder wont bring in human slaves.
The Slaughter wont remove all animals.
The Feral wont tame Graugs (and use against you)
The Warmonger wont have more troops than everyone else.
Sure, the story is new.
But where are all the people from Nurn? The Outcasts? The people i spent a whole game to save?
Oh its a new city full of people to save?
Led by a girl?
Who has a parent who leads the people?
Let me guess, they are actually mind controled by some evil force.
And the girl gets in trouble.
And Talion has to spend a very long escort mission saving them.
Fantastic.
And do we have to follow gollum around for a bit?
Nice
Torvin shows up?
Perfect
Extra content where we play as Celebrimbor in the past?
Super
Single life extra campaign?

[h1]Top 10 Most Underrated Games of the Decade[/h1]

Maybe it's just me but I never really heard too much about this game when it first released and after playing it I have no idea how this game didn't garner the type of attention games like Skyrim, Witcher 3, Assassin's Creed, etc got.

Think [i]Assassin's Creed[/i] movement with a hint of [i]Witcher 3[/i] style combat. Then add in the ability to recruit/build an army and take part in sieges for castles. Also one of the best and most unique enemy systems (its called the [b]Nemesis system[/b], tough to explain but its awesome). Finally, add in an incredible story that feels like they really did keep Tolkien's vision/lore in mind (unlike certain Amazon shows).

I played this game years ago on Xbox and I just picked it up while it was on sale for $5. Possibly the single best deal of all time. The game still holds up 6 years after its release. Super fun gameplay that you can mess around in the open world but also such a compelling story. I had forgotten how the nemesis system creates unique dialogue and enemies depending on your decisions. I mean it really is tough to explain in detail but an example is I killed an orc at the start of the game and waaay later on he shows up to ambush me saying he survived and he's back to avenge his defeat at my hands. I mean how cool is that!? 

I definitely recommend giving this game a shot. It's still worth it at full price if you miss the sale. 

P.S. At the time of writing, it seems like there is still a healthy online player base so you can still take advantage of the online components like Pit Fights and Besieging other players' castles.

While the first game in the series was quite fun, this one is just enraging.
The movement system is arbitrary and unpredictable, doing things that you don't want it to do every single time you try to do something. Believe it or not, binding EVERY SINGLE MOVEMENT ABILITY to ONE KEY is not a good idea. The moment when I realized I had absolutely no desire to continue playing this game was when I was chasing after an orc, holding down the sprint key and rather than sprinting, the game decided that what I really wanted to do was start jumping up a nearby tower. The game tries to automate everything about moving, and in the process, takes away all of your agency. The story just flat out sucks as the characters do what the plot demands of them. They are simply puppets to the great writers in the sky; they have no say in what they decide to do. The decisions are weird and make no sense. The wraith and Talion fight over the same thing without any progression in the argument, simply stating the same benign statements over and over and over again. 
Moving across the terrain is tedious, and you run into 18 different captains moving 1000 meters. Defeat one of the captains? His brother just comes to waste your time. Kill him? He comes back from the freaking dead to come and annoy you once more. This is just one aspect where it wastes your time. Don't forget that every captain you encounter has a 30 second intro speech AND a death speech. These are unskipable, and I could feel my brain cells melting away as they just droned on and on and on and on and on. The combat system was repetitive, tedious, and dull, as you just parried when the little icon popped up and spammed left click until you could do something else. This could last for any amount of time. It was just annoying to deal with. Combine that with the weird texturing, lackluster graphics, and abysmal shading, it was not a pleasant gaming experience. 
The one good thing I can say about this game was the only thing they advertised: the nemesis system, and even that has major flaws, such as RAISING THE FREAKING DEAD.
This game is a masterclass in wasting your time and insulting your intelligence. I could beat it if I really wanted to, but honestly, I just don't care anymore.
I came into this expecting to enjoy it, trying to enjoy it, but it just doesn't care about you, or the IP. Warner Brothers found that they had built an entertaining game that people enjoyed, and decided to exploit that fact for a couple extra bucks. It's sickening.

This game, is frustrating in every way possible. It feels like a good game, for the first few minutes. Then you start to realize the whole game is just a quick time event. the controls suck and are always never in the right input direction, which may be more of a function of the constantly panning camera changing what direction is "forward" on the controller. You will find yourself wishing to move in a certain direction, but the camera has panned just enough to make you move entirely the wrong way. when you aren't being constantly bombarded by orc chieftain ambushes, or dead because of a misinput, the only "quests" in the game are "go here and press *pickup button*. its a mediocre game with flashy action and gore. but it is so bad that it is painful to play. I couldn't even tell you what the story is either because so little actually happens in the first few hours. it is just Talion running around getting ambushed by orc captains constantly.

Masterpiece.

I had a great first time playing this.

I first found out about this when my dad showed it on steam. He said there was a free demo. I downloaded the demo for this game at the very end of 2019, after the microtransactions were removed. When I started it up, I heard the main menu theme and I thought it was great. The soundtrack is amazing. I didn't even want to play the game yet because I wanted to listen to the music. As soon as I started the demo, I got a rundown of the story by the infamous Bruz the Chopper. He told me what Middle Earth Shadow of War is all about, and what happened in Shadow of Mordor. I never really saw a story like this; a ranger of the Black Gate who died and became possessed by an Elf spirit that helped create the Rings of Power. Neat!
After the cutscene, I jumped into the tutorial in Nurnen, and first dominated an orc commander named Bolg the War Bringer, part of the Warmonger tribe. It reminded me of Bolg from the Hobbit. I had a good feeling about this!

This is when things got really good. I made a new enemy: Grisha Ghul Hunter, he was a green colored feral marksman. Every time he saw me, he let out a screech, or howl, or some sort of scream some of the deranged captains make. Fun little character trait. He was my enemy I loved to hate. One day, I tried out a Power Struggle mission, which is basically when an Orc captain does something to increase their level, such as an animal hunt or fighting another captain. I didn't exactly win, he shot me a few times and I was downed. But it wasn't him that killed me. An orc grunt came up and hit me with his sword. Then he started going on about how his axe was thirsty for more blood despite the fact it was a sword. He was promoted to captain. Amug Blood Axe, a brown colored Slayer part of the Slaughter Tribe. This wasn't good...

I decided to go down to the docks and get my 2nd follower. I started another Power Struggle mission. When I finished, I didn't just make a new follower, I made a new friend! Zunn the Anvil, a tan colored Machine Slayer. I thought he was the best. The way he plowed through everyone! I wanted him in my army. After the mission, Bruz the Chopper came up behind me and told me that I needed a bodyguard. "Anyone who wants to carve their way across Mordor will need a guard or two! I mean, I don't. Obviously. If there was ever a time when I needed help on the battlefield, I gut me own throat! But you, you should have some extra muscle. No shame in it!" So I made Zunn my bodyguard. We decided to take a stroll at the burned area near the fort, murdering every orc grunt we see. I've found that a good way to improve your relationship with your followers is to do something like this. Take a stroll and get into fights. Sounds like something orcs would enjoy. Also, you can do power struggle missions that your followers are in to make them like you. The trailers weren’t wrong when they said you can forge friendships.

The time had come for me to get revenge on Amug. I tracked him down and found him in a camp. He said to me, "Look upon the glory of the Blood Axe! It spoke to me, says it wants to taste your flesh and feel your blood flow!” He was off his rocker. More so than other orcs were. I fought him and his army for a while. I got downed three times. I didn't have any more chances. Another random grunt came up and was about to kill me. Here we go again. As soon as he was about to swing, Zunn the Anvil came up and killed the grunt! Then he said, "Just doing my duty, boss." Ah, he was so professional. It was me and him vs. Amug Blood Axe. We were duking it out, but then another Orc captain ambushed me: Grom the Bone Collector, a purple colored Feral (or maybe Marauder?) beastmaster with a (goat?) horns helmet. Then it was a 2v2. Zunn vs Grom and Me vs Amug. Amug won. His level increased.

As soon as I respawned, I decided to send Zunn on a mission to kill Grisha Ghul Hunter while I went to defeat Grom. Grom was at an outpost. I sneak attacked him! We fought for a while until I dominate him and brought him to my side. "Join the army of the Bright Lord!" I should mention that you can't recruit every orc you find. They need to be the same level as you or lower. I sent him away and set a waypoint on my map to try and take care of Amug once again. As soon as I exited my map, Grom came back around and ambushed me! He didn't want to be part of my army! We fought again and I tried to dominate him, but it didn't work. He now had an Iron Will, claiming that Sauron guarded his mind. So I shamed him. Then he had a hand mark burned on his face I then set out to fight Amug again. I caught him having a bash in honor of my defeat. In short, we fought. I died. He became epic and a Warchief. Oh, bother...

I was doing more missions, raising my level. Then Zunn was captured! He failed to kill Grisha. I had to save my friend! He was tied to a pole. They branded the eye of Sauron on his forehead. Orc slaves also had that mark. I jumped down from above and started slashing away at the orcs. I cut him free and dominated the captain. After that, Bruz approached me again and said that I can send one of my followers to spy on a warchief... and then I got an idea. It was time for Bolg the War Bringer to come into play. I sent him to the fight pits to become a "bodyguard" of Amug Blood Axe. He won the fight and became a spy. This was a great opportunity for me to defeat him more easily. Before I began, I figured that follower orcs can die just as easily as enemy captains. I was afraid of losing Zunn on my quest for vengeance, so I decided to take another orc captain for now. I was ready. I was going to finally SLAUGHTER Amug Blood Axe.

It was nighttime. Warchief missions involve you doing a task to draw out a fortress' warchief, such as destroying their grog supply or killing their men. I had to go to a pit at the 2nd level of the fort, where the door of the keep was, to spring a trap. I jumped around from building to building, dominating any orc grunt I came across. I even jumped down and dominated an orc on the ground without anyone noticing. That was fun. I finally made my way to the pit and sprung Amug's trap. He appeared from the right side of the keep. I heard orcs chanting in the background, "Amug, Amug, Amug!" The Blood Axe was guarded by two other captains; Grom the Bone Collector, and Bolg the War Bringer... well... at least until Bolg yelled, "For the Bright lord!", and stabbed Amug in the back. I ran up to assist him and decided to fight Grom. We fought each other for a bit, and then I decided to summon my bodyguard. As soon as I pressed 2, I heard, "HEY!" I was being ambushed by his Identical Blood Brother! I tried to roll out of the way of the fight, and summoned him again. He showed up and BETRAYED me, probably because he wanted to help his blood brother. As soon as that happened, Amug killed Bolg the War Bringer! Oh boy... I decided to blow a big stack of grog and set everyone on fire while I tried to make my getaway. I should've known this earlier, but Grom the Bone Collector was MORTALLY FLAMMABLE. The fire from the explosion killed him quickly. One less captain to worry about. I climbed up one of the towers in the wall so I could recover. Amug followed me up. Here we were... here we would end this for good. We dueled on the tower and I beat him. He went down on his knees and said," Can I at least say goodbye to the Blood Axe? Goodbye, Blood Axe!" Then I finished him. I don't remember exactly how he was executed, but I did it, and ended our rivalry.

This game is overall very good. The combat is fluid and varied allowing you to play in multiple different ways, the areas are beautiful and the nemesis system is fantastically fun. Issues arise fairly early on however, after act 1, which introduces you to the basics of the nemesis system, you enter act 2, which is the full fledged nemesis system gets unlocked. Then you get flooded with the extra systems, online revenge missions, send your orcs to fight online, buy upgrades for your orcs, open loot boxes. The game has a grind to it as well, it feels daunting to get to a new area and get a start in it and killing orcs captains and war chiefs can become a chore. The game itself is great (mostly thanks to the combat) but it has too many systems in the game to prolong the games playtime. I would still recommend this game, especially when on sale. Also story wise, I don;t know much about LOTR but I've heard its not great for the cannon of the series, but story is interesting enough for me to keep playing the story missions. Story does have some "plot twists" that you'll see coming from the next town over.

Loved the first game. This just feels like they took the final act of the first game and just copy pasted it four or five times on different maps. Combat is either a joke and you can just button mash or sprint past the encounters or it's a string of bullshit that one shots you while being immune to 90% of your arsenal. Controls are sloppy and suffer from the "Only so many buttons on a controller" problem. The space bar alone is bound to about 17 different functions (each listed individually in the binding menu) but try to rebind a single function to a different key to make it easier to dodge instead of vaulting? Nope. You must rebind the whole block to the same key.

The "build an army" aspect just feels like it was designed to waste your time. Every new map you enter you have to build a new army and capture new forts. But assigned captains can and, orcs being orcs, will betray you leaving a large hole in your army that you have to go find another captain to plug it. It's like if during the Elite Four in Pokemon part of your team would just.. run the hell off and you'd have to scavenge a replacement in some grass somewhere.

Speaking of wasting time the orc intros.. uff da the orc intros. Every orc captain you encounter has an intro and in some cases you can encounter upwards of 4 in a single mission. Some of them are rather quick taking only 10 or so seconds but others? Damn orcs are monologuing entire novels at you. There's no way to skip them either so I sure hope you like hearing about how some orc became a living hive of maggots and how he's going to pass their "wriggling warmth" on to you.

I recently had the pleasure of playing Middle-earth™: Shadow of War™ on Steam, and I must say, it's an exceptional gaming experience that every Lord of the Rings fan should indulge in. Building upon its predecessor, Shadow of Mordor, this game takes the open-world action-adventure genre to new heights with its gripping story line, immersive game play mechanics, and breathtaking visuals.
One of the standout features of Shadow of War is its captivating narrative. Set in the expansive world of Middle-earth, the game puts you in the shoes of Talion, a ranger resurrected by a powerful Elven spirit. The story takes you on a thrilling journey as you forge alliances, battle hordes of orcs, and confront the formidable forces of Sauron. The writing is masterful, staying true to Tolkien's lore while offering an original and engrossing tale of its own.
The game play mechanics in Shadow of War are a sheer delight. The Nemesis System, which was introduced in Shadow of Mordor, has been expanded and improved upon, offering a dynamic and personalised experience. Each encounter with an orc captain or warlord feels unique, as they remember past encounters and evolve based on your interactions. The ability to recruit orcs to your cause, train them, and form your own army adds a layer of strategy to the game, making each conquest a tactical endeavour.
Combat in Shadow of War is fluid, brutal, and immensely satisfying. Talion's move set has been expanded, offering a wide array of acrobatic maneuvers, stealth take-downs, and devastating combos. The inclusion of powerful, wraith-like abilities further enhances the combat experience. Whether you prefer the finesse of stealth kills or the adrenaline of engaging in intense battles, the game caters to various play styles.
Visually, Shadow of War is a marvel. The attention to detail in the environments, character models, and animations is remarkable. Exploring the vast regions of Mordor and other iconic locations from Middle-earth feels immersive and visually stunning. The game's lighting effects and atmospheric soundtrack further enhance the overall ambience, making it feel like you're truly part of this epic world.
I also want to commend the developers for their continuous support and improvement of the game. They have listened to the community's feedback and made meaningful updates, including the removal of controversial micro transactions, to ensure a more balanced and enjoyable experience.
In conclusion, Middle-earth™: Shadow of War™ is an absolute must-play for fans of the Lord of the Rings franchise and anyone who appreciates a well-crafted open-world adventure. With its enthralling story line, engaging game play mechanics, and breathtaking visuals, it's an experience that will keep you hooked from start to finish. Prepare to embark on an epic journey through Middle-earth like never before.

So I missed this game at launch, but I heard about what happened. My understanding was that there was an eventual reversal on the micro-transactions, but the core problems still remain. What was fun in the previous game has been made tedious, boring, repetitive. It's ok for the first few hours, but gets old quickly.

One of the worst parts is the gear score creep. You keep getting new weapons that the game tells you are "better", but they're decidedly not. +1 or +2 to the number on your currently equipped gear literally doesn't make a difference to how quickly you kill orcs. The only thing that matters is the ability tied to the equipment.

To add to this, the story is pretty bland. Where they first game fitted into lore pretty well, I'm left wondering why Tallion is even still here, and why they're shoehorning more characters from the series into the game.

In short, this is a tedious grindfest with a limp story. What might have been an interesting game was ruined by greed to the point where the nemesis system couldn't save it, at least not for me.

Middle Earth: Shadow of War is an action-packed, open-world video game that takes place in the epic fantasy world of J.R.R. Tolkien's Middle-earth. Developed by Monolith Productions and published by Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment, the game is a sequel to 2014's Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor and was released in October 2017.

The game's story follows the adventures of Talion, a ranger of Gondor who has been possessed by the spirit of the elf lord Celebrimbor. Together, they seek to create a new Ring of Power to defeat the dark lord Sauron and his armies of orcs. Throughout the game, players must engage in battles with orcs, explore the vast open-world environments, and build an army of followers to help them conquer the enemy.

One of the standout features of Shadow of War is the Nemesis System, which is an advanced artificial intelligence system that creates unique enemies and allies for each player. This system allows players to build relationships with various characters and witness the consequences of their actions. The game also features an enhanced combat system that allows for more varied and dynamic combat sequences.

In terms of graphics and sound, Shadow of War does not disappoint. The game's environments are beautifully rendered, and the character animations are smooth and fluid. The soundtrack is also excellent, featuring a mix of original compositions and classic themes from the Lord of the Rings films.

However, the game is not without its flaws. Some players have criticized the game's inclusion of microtransactions, which allow players to purchase in-game currency with real money. Additionally, the game's story has been criticized for being too convoluted and for straying too far from Tolkien's original work.

Overall, Middle Earth: Shadow of War is an exciting and immersive game that will appeal to fans of the Lord of the Rings franchise and action-adventure games. Its advanced AI system and enhanced combat mechanics make for a unique and engaging experience, although its microtransactions and story may not be to everyone's liking.

the shadow games are interesting to talk about. for one, they're TERRIBLE Lord of the Rings games, but they are no doubt GREAT games. LotR fans will no doubt be a little disappointed in the story but thats such a small part of the experience, it doesn't matter.

You've played the Shadow games before--be it in the form of Mad Max, the Batman Arkham games, etc, as its combat system is Rocksteady's highly recognizable freeflow system put into the context of a Tolkien character. the brilliance of the shadow games is the consequences of its combat. where in other games, the consequences of combat are story advancement, XP, and fun, Shadow adds on to that a unique story-generation aspect. Orcs will remember being defeated by you as well how, they each have a dynamic personality that effects them in combat but can also evolve over multiple bouts with the player, adapting to their strategies, developing new strengths, etc.

Graphically, its in the middle: Shadow Of War looks fine, great at times, but fails to really sell you on the believability of its worlds. they're too big to memorize but not big enough to provide meaningful exploration. the result is a world that you just pass through and pay no attention to, despite the world and lore of Middle Earth being super cool and interesting.

Characters, like the story, are weak. Theres little reason to not just skip most cutscenes and get back to the game, but the voice acting is universally good.

for 5 bucks as it is now, the shadow games, War in particular are a no brainer, you'll no doubt get more than five dollars of enjoyment out of these games, regardless of your connection to the series of books and films, but 50 bucks as it is normally is a bit of an ask, especially for games as old as these.

A worthy sequel to the already great Shadow of Mordor. As with the first game, the storytelling is kind of terrible in terms of pacing and focus, but the gameplay is a ton of fun and the nemesis system is much expanded upon in all the right ways. I even liked the online elements! Definitely play this if you liked the first one.

I did my first play through on Gravewalker difficulty. It was really annoying to get hit by one attack and die. Especially with the DLC, Desolation of Mordor, where dying resets most of your progress. It was painful and enjoyable. Yes. good game.

Hm, there is also a ton of stuff you can do within the game. The nemesis system is actually incredible. Bully an orc enough and he might go crazy or become a necromancer. Not only that, but there are certain character builds you can do that change the way you might fight or bonuses you receive. Even after I beat the story, it was a lot of fun just playing around and besieging forts.

Six freaking years and this game still has game breaking bugs that cause it to just randomly lock up.  They really like to happen in the middle of important events too.

After experiencing several of these, I decided to start tracking them.  I suppose I'll update as I keep playing.

Locked up after:
Killing a captain as part of the main story
Fast travelling to a new area and clicking a mission on the map
Leaving the game running and walking away for an hour or so
Just finished the game got all achievements. Love the combat its basically Batman Game With sword and Rpg elements.

Repetitive, copy pasted areas and progression (basically capture the same fortress a few dozen times but with a different theme pack)
Terrible Batman Arkham style combat
button prompts for dodging often fail to read inputs or show at the correct time
Laughably boring, generic story and characters
Enemies at high levels are often immune to almost everything, so they can take over half an hour to beat in some cases

The online conquest component is almost fun. If not for the aforementioned awful combat, as well as there only being one format of siege, so each one plays out exactly the same. High level fortresses are also the exclusive domain of cheaters who hack in literally unbeatable orcs with custom traits

Also don't expect any interesting orcs. The cool ones are handmade and can't be captured. The rare occasion that a randomly generated orc that you want shows up the game detects it and goes out of its way to deny you. Five times I saw an orc I actually wanted, and each time the game suddenly threw an ambush or something similar that not only prevented me from getting them, but which also seemed perfectly calculated to kill them as quickly as possible before I could make a move.

Oh, and about 2/3rds of this game is just waiting for orcs to shut up. Every single time you meet a named orc he has a long intro (sometimes 2), which he just has to get out of the way (you cant skip them). And if you see an orc you like, they dont do anything once you bring them to your side, all they have is their intro after which they are entirely devoid of any kind of personality whatsoever.

To further illustrate how much time you will spend waiting for orcs to finish monologuing:
In online conquest, you get gold rating by finishing within 7 minutes. If the clock goes down by 4 minutes by the time you finish, you will have spent over 20 minutes of real time. This is because the clock pauses during orc monologues. For 4 minutes of gameplay you will have needed to sit through 16 minutes of orcs strutting about and boasting about how they'll kill you. And each and every one of these forgettable orcs will be dead by the end of it. This game is a massive waste of time.

The controls are stupid af on PC.  If you have a controller, go for it.  If you use mouse and keyboard, don't waste your time.

The game plays and handles much like the first game, with some massive improvements.

You can spend focus to run 3x faster for a short time, so you don't have to wait for that random rock or tree stump to appear on your travels. Just run 24/7 with little to no worry. The mounted combat feels a lot better since the caragors no longer prioritize climbing on every single wall that you pass. The biggest one being, that you run an entire fortress and decide how you want to take them down.

There are fight pits where you can watch orcs fight one another and it makes for an amazing drinking game on who's gonna win. If you happen to lose one of your beloved followers in the fight pit, simply dominate the captain that killed yours and keep it rolling!

The story and world feel a lot better designed, especially the perk tree since you have a lot more options on how you want to play. I didn't bother switching skills per captain and never had a problem taking them down throughout the game. You can cater everything to your direct playstyle. If you are into set bonuses, those are in the game too so you can min-max exactly how you want to execute your strategies.

Aside from that, it's similar to the first game and fixes a bunch of issues that it had in terms of balancing.

While I haven't finished this game, I'll still leave a review based on the time I spent on Shadow of Mordor and the time I've spent on this game. I'd hoped that this game was a somewhat improvement on Shadow of Mordor, but at best it's simply the same game with some added features. The game is very janky, especially the movement and targeting. Over time you get extremely frustrated by how Talion either skips across wast distances, or simply flops down on the ground directly below you even though there's something to jump at within reasonable distance. At the same time you get annoyed by how executions, drain/interrogation or grab targets enemies. The nemesis system is a great idea, but seems terribly executed if you ask me. Not to mention you get extremely tired by listening to the same cutscenes of captains introducing themselves, or your nemesis ambushing you at the worst times. The game loves to make you spend lots of time in non-skippable monologues about how these captains are going to kill/betray/take revenge upon you. How hard would it have been to add a option to skip previously seen/heard monologues? The developers seem to have intentionally made the choices that are annoying to the player. The game isn't really that hard, but you're likely going to die or get knocked down several times by bullshit that is out of your control. The difficulties are extremely superficial, simply giving enemies more health, making them more aggressive or giving captains more resistances to your attacks. It simply emphasises the problem of the game being repetetive.

I thought that the GTA games had poor sprint mechanics, but this game has a worse sprint. Not to mention that it does not feel like the sprint affects much in terms of speed, unless you're sneaking and even then it's still slow. The sprint boost you can get when vaulting/landing gives a significant boost, but you get bored by having to press a button to activate it. What I wouldn't give to have a skill upgrade that simply auto-activated it for me, whenever it was relevant.

The online mechanics that have been added to this game (which wasn't in Shadow of Mordor) are a fun feature the first few times you try any of them out, but become extremely repetetive over time. Now I'm playing this almost 6 years after launch, but some of the online conquests I've tried have been extremely unbalanced, to the point that the captains in their fortress is 30-40 levels above my level. Which means that I get almost one-shotted by their captains, while mine are severely underpowered in comparison.

If you've never played Shadow of Mordor, then this game might be a slightly more interesting version of that game. If you've played Shadow of Mordor and were extremely tired by it at the end of that game, then you're likely going to be feeling the same things I've written above within a short while of playing this. It is definitely not worth the full price, but at a sale and without any better games to play it can be an OK time sink. The gameloop is quite repetetive, but if that's your cup of tea, then go ahead, I won't judge you. I'd rather recommend getting one of the earlier Assasins Creed games or even MGSV The Phantom Pain. The game simply feels like an unpolished version of those games set in the LOTR universe. If it wasn't set in the LOTR universe it would probably not even be a somewhat notable game.
This game is really good. Very well-made and so fun. Back when developers cared about getting a good game out.
This and Shadow of Mordor are both worthy of the Lord of the Rings franchise.  You will not regret buying this game and all DLCs.

Bought for $12.74 AUD. Played on a PC with an Intel i7 10700K, an RTX 3080 10GB GPU, 32GB RAM and NVME PCIE SSDs. Performance was great, after I realised that the dynamic resolution setting was making the game look like mud. After that, everything on Ultra and it ran smooth as. No noticeable dips in framerate. Graphically, it's showing its age a bit, but that's never my main reason for playing a game anyway. 

I had a bit of a love/hate relationship with this game. I'll go over the good, then the bad, and my final take on it.

The combat was very enjoyable and cathartic. Talion's abilities and skills were all very enjoyable. I'm always the stealth guy if I can help it, and indeed for most of the game that was my play style, though the times that I couldn't stealth, I still had plenty of other skills to use when swords had to clash. Having Celebrimbor along for the ride also gave you a ton of very flashy and powerful moves that were just a delight to use. 

I was very interested in all the lore hidden behind collectables. The LOTR world we all know was very much alive in this game. I'm no die-hard fan of LOTR, but from what I know of the series, it felt 'right'.

The story was good for the most part, if not predictable. What became of our Talion left a bit of a disappointed feeling in me, however.

Now, the whole fort/captain system in this game HAS some enjoyable elements to it. It takes a lot of work to convert a whole army of captains to take a fort, and then defend it. But once you've converted the entire map to your side, it feels good. But the frustration comes from the nemesis system, in particular when you get paired off fighting an orc that isn't only immune to fire, poison, arrows, executions and stealth, but also who regains full health after you somehow manage to get him to low health. Who also has a no last chance perk. Who dodges all of your attacks, or blocks them with a shield. In the middle of a seige, surrounded by other captains and grunts all trying to kill you. Individually, these immunities are easily worked around. Even with a few of these immunities, you still have enough of an arsenal to defeat your foe. But sometimes it really just feels like it was too punishing, and I was only playing on normal difficulty. It's particularly bad when you lose a fort because of one such enemy, and hours of your play time goes up in smoke. I shudder to think what the harder difficulties were like. So having taken forts, then having lost those forts, then taking them again...it all became rather repetitive, dull and frustrating. I really didn't enjoy the system by the end of the game, and after I had completed the final fort defense, I was so glad to be done with it. 

The DLC that focused on Eltariel was pretty average. It didn't really add anything meaningful to the game, and more often than not, I came across enemies that were immune to light; the core of Eltariel's move set. Again, the nemesis system felt over-tuned.

The DLC that focused on the other fellow....his name escapes me right now. But this DLC was far more interesting. Different moves, fighting styles and abilities, not to mention new gadgets and an interesting spin on the captain system all made for a much more enjoyable couple of hours.

So, looking back and summing up, there was enjoyment to be had, but my experience was ultimately soured by a disappointing story outcome and an overly punishing nemesis system. My recommendation is, if you're a fan of LOTR, give it a go, but maybe try it on easy.

Middle Earth: Shadow of War is an epic journey through Tolkien's rich universe that immerses players in a sprawling, action-packed adventure. With improved mechanics and features that build upon its predecessor, Shadow of War delivers a fantastic experience that is both rewarding and enjoyable.

One of the most significant improvements in Shadow of War is the Nemesis System. This feature allows players to create and develop their army of followers, each with their unique strengths and weaknesses. The Nemesis System also introduces new enemies, including Orc Captains, who will remember and react to the player's actions throughout the game. This system adds an extra layer of depth and strategy to the gameplay, making every decision and action feel significant.

The combat in Shadow of War is also exceptional, with a wide variety of weapons, skills, and abilities to choose from. The game offers a range of different playstyles, from stealthy assassinations to all-out brawls. The ability to customize your gear and skill tree further enhances the gameplay experience, providing a sense of personalization that allows players to tailor their playstyle to their preferences.

The open-world of Middle Earth in Shadow of War is stunning, with breathtaking vistas, intricate dungeons, and a variety of landscapes to explore. The game's fast travel system and mount mechanics make it easy to traverse the world, making each area feel connected and part of a cohesive whole.

One of the standout features of Shadow of War is its storytelling. The game's narrative is engaging, with memorable characters and a rich lore that draws players in. The story is also expertly woven into the gameplay, with many quests and missions advancing the plot and revealing more about the world and its inhabitants.

Overall, Middle Earth: Shadow of War is a fantastic addition to the franchise and a must-play for any fan of action RPGs or Tolkien's universe. With improved mechanics and features, the Nemesis System, immersive combat, breathtaking landscapes, and an engaging narrative, Shadow of War delivers an exceptional gaming experience that is sure to keep players hooked for hours on end.

Middle-earth™: Shadow of War™ is an amazing game that has captured the hearts of many players around the world. It is an action-packed adventure game that takes you on a journey through the epic world of Middle-earth, filled with unique characters, fearsome enemies, and incredible battle scenes.

One of the most remarkable things about Middle-earth™: Shadow of War™ is its stunning graphics - the visuals are breathtaking and the attention to detail is simply incredible. The game truly makes you feel like you are part of the fantasy world, with its vast landscapes, towering fortresses, and intricate character designs.

The gameplay is also outstanding, offering a seamless blend of stealth, combat, and strategy elements. You play as Talion, a ranger who is bonded with a wraith called Celebrimbor, and together you embark on a quest to forge a new Ring of Power and defeat the dark lord Sauron once and for all. Along the way, you will recruit and train your own army of orcs, trolls, and other creatures, using them to fight against your enemies and conquer their fortresses.

One of the most impressive features of Middle-earth™: Shadow of War™ is the Nemesis System, which allows each in-game enemy to have its own unique personality, strengths, and weaknesses. This means that every battle is different, and you will need to use careful tactics and strategic planning to overcome your foes.

Overall, Middle-earth™: Shadow of War™ is a fantastic game that offers a truly immersive and exciting experience. It is an absolute must-play for anyone who enjoys action-adventure games, RPGs, or any type of fantasy world games.  So, if you’re looking for a thrilling adventure full of epic battles and unforgettable moments, then Middle-earth™: Shadow of War™ is definitely the game for you!

If you are familiar with American Outsider Art, you may have come across Henry Darger. Darger spent the majority of his life writing and illustrating In the Realms of the Unreal, over 15 thousand pages of literature describing a massive conflagration between two diametrically opposed forces. Good is entirely good, evil is purely wicked - there is no ambiguity. The epic details chapters of this all-encompassing struggle with breathtaking heroism and unspeakable savagery, which only really ended because the author was dying of old age.

That is the reference that comes to mind most when playing Shadow of War. You are Talion, a ranger who, by all biological metrics, is very dead, but has bonded with elf wraith Celebrimbor to fight Sauron in the big baddie's quest to corrupt all of Middle-earth. The means to do this is a ring macguffin that will convert orcs fighting under Sauron's flag to yours. Yadda yadda.

You stealth and hack-and-slash through rather open strongholds leading to a fortress controlled by a hierarchy of orcs - outlined in this game's signature (and, like... patented??) Nemesis system. You can slay captains or convert them to your side. Each captain is named and titled, giving you a shortform biography of what ugliness they got up to before you got there. It may not be super deep, but it is effective in producing what feels like a land with history and activity - there are things going on without you. They also "remember" their last encounters with you - if you fled, if they retreated, if you failed to kill them. And by your undead nature, I feel the game wants you to treat your own death as part of an ongoing narrative. Orcs level up when they kill you. There exists a story where a lowly grunt takes on a name and title after clubbing your skull in, then moves up the orc corporate ladder.

You are given/can unlock many tools in stealth and combat and there are many possible ways to encounter orcs. These orcs are, like, busy. There are encounters - duels, camp raids, caragor hunts - that you can ambush, and those not involved wander in zones around the map. Only a select number of orcs - the Overlord, the Warchiefs, the Outpost Leaders - are really siloed, hiding behind walls of gameplay significance.

Depending on your view, the process of picking off orcs with sword, bow, or dagger, converting some to your side, leveling them by sending them on missions (or buying levels outright like the industrialist you are), and leading your army to a big setpiece confrontation with the Overlord might be very repetitive. A Strong Story this game... really does not have. It's big bad Sauron, all hope being lost, and timely intervention to rescue mankind from desolation. However, the game can also be a platform for your own story and experimentation.

I can understand why someone might play this game for hundreds of hours, and it's based on these horrible, ugly, petty orcs. Every orc presents the chance for a mini-epic to play out over hours. I was killed by an orc, he leveled up, I challenged him again, he taunted me for my lack of skill, he killed me again, he became a Warchief, I challenged him again, and he gave me one last insult for how long this took before I cleaved his head off. Thus ends the saga of Dush the Uncatchable. And that's one saga in a potentially never-ending story between you and these orcs, separate from the game lore entirely. Add in loot mechanics and instanced online play and you get a great bad case of the 'to-do's' - always something to collect, always something to level, always something to grind, always something to challenge.

Thus, I return to Darger. I won't claim to understand what in someone's imagination could continue to inspire until the longest manuscript in the English language was produced, but the feelings of it are in this game for me. Conflict never ends, there is always something bigger and nastier around the corner, always some insurmountable foe to... surmount. But I am a person who derives hours of entertainment checking the pockets and corners of games like Bioshock, Fallout 3, and Prey for my own personal narrative content outside of the Big Story. What that impulse is for environment in those games, it's more for character in Shadow of War. And that may not be appealing to some at all. But, I've got a sick orc named Ukbuk the Scorpion and I'm going to make him Overlord.

Middle-earth™: Shadow of War™ is an incredibly fun and immersive game that I thoroughly enjoyed playing on Steam. The game transports you to the world of J.R.R. Tolkien's Middle-earth, where you play as Talion, a Ranger of Gondor who is possessed by the spirit of Celebrimbor, the Elf Lord who forged the Rings of Power.

One of the standout features of this game is the Nemesis System, which creates a dynamic and unpredictable environment where your actions have consequences. This system allows for unique and memorable encounters with the game's various orc enemies, who have their own distinct personalities, strengths, and weaknesses. The orcs remember your previous battles with them, and can even rise through the ranks to become powerful captains and warlords who will challenge you in epic battles.

The combat in Middle-earth™: Shadow of War™ is also fantastic, with a variety of different moves, abilities, and weapons to use against your enemies. The game's open-world design also allows for plenty of exploration and side missions, which adds to the overall experience and makes the game feel even more expansive.

Overall, Middle-earth™: Shadow of War™ is a must-play for fans of the Tolkien universe and action RPGs. The Nemesis System is a game-changer, providing endless hours of gameplay and making each playthrough feel unique. The game's combat is satisfying and the world is rich with lore and detail. I highly recommend giving it a try.

The world is like a painting, the details in the scenery and the atmosphere give the feeling of a living dead world which I love. This also shows a lot in the orcs you find and gear. The detail on the armor and swords really shows from the menu to when you impale an uruk's head with it.

The story continues where the last game left off. To fight Sauron's forces, Celebrimbor and Talion forge a New Ring, powerful and uncorrupted by Sauron. Unfortunately, Celebrimbor becomes prisoner of Shelob, the giant spider who's impressively hot. She offers Talion a choice. Give her the ring and get Celebrimbor back, or let fate finally slit his throat and die. He chooses to save the wraith, and now the ring is with Shelob. Then the first act begins and I have to say it doesn't disappoint. We eventually go to Minas Tirith to find the Palantir, finally seeing human faces in this desolate world and the direction the game takes from there is pretty good. I'm not gonna tell much, but believe me, the story is good. I love how they introduced Shelob in a natural way, she works great in the story of the game, kinda like a Chaotic Neutral character, she also plays a very important role in the game as she gives Talion visions of the future and because they actually made a giant spider the most attractive figure in the game. That's impressive. The characters are well-made and they make the experience all so much better, specially late-game Talion. He is one hell of a badass.

Gameplay has hugely improved from the last game. They made travelling and moving way easier with double jumping, fast climbing, combat is now way more fun and polished, and with the new gear system you can make some pretty cool sets that allow for crazy playstyles. The upgrade system has been completely reworked with new skill trees and more focus on sets of skills rather than just being strong as hell. Now you can buy a lot of different skills, which can contain 2-3 upgrades you can buy, but can only use one upgrade at a time. This is interesting because you can choose what playstyle you want and adapt more to the enemies and interact better with the Nemesis system, specially during the later parts of the game. Oh, did I mention you can ride a dragon?

But the real deal is in the Nemesis system. Back in Shadow of Mordor, all you could do was dominate some orcs, control their positions and make them fight. But here, there is a whole new depth to it. First of all, every orc is its own character. They all have unique things about them that make them stand out, instead of being just regular goons that you can either control or kill. They all have specific strenghts, attributes and weaknesses that you can explore. You can exploit their fears to take them down more easily, or focus on their strengths when they become your ally to make them stronger. And that's the beauty of the Nemesis system, the fact that it creates narratives outside of the main campaign. There's a guy on YT that made a video talking about it more extensively, but the Nemesis system creates stories. It gives you narratives outside of the main campaign, and since orcs are always being made, you will never run out of characters to give you fun and varied experiences. You can have a slave orc kill you so he becomes a respected unit in their region, dominate him, and with proper training, turn him into a Legendary Overlord that can firmly protect your fort. You could find an orc that just refuses to die, so everytime you meet he just becomes stronger and crazier than the last time. You can have one of your own Orcs betray you because you accidentaly killed his blood brother and have a whole turn of events during a mission because he chose to ambush you when you least expected. There is always a new orc to see, a fresh story to live, and new experiences to be had. It's honestly mesmerizing.

The DLCs are great, and I really wanna talk about them but I'm gonna do that in the DLC's steam page, so if you wanna know about Blade of Galadriel and Desolation of Mordor, go there.

I really love Shadow of War, if you're looking for an engaging open world experience with great combat, beautiful visuals and fun, fresh experiences with your enemies, you're looking at the perfect game.

In the land of Middle-Earth, a new hero has risen to take up the mantle of the ranger Talion. Middle-Earth: Shadow of War is a breathtaking journey that will have you fighting for the fate of all living beings.

From the moment you step into this world, you'll be transported to a place of awe-inspiring beauty and darkness. The game's graphics are truly stunning, with landscapes that are both vast and detailed, and a sense of atmosphere that is palpable. Every detail, from the way the light filters through the trees to the sound of the wind as it whips through the ruins, is crafted with care and attention to detail.

But Shadow of War is not just a feast for the eyes. The game's combat system is a thing of beauty, allowing you to unleash devastating attacks, dodge enemy strikes, and engage in epic battles against foes both great and small. You'll need to master a range of weapons, skills, and abilities to take on the game's many challenges, from brutal orc warlords to massive trolls and other supernatural creatures.

What truly sets Shadow of War apart, however, is its emphasis on strategy and conquest. You'll need to build your own army, recruit powerful allies, and take on the forces of darkness in a battle for supremacy. The game's Nemesis System, which allows you to interact with and influence the behavior of enemy characters, is one of the most innovative and thrilling features in any game to date.

As you journey deeper into the heart of Middle-Earth, you'll be accompanied by a cast of memorable characters, each with their own unique personalities and motivations. Whether you're forging alliances, exploring ruins, or taking on massive fortresses, there's never a dull moment in this epic adventure.

In conclusion, Middle-Earth: Shadow of War is a game that deserves a place among the greats. It's a triumph of storytelling, world-building, and gameplay, and a worthy successor to the legendary Lord of the Rings franchise. So don your armor, sharpen your blades, and embark on a journey that will take you to the very edge of the known world - for Middle-Earth awaits!

Arrow Proof Savage Overlord who could heal himself, with infinitely spawning defenders, savages and ologs in his throne room, who adapted to executions and acrobatics.
Couldn't shoot or pin him to get damage in or even interrupt his healing. Waves of adds wouldn't let get damage in on the rare occasions my weapon would light him on fire. I was grinding him down with executions and getting used to the timing on the adds that would sprint in, but then he adapted to executions. He didn't have anything he was afraid of, at all. My summoned minions wouldn't appear in the throne room. And he'd kneel down to heal every 30 seconds. And even if I interrupted him almost immediately, he'd still get about as much health back as I was dealing to him. I was even getting good at timing my efl-shot refills to take out adds and heal between his heals. But I just COULDN'T F_____ING DAMAGE HIM! And after half an hour of fighting him and him healing, I made enough mistakes that he killed me and the fortress invasion failed.
And that was after I had assassinated all of his fortress commanders over a four hour period. F___ this game. Maybe there’s some obscure mechanic I could have taken advantage of to consistently damage him. But I was down to perfect counters, getting a single attack in after rolling away from his uncounterable attacks, and trying to get off brutalizations without getting interrupted on the rare occasion I dazed him.
And you know what, that would have been enough if HE DIDN’T HEAL HIMSELF EVERY 30 SECONDS. HELL I COULD HAVE DEALT WITH THAT IF THE GAME WOULD LET ME SOLO HIM, BUT NO, A GROUP OF SEVEN MASOCHISTIC SHIT-WHITS KEPT DEMANDING HEADSHOTS EVERY 15 SECONDS.
I get that I’m fighting an entire army, but even armies have limits. Let me kill ALL THE ORCS. I promise you I can! After taking out 50-100 in the same area, JUST STOP SPAWNING THEM! They’re not a challenge, it’s no longer immersive, they’re just an annoyance that keeps my from soloing bosses. And I should be able to earn that solo if I kill enough of them. So, put spawn caps on areas that refresh when the area gets reloaded. Allow me to completely genocide a camp of orcs. That would feel so good! But no, they have to spawn infinitely. 
Also, I like the nemesis system, I really do, but does the game really need to completely stop and let every, single captain get in a 20 second monologue before I can shoot them in the forehead with an arrow? Is Tallion really that polite? I wouldn’t be if orcs killed my family! I’d be fine with it, but he also has to let them have last words before he cuts their heads off. Even that would be tolerable, but when I set up a warchief to be betrayed by his henchmen which I’ve converted, and then stop to let him shit-talk be, and then have to wait for the betrayal animation to play out, and then get ambushed myself, F___ING TWICE, by legenday orcs whom I’ve already killed -- one of them twice already in the same playthrough -- and I STILL F___ING HAVE TO LISTEN TO EACH OF THEM INTRODUCE THEMSELVES BEFORE I CAN KILL THE HALF-DEAD BASTARD JUST TO THE LEFT… That’s a bit much. That was 7 unskippable cutscenes in the middle of the same fight. (two for each captain I killed, and yes, I’m counting the betrayal animation).
I won that, by the way. Handily. I’m good at this game, when it doesn't MAKE ORCS IMMUNE TO F___ING EVERYTHING!
I wanted to like this game. I really did. But all if gave me to attach to was the combat and the nemesis system. The story is dogwater. Shelob arbitrarily being a hot woman is nonsense (should have been an eldritch horror, Tolkine hated him some spiders, but no, dev want boobies). The actual boss fights are boring or stupid (I also have issues with the ring wraith mechanics, but I’m not going to go there…) The core of the nemesis system is great, but we desperately need to be able to skip the captain introductions (At least give us a perk we can unlock that lets us Renegade Interrupt them mid monologue.), and certain combinations of abilities and resistances on the orcs are bullshit. At the very least, they healing mechanic needs a limit. Like, they can only do it 2-3 times in a single fight. If that was the only change that was made to this game, I wouldn’t be writing a thesis dunking on it. But that fight was a step too far for me. Instant uninstall.
And I never even interacted with the pseudo-multiplayer take over actual player’s fortresses shit. Maybe it’s good! Maybe it’s shit! Dunno! I just wanted to finish the campaign before I looked into it. Or any of the DLC. But now I’m not gonna. Because when I get this pissed off, I get stubborn, and I’m never reinstalling this game again. I’m going to try very hard to never think about it again.

Most everything about this game is mediocre:

- Graphics are poor even on ultra.
- Contains probably the most frustrating, confusing, ugly UI I have used with random unexplained gauges littered everywhere on the screen, and menus containing an overwhelming amount of random buttons and text in spots where you would not expect buttons and text to be in. Menus within menus within menus is also a common occurrence.
- Horrible ubisoft-style semi open world design where you have countless symbols and markers littered on your map.
- Poorly balanced as the game expects you to grind XP to actually have a fighting chance against any of the captains/war chiefs. I heard online its best to just not interact with the Nemesis system in the early game and to instead grind through the uninspired story missions to get the XP you need to actually have fun with the system THAT THE GAME IS BUILT AROUND. 
- Speaking of the story, the only character that actually put effort in acting and making you feel for them is Bruz. This team managed to make the rest of the characters you are forced to interact with entirely boring and uninspired.

Yet I still put over 30 hours into the game. The nemesis system is such a unique mechanic that can't be found in any other game, as the publisher patented it. Makes it worth trudging through all the negatives I listed above just to experience it.

Overall, I would say this game does not hold up in 2023 but if you want something unique, this game has it.

Middle Earth: Shadow of War is a thrilling action-adventure game that was released in 2017. Developed by Monolith Productions and published by Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment, the game is a sequel to the critically acclaimed Middle Earth: Shadow of Mordor. Set in the Lord of the Rings universe, Shadow of War immerses players in a world of magic, adventure, and epic battles. In this review, I will explore the various aspects of the game and discuss why it is a must-play for fans of the genre.

Gameplay:
The gameplay in Shadow of War is exceptional, offering players a diverse set of mechanics and features that keep them engaged for hours on end. The game's combat system is fast-paced and satisfying, with a range of moves and abilities that players can unlock as they progress through the game. The game also features a robust customization system, allowing players to craft unique playstyles that suit their preferences.

One of the most impressive features of Shadow of War is the Nemesis System, a groundbreaking mechanic that was first introduced in Shadow of Mordor. The Nemesis System allows players to build relationships with enemy NPCs and shape the game's narrative based on their actions. The system is deep and complex, giving players a sense of agency and control over the game's world that is rarely seen in other games.

Story:
The story of Shadow of War takes place after the events of Shadow of Mordor and follows the protagonist Talion as he seeks to forge a new Ring of Power to defeat the evil forces of Sauron. The game's narrative is well-crafted, with a strong focus on character development and world-building. The game's story is also filled with twists and turns that keep players on their toes, making it an engaging and immersive experience from start to finish.

Graphics and Sound:
Shadow of War's graphics are stunning, with detailed character models and environments that bring the game's world to life. The game's art style is faithful to the Lord of the Rings universe, with a sense of realism that is both gritty and beautiful. The game's sound design is also excellent, with a haunting soundtrack and voice acting that is top-notch.

Conclusion:
Middle Earth: Shadow of War is a fantastic game that is both immersive and engaging. The game's gameplay is exceptional, with a deep combat system and a groundbreaking Nemesis System that sets it apart from other games in the genre. The story is well-crafted, with strong character development and world-building that keeps players invested in the game's world. The graphics and sound design are also excellent, making the game a feast for the senses. Overall, Middle Earth: Shadow of War is a must-play for fans of the genre and a standout title in the Lord of the Rings universe.

Однообразная дрочильня в духе assassin's creed.

[h1] Миссии[/h1]
Миссии у каждого квестодателя практически не отличаются.
Например, у одних освободи гондорцев убивая орков, а у других прерывай ритуал убивая орков.


[h1] Орки[/h1]
Болтовню орков, заставку перед осадой и т п вещи нельзя пропустить, а это спустя какое-то время начинает знатно бесить, так как отнимает время.
Например, врываешься в битву и приходят 3 капитана и каждый КАЖДЫЙ представляется по секунд 10... 

[h1] Сюжет[/h1]
Сюжет с небя звезд не берет и его ну очень мало. 
Так же, как и мало какой-либо интересной постановки.
90% заставок - это болтовня.

Молучу еще, что истиная концовка получается только в том случае, если задрочить всю карту.

[hr][/hr]

Я согласен, что какое-то удовольствие я получал первые несколько часов, но далее по прошествии часов 5 игра не дает какие-то новые интересные механики, которые делают игру веселее, а так же не балует красивыми "мультиками".

Изменения по сравнению с первой частью около 0-ые и разработчики зачем-то увеличили унылые локации в несколько раз.

Shadow of War is a continuation of the story from Shadow of Mordor, with tons of content and things to do to keep you busy. Honestly, this game is a complete upgrade from its predecessor, with a very big emphasis on the Nemesis system.

Let me just be straight: If you're looking at this game for a good story, maybe give the game a  pass. The story is [i]okay[/i] at best. Its not necessarily annoying or hard, its just very linear and predictable. The actual meat and bones of this game is the gameplay and the Nemesis system. Every action you make influences your enemies, and over time they will get used to your playstyle, causing you as a player to adapt to every scenario and find solutions to every encounter. 

Somebody pointed out in another review that you should increase the difficulty. I honestly have to agree here. The nemesis system REALLY shines on higher difficulties, and unlike most games, dying isn't really a setback here. If anything, its a part of the gameplay and it ends in some pretty fun interactions, like getting killed by a grunt that you then kill literally a million times afterwards because they won't stay dead. It still boggles me how many different personalities there are for enemies in this game, and how many unique lines of dialogue there is for each one. Every time I do a new playthrough, its almost completely different from my previous ones. 

For an example, my first playthrough of this game I was quite bad and kept dying to one particular captain over and over. This captain basically became my eternal nemesis; he followed me wherever I went, from one region to the next (yes, they can do that!) and was constantly a thorn in my side. Eventually, I ended up defeating him and dominating him to add him to my own army. I ended up using him in a siege on a fortress, and during that siege, he ended up betraying me and killing me AGAIN. After that, I had a vendetta versus this dude and fought him again, this time killing him. But guess what? HE SURVIVED AND KILLED ME AGAIN. This basically continued for the rest of that playthrough, and although at times it was frustrating, I don't think I've ever been this immersed in a game before. Even though it was frustrating, that need for revenge kept driving me forward and trying to confront this guy. Over and over. It got to a point where him intruding on things was almost expected, and I enjoyed every second of attempting to confront my eternal nemesis. I even began to enjoy his eccentric personality and weird quips he made after each unique encounter.

The TL;DR is if you want a game that forces you to think outside the box and has you constantly adapting, then this is your game. You'll enjoy every moment of it. 

Also as a slight recommendation, I do recommend using a controller. Keyboard and Mouse works perfectly well, but it can feel a bit clunky later in the game.

Let me start by saying that I liked Shadow of Mordor and I even finished it on 100% achievement. So what can I say about Shadow of War? It got bigger, but more annoying.

There are more locations and more quests. However, it is depressing that there is a large number of collectable items that we can collect. Yes, you can not do this, but why do those who created this game have put them in such large numbers? From 9-11 per location. Why do I need to know that some vase is an ancient artifact?

So what didn't I like and what did I like about it?

+: 

- The combat became more varied.

- The system of blood enemies became better (there are more events on the kill missions)

- There is an opportunity to become a fortress owner on which we will place our orcs

- The presence of charismatic orcs such as Gruz and Krysarius (for me this is a plus, because their lines diluted the humdrum)

-:

- The narration is spontaneous. First we take a task from one character, then another, because the previous one is unavailable.

- There are too many locations. Yes, I understand that it will stretch the gameplay and we learn more story about the world of Middle-earth, but it's pure routine, because without a high level in the locations after Nurn you are nobody.

- The game is too demanding for the level of the player. Why do we have to do a bunch of one-type quests to recruit orcs? We are a light lord with a ring of power.

Overall, to buy the game or not to buy?  I didn't like this game, but if you're still interested in it, you can buy it on sale

The concept of this game is truly remarkable and incredibly enjoyable to play. The ability to build and lead your own army of orcs, each with their own unique personalities and characteristics, adds an extra layer of excitement to the gameplay. The combat system is well-designed and the animations are nice, making your character look powerful and agile as they engage in battle.

Additionally, the armor customization options provide a wide range of choices, allowing players to create a personalized look for their character. The weapon customization vary in amount for each weapon but overall great. The skill system is great, offering an array of abilities to upgrade and customize your orc army. However, some skills may feel underwhelming taking away from the overall experience.

Unfortunately, the game does have some technical issues, such as bugs with climbing and enemies that randomly appear, which can be a bit frustrating at times. Despite these minor setbacks, the overall experience of playing this game is highly enjoyable and well worth the time investment.

Despite the problems with monetization upon the games launch, and the rough launch week it had. The current version of the game is a very good experience. Heavily recommend for anyone who loves action adventure games.

8/10 from me.

[h1] Plot [/h1]
The plot continues from where the last game left off. Talion just crafted the "new ring" to combat Sauron, as thus he, Celebrimbor, Shelob, and a myriad of other characters go on your quest to conquer Middle-Earth from Sauron.

[h1] Game Aspects [/h1]
Game introduces several new systems in the main game alone. With the new ring Talion can "dominate" normal orcs, and high ranking captain orcs to have them serve him and assist him in his conquest of the several different regions. You can also train, upgrade, level up, and have your orcs engage in a variety of activities such as the pit-fight, or even have some of them be spies for you to backstab a Warchief for you to make it easier for you to finish them off. There's of course your usual skill tree this time a lot more versatile offering a lot of unique approaches to any situation. There's a fair bit more, but that's the rough idea.

[h1] Graphics [/h1]
I mean yeah, graphics are beautiful. Even now in 2023 the game still holds up and looks really good, genuinely beautiful and amazing. There are different regions that you end up exploring during Talion's quest for conquest, and each region looks unique and diverse with different weather.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]
Playing the game feels good, countering attacks and finishing enemies off in beautiful epic ways such as executions and a variety of special skills / attacks if you've unlocked them. The variety of approaches you can have due to all of your abilities to any situation makes the gameplay always feel unique and refreshing, especially as the high ranking orcs will adapt to your playstyle, so you have to constantly change your approach.

You can also dominate and ride a variety of mounts to even further change how the game is played. Although that all being said the game does have a few bugs. You can glitch into buildings or the terrain itself, however rare it does / did happen, so it's not a 100% perfectly polished game, but it is excusable due to the absolute size of this game's world and all of the content it has.

[h1] Expansions [/h1]
Game has 2 story expansions, pretty cool.

LOTR Sim
Dominate rough uruk-hai in this detailed Lord of the Rings BDSM simulator.

Pro:

Mounted combat is better than some games I have played (although not when the orc/troll you want to kill is immune to beats and fire). I found the warg-like mounts particularly useful with stealth attacks, and drakes are obviously good for burning enemies. It is also fun to heal your mount be having them feed on orcs.

The story was fun, but you will spend much more of your time grinding gear and captains for your army than enjoying it.

Con:

You cannot play again to experience the whole story line without overwriting your existing save! With all the grinding you do that is real bad.

The overall experience does get brought down by combat mechanics that function poorly at times. Some orcs are resistant to almost all hard-hitting attacks.

Now that I have played an Assassin's Creed game I can see WB basically copied AC game mechanics for combat while patenting their own for Nemesis. It seems innovative game developers should create a "pay it forward or pay royalty" policy style of patenting to discourage that behavior. Either share your own, or pay to copy others in yours.

Overall:

For an action/adventure game Witcher III or Skyrim would be better choices for the money, and both have more RPG options. They also have much better balanced sword/ranged strikes that don't require a special attack to do real damage. While the story was fun, I don't feel like playing again due to the grinding required.
