I bought this game for like 7$ on sale, and id highly recommend you do too if you ever see it at such a price.
The games easily worth its 60$ price point, and if it came out today and cost 80$, itd be one of the few games I'd agree is worth that pricepoint (Canadian dollars)

The campaign is fun, I barely know LOTR and I was still able to get hella enjoyment, the combat system reminds me highly of the Batman Arkham series, so if you've played that and enjoyed beating up guys, its a less complicated version that is also unique in its own ways. There were a lot of story beats and even just the characters drew me in, I have to play it to the end to know what happens, and if my favorite characters die or not!

The side missions are quite plentiful, and while they are kind of the same thing a lot, each encounter is different and will require a different strategy. Sometimes you have to fight 8 orc captains all higher level than you, so you will want to stealth around a bit, and take advantage of the campfires and explosive barrels found in the enviroment. Or pick off enemies from afar, or you can even just jump in there and slowly widdle down each and every healthbar with perfect counters, dodging, and executions. The base gameplay is very enjoyable for me, so all of the side content so far has been, and I plan to 100% my save.

The nemesis system, recruiting orcs, making them fight, infiltrate, and assist you on your quest for Mordor is one of the best parts of this game, and the main reason I bought it to be honest. And it doesn't disappoint, adds in tons of extra hours of enjoyment. I loved just spending hours in between missions going out and breaking the strongest captains and adding them to my ranks, anytime I was fighting a captain and they gave me a tough time, I would go out of my way to track them down and recruit. Even if it delayed my story progress a lot, it still was fun. And when my fortresses eventually got raided, it was easier than anything else, as my warchiefs are insanely OP from how often I did pit battles, and I havent even talked about them. I dont even want to spoil it for you if you've read this far, Pit fights and Orcs could've been a game on there own, filled with microtransactions and awful, but no. It exists here, and while it does feel "Unfair" at times, that unfairness can work in your favor occasionally, so dont take it too seriously.

Now, heres my literal one gripe from this game, and its something that's just made me Alt + f4 at least once. The movement system, now heres the problem with that, movement feels amazing in this game, especially out of combat. But when your fighting a large horde, and the captain your attacking puts you to 1 health from a single spear landing, you may want to retreat to get into stealth or go steal some health back. So youll go to run, well maybe youll dodge. thats fine, but then your climbing a tiny fence that you dont want to be, then your trying to double air jump over onto a wall that if climbed, would surely take you to safety.
However Tallion decides that it would instead be best to leap directly back into the horde. Leaving you surrounded by 20 orcs at 1 health, in a bad animation.

Seriously if the movement was refined just a bit to be smarter about jumping into things, and auto vaulting down hills and stuff. The game would be absolutely perfect, but this is frustrating, and you probably will notice it a few times. However it really doesn't take away from how good overall the game is, and if its on sale. Buy it and try it, it's highly worth it.

Carrying on from the fairly interesting Shadow of Mordor, Shadow of War is much the same, but more. It's more nonsense, more weird fanservice, more clunkiness and more time wasted.

After nearly 20 hours I gave up, feeling it unlikely I'd ever bother to actually finish the game, and so: here's why.

You may have heard of a little book (or a series of movies) called The Lord of the Rings, which revolves around the One Ring of Power. This game steps up to craft the Second Ring of Power, which turns into the pivotal object around which the game revolves. It allows our undead protagonist, Talion, and his ghostly elf-friend Celebrimbor to forge hordes of unreliable orcs into an army to fight for control of Mordor itself.

There in lies the most interesting quirk of the game: encountering, studying, fighting, subjugating and commanding various orc characters with different traits. You essentially become an orc collector, which is a fine idea! Though the game quickly over-uses this fine idea, turning a fun concept into a slow, grindy and repetitive affair that reduces the orcs to short-lived collectables. Originally the game was released with an invasive onlinse store, which likely explains the above issue well: the game was designed to waste time and frustrate the player to coax them into purchasing ways to make the game more fun. Still, the underlying idea is kind of fun!

However, the game is badly let down in almost every other area, from general gameplay to story to even the basic cast of characters. While Talion is a fairly average protagonist, though the game does little to establish his character and leaves it up to the player to play the first game before this one, the other characters feel thing, one-dimensional and dull. Celebrimbor is an annyoing elf-ghost who does nothing but whine and berate. The giant spider Shelob turns into a milf Frodo and Sam would definitely have spent more time with had she appeared to them as she does to Talion. Ratbag the orc returns from the first game to provide some fairly inappropriate comedic relief. None of the characters really click, though, nor provide more than a reason to awkwardly smile sometimes.

Otherwise the gameplay takes most of its cues from the Assassin's Creed series, along with the Batman Arkham games. Stealth exists, but is almost entirely optional as there is no punishment for not using it. Combat against a single opponent feels dull and repetitive, and so the game opts to throw in dozens of enemies at a time to add challenge and spectacle. This idea works in theory, but the game's mechanics and controls fall apart here. You may have your opponent one swing away from death, but the automatic lock-on mechanic might decide you want to target an entirely different enemy in the next county over, and so the attack button sends Talion leaping off into the distance. Climbing and parkour movement also suffer of similar issues where the player simply lacks control over their movements and can end up leaping off in unpredictable ways, or just simply stuck for extended periods of time as Talion refuses to let go of a ledge. I died a few times when trying to evade an enemy by leaping off a rooftop as Talion would step up to the edge, but instead of jumping off she would roll against an invisible barrier while not moving away from the enemy, leading to endless frustration.

On a technical level the game may have been passable back when it came out, but it hasn't aged all that well. Many visuals were lackluster back in the day, seemingly not having evolved at all from the first game, and now, years later, the game comes off as downright ugly from time to time. Music feel forgettable, while trying to invoke some of the Lord of the Rings movie soudntrack sensations, but it's use is misguided (I hated the comedy music that plays out whenever Ratbag shows up) and it usually ends up drowned out by all the shouting going on.

With broken mechanics, frustrating grinding, endless repetition and a story premise best left to some third-rate Tolkien fanboy's fanfic collection, Shadow of War is impossible to recommend.

As a huge fan of the Lord of the Rings franchise, I was excited to play "Middle-earth: Shadow of War". I'm happy to say that the game does not disappoint, offering an incredible open-world experience that immerses you in the world of Middle-earth.The graphics are stunning, with detailed landscapes, vibrant colors, and incredible character animations. The combat is satisfying, with a variety of moves and abilities to master, and the Nemesis System adds an extra layer of depth and strategy to the gameplay.The story is engaging and well-written, continuing the journey of Talion and Celebrimbor as they work to defeat the Dark Lord Sauron and his armies. The characters are well-developed and memorable, with great voice acting that brings them to life.But what really sets "Middle-earth: Shadow of War" apart is its replayability. The game is filled with side quests, challenges, and collectibles that will keep you playing for hours on end. And with the ability to recruit and command your own army of orcs, there are endless possibilities for customization and strategy.Overall, "Middle-earth: Shadow of War" is an excellent game that offers a truly immersive and rewarding experience. Whether you're a fan of the Lord of the Rings or just looking for a great open-world adventure, this game is definitely worth checking out."

But the real draw, is the Nemesis system. You can meet an Orc who is just a mere grunt, and while learning the controls, he kills you. Now, that grunt gets promoted to a Captain as Murk The Tark Slayer. So, because you're mildly salty, you hunt him down and kill him. Later, he returns after barely surviving his wounds as Murk The Survivor. So again, you hunt him down and kill him. Now you think he's gotta be dead for sure because you cleaved him in half. But then Murk The Machine shows up, rebuilt with metal. This goes on 7 more times, each time, he is less Orc, and more metal. Now, you finally decapitate him which is supposed to permanently kill. You relax. Hours of gameplay and days in real life later, you're doing some missions. You are fighting a necromancer enemy Orc, and he revives some of the captains you've killed, and guess who shows up? Murk, The Goddamn Machine. The very first Orc to kill you, following you deep into the game, never leaving, never dying, always there. So, this time, you purify him. Finally, he's gone. The Machine can rest

R.I.P Murk The Machine. January 2023 - March 2023. You were deeply hated, we will all not miss you

The Lord of the Rings franchise is as deep and fleshed out as it is loved by it's fans. Middle Earth: Shadow of War does it's fan's affection justice by remaining true to the written information provided by J. R. R Tolkien whilst filling in any blanks with a fresh sense of creativity and fitting details that are both entertaining and make sense. In the grander scheme of things, this singleplayer masterpiece from Warner Brothers Entertainment makes for an excellent gameplay experience filled with emotional, well voiced cut-scenes and action filled gameplay. While the multiplayer experience does leave much to be desired, the Nemesis system adds so much depth to interactions with NPC's and enemies it has little to no rival in its playing field and truly helps to add to the total experience, making it a must-play game.

General: 9.5/10
Graphics: 9/10
Soundtrack and EFX: 9/10
Multiplayer Experience: 3/10
Singleplayer Story: 10/10
Smoothness and Reliability: 8.5/10
UI and Menus: 9/10

The biggest issue with the game by far is that the combat isn't very good. In most 3D brawlers even the small hits feel great to do, they will have a nice hit noise and animation so that it is fun to wail on people even when you aren't doing much damage. This game doesn't have that. Your attacks are mostly dull "swing" noises that the enemies recoil from gently. Even your heavy attack gives the impression that it is hitting the enemies with the wind from the swing rather than a big two handed weapon.

The above would be okay if they had gotten some good effect for when you pull off a stealth kill or a finisher, but the game disappoints there too. At best you get a bit more of a solid noise, but nothing like the visceral feedback of the Dark Souls backstab "Dun... DUN" or the Yakuza fight ending "Woosh + Cash register". Not to mention the awful parry noise in this game is an ear grating wood on wood sound(this might be different if the enemy has a different weapon, but it seems to be usually wood) as opposed to a nice crisp success "ding".

Now the above may seem minor but that combination of animation and sound (as well as hit effects which I haven't mentioned yet) is what makes combat in a game "feel" better or worse. In addition to that it also helps to communicate more efficiently to the player what is going on as they fight. Set up correctly those effects will even be able to give the player information about the relative damage of attacks, which they can use to better plan out their fights and how to dispatch enemies(when health and damage aren't explicitly stated).

I will briefly mention that the game does have a bunch of loud effects that cut in as you fight that are meant to signal different things, but they don't sync well with the animations (or any other clear effect marker) so you can barely tell what they are for. The game also uses slowmo during fights in very strange ways, I don't even know from playing if it is just for the window when you can parry or dodge or if they are using it for other things as in a hectic battle it will just kick in randomly sometimes with no indicators on screen.

The above is enough for me to say that the game is a hard pass, but if you do pick it up anyway I recommend spending time reading the in game guides or maybe even looking outside the game for explanations of mechanics as the tutorials are really bad. They waste a lot of time forcing you to learn what buttons to press for things that have frequent onscreen prompts but don't do any in game explanation of core game mechanics like stealth, wraith mode, crafting/items/loot, status effects, etc. beyond telling you what buttons they are.

As a designed piece it fails on its core concept.

The artistic goal of the game was to make the orcs evolve around you, becoming the main villains and characters in the game. For this to work, you need to not just kill them immediately, so unless you have the difficulty turned up to the max, it does not work. In that event it becomes actually awesome! For the first 1 act. The problem is there are still story characters and story fights outside of that, which don't work on the hardest difficulty. You either get the artistic view (strong orcs) or the rest of the game, never both.

For the first act I had a super strong orc who killed me in a few different spots and became someone I dreaded and ran away from. He came back as an actual progression boss, and I could NOT kill him. I ended up having to exit the mission, track him down, and engineer the perfect situation to kill him. Awesome.

If only it worked with the rest of the game.

Shadow of War is an enjoyable Action RPG but a terrible Lord of the Rings game.

Shadow of Mordor had the benefit of being a UFO in the landscape of Lord of the Rings and, though not canonical, was also a fairly enjoyable Action RPG. I daresay the game felt quite intimate and thus of little significance of the LotR universe as it focused on Talion getting his revenge whilst exploring the uncharted lands of Mordor.

Shadow of War only builds on the Boromir/Arargon fantasy, the epic battles of the movies and making orcs "cool". Talion is now as powerful as the Witch King, leaps from building like Spiderman and raises armies in an instant. Orcs speak in a contemporary British accent, with expressions barely dating 50 years, turning interactions with them into slapstick comedy which has nothing to do in a LotR game.

You lose all sense of quest, journey, discovery and Homeric epiness from LotR (which to a certain extent Shadow of Mordor had clumsily managed to deliver on) - akin to most media based on LotR. The battle of good vs evil is non-existant, as the games blurs all lines on that front - something Tolkien always wanted to avoid.

Nevertheless most of you will enjoy your time with this game, but it is a far cry from Lord of the Rings and its pillars. Unsurprisingly it stands closer to the Arkham Asylum series which was (back then) in its prime. Perhaps a better name for this game would have been: Middle-Earth: Batman of Mordor.

This game finally is how it was supposed look when it was released all the way back in 2017. It's launch was plagued with community outrage and controversy. When I first played it, it left a very sour aftertaste. Gladly, 1.18 Patch fixed all the bullshit that was going on with this game (years later, I might add). The devs finally removed the store, which was filled with useless micro-transactions designed to pray on the fans of the franchise. They were totally unnecessary in a single-player action-RPG. It was a dick move from WB to milk every cent from this game. Aside from that, they raised the level cap, added another legendary set and most important, reduced the Shadow Wars grind at the end of the game. The "real" ending cut-scene was walled behind a 20 defensive siege missions gauntlet. A cheap move to pad the game's playtime. I remember, thats where I abandoned this game on my first playthrough in 2017. Now it's only 5 missions, if you lose one, then you have to play an offensive siege to retake the region. The devs took more liberties with the source material this time around, but the story is still enjoyable. Grab this one on sale and give it a chance.

This game is some old-fashioned fun. The nemesis system still holds up today and the Uruk-hai you go up against do have personality. It's the only game where your character getting killed generates a whole new story branch. Although, you will find yourself going up against some orcs that are exactly the same as others you have encountered. They may look different on occasions but a lot of the Uruks will have the same voices and lines. Shadow of War's main problem is that it gets boring after a while and you'll find yourself just playing a game of Pokemon with Uruks where you'll try to catch them all. This game should be played on harder difficulties as the nemesis system is much more fun. If you are a hardcore Tolkien fan then I do have to warn you that it plays around with the LOTR lore very liberally which does annoy me as a fan myself. Although, I do admit that it really isn't as bad as some other games which take their source from a popular book, movie, or TV show. At least here the game is fun and enjoyable

Initially purchased, but due to micro transactions, returned it. Then, years later, I went back to play it, and, to be completely honest, I think this game is excellent. The nemesis system is entirely awesome. It was very well done by Monolith. The additional DLCs are worthwhile because they do introduce new game-play mechanics and styles which you must follow when playing the DLCs. There is a good narrative in this game. Loved the conclusions. You can always lower the difficulty if you find the game-play too challenging because the battles can be too chaotic and overwhelming at times. (but still game handles the chaos right). The game-play was fair when I was playing on the Nemesis level. Yes, if you've played Shadow of Mordor, this exceeds your hopes for a sequel, at least in my opinion. Every orc war-chief, commander, or overlord feels different. It can be completed in as little as 45–55 hours if you want to enjoy the story and expansions.

Don't trust the number of hours I played this game on Steam. Because I had chores to do, I occasionally had to pause the game and leave it there for hours. My actual playing time is between 60 and 70 hours.

The game is ultimately worth the full price. Definitely give it a try during a discount.

Story follows Talion, who's on the hunt for revenge after he's betrayed by his elf fiancée, and murdered by Orcs. So he has to kill every Orc with no sympathy left in him, even the wounded ones.
I must admit, it's tough, even though the aim is to re-kill every Orc you encounter and thus boost your score. And i'm not sure if that's the correct way to think of it.
Just because you take an Orc's life, doesn't mean that the rest of them will just leave you alone. Even if they are totally unconscious, some ornery bastard will just get up and kill you anyway.

Gameplay is brilliant, you must really stop to think that a sadistic psychopath likes shooting innocent defenseless Orcs while they lie on the ground trying to get back on their feet.
And if you want to be even more brutal, you can make their deaths a real spectacle with graphics so realistic they would give your wallet a major heart attack.
Every time an Orc is about to take his last breath, he'll suddenly jerk violently and flail his limbs in pain, only to suddenly die moments later.
Saddest part is that he's always right there for you to shoot at any time, but i guess you'd rather risk damaging your gear than kill a guy just to blow off some steam.

There's not much story to be told here, and if you really want to experience the whole spectrum of killing orcs, then you better go through the whole game to find out how it ends. I played this game for a few hours and i'm still playing it right now.

Update: I've changed my mind, this game sucks, don't play it

You play as a ranger who can bend the will of orcs to his own. It's like playing Pokémon, but instead of catching cute little creatures, you're enslaving monstrous hordes to fight for you. Gotta catch 'em all... or something like that.

Those good old days when Celebrimbor wasn't an old useless man and Galadriel wasn't going around to fight the patriarchy cause "you didn't see what i've seen", hell yeah sunshine. 

See, playing this game in 2023 shows how much respect and willing to be as Tolkinian as possible the writers tried to be in inventing a new story and trying to attaching it to the original lore. After that disaster of Ring of Powers, you can't appreciate enough how the story, even if not canonical, could absolutely become part of the original story and expand it without completely breaking what Tolkien wrote. 

Funny thing is that I've already played and got the platinum on Playstation when the game came out, but couldn't resist to playing it again in 2023, and still today the game holds well in every single aspect you can think of, from the graphic, storyline, combat system and the huge amount of things and side quests that you can take part on, especially cause they aren't just " things to do " to make it as long as possible, in a way or another they tie to some aspect of the original lore and expand it. 

Every single aspect that was good in the first game, has been perfectionated in this second chapter, everything polished and made it almost perfect, to the point where getting all the achievements isn't boring as the majority of the games out there. 

As a Tolkien fan I cannot recommend it more  to both Tolkien fans or normies, especially those who endured one entire season of that Amazon insult and they need a good story based on Mordor.

Probably one of the best games I've played in a long time. 1: movement can be awkward, especially when you are trying to get somewhere quick in a busy environment. You don't always go where you want to go it seems

Other than that, I would give this game a solid 10/10 for story, 8/10 for gameplay. Pick this game up if you get a chance

The introduction to the game was very wonky, confusing in regards to figuring out all the features that were available. This one-man army thing gets very tedious when orcs just keep spawning to attack; learn to do more stealth, running away, or hiding. Pretty annoying to try to pick up upgrades when endless hordes of orcs keep interrupting you. Thankfully, there are exploding barrels to shave off some of these annoying characters. These orcs just sponge all the attack moves, makes the fights pretty boring. I'm overwhelmed with all the features, which the floating tutorial signs persistently tell me what button to mash. The intro monologues of each general/captain can't be skipped; I had 3-4 of them appear in one area. This really breaks the flow of the battle with all these distractions. 

Once you figure out the game mechanics, things begin to flow and become fun. That's when unexpected game crashes begin to occur. I can't recommend a game that I can't finish, since the game crashes once I start one of the story missions. Nonetheless, I appreciate the effort made to create this game. Nice graphics and interesting story so far...just skip the missions that cause crashes and you'll have enough fun.

This, is not a review.
This, is a love letter.

I'm asking one question to passionate gamers here: 
How many times did you came back to your most treasured entertainment software once completed ? You can boot up Super Mario Bros and enjoy your 100th run, you can start a skirmish on your preferred C&C and know you will enjoy its sand box strategy for the next hour, as if it was released yesterday. Examples are as numerous as there are players on this little planet.

What accomplished the nemesis system here ?
Shadow of Mordor was a beta version, just to refund on the development costs. Now, you made your first run of shadow of war on normal, discovered the mechanics, experienced some hard times, had some fun, but something happened, you HAD to restart it on higher difficulty. 

Why ? Hehe, I won't spill it there, but I think you already understand.

I stopped my second difficult playthrough halfway just to experience from scrath the gravewalker difficulty, the 'one shot' and 'no mistakes allowed' kind. Many complained about its unfairness, and they are right, but that's definitely where the game truly shines in my eyes.

Talion is a powerhouse, but frail. Orcs cannot be stopped, they will overwhelm you, whatever you do. But shadow is on your side. And cheese as well. So many tools are given to you, you always have several ways to face a captain, then kill him for fancy new gear and experience, or hire a devoted zealot who will back you up.

Oh boy, your first encounters will enrage you, but you will learn from every mistake, spy your foe, manage long range *astards, have the first blow, crowd control with nasty explosive grug barrels if necessary, flee and isolate your target if everything goes out of hand, and in the end, prevail.

It may be a painful journey, but every head rolling on the ground, every gem refined, every gear found is definitely rewarding. I remember so many orcs, from this dumb bard who humiliated me so many times, to this poor dude I burned to death four times and always came back, to finally become one of my finest bodyguards.

And then, there is the epiphany. 
I was just minding my daily business, looking for a sweet isolated target, then got ambushed by not one, not two, not three but four bloodthirsty captains. I was about to flee once again, but at this point of your journey, you are Neo in the subway, facing agent Smith. You don't run, you start to believe. In seconds, I called a drake and burned all of these sorry dudes. That was one of the most satisfying experience I had with this game. 

You can just even the unfair odds, just like in classic Xcom, but here, it is YOU who spank the RNG.  

That's shadow of war baby !

This game feels like a paint-by-numbers sequel that attempts to ape Ubisoft's formula (with some degree of success) while expanding on the Nemesis system that made the earlier Shadow of Mordor so successful in a way that strikes me as a mile wide and an inch deep. 

Despite all the options available and the different enemy and damage types, everything felt very samey in a very short amount of time. The first game overstayed its welcome by the end, but the core gameplay loop held on for most of it. This game offers very little new moment to moment despite the refinements to the Nemesis system.

The story here is told better, but to what end? The engine does a remarkable job with subtle facial expressions, and the voice actors are killing it, but all in service to a story that lacks anything resembling the stakes or cohesion I needed to overcome the plodding gameplay.

If you want a fun experience incrementally leveling up and finding better gear, there are umpteen ARPGs. If you want a good story, there are plenty to choose from. If you want an open world, there are options that don't feel spacious in this perfunctory way. This game is the definition of C effort. Tons of money and talent and energy and intelligence went into making something that is wholly and entirely adequate.

Its the same game as spiderman, witcher 3, fallout 3 and 4, and every assassins creed game. same exact game with different paint.

however, each of those games has their 1 thing that differentiates them.  For Shadow of War, its the Nemesis system, which generates random orc enemies with random powers and weaknesses, and if you abuse the same technique against them multiple times they become immune to it permanently, eventually leading to orcs returning immune to just about everything you can do to them, making for truly ferocious nemesis'.

I've done 3 complete play throughs, so add another 40 hours to my current played time since one of those was on Ps4.  
The servers are shut down so you can't buy premium currency anymore, and the nemesis forge is shut down on Shadow of Mordor as well.  Still, I didnt even notice this because they werent needed anyway.  
You can also save your favorite orcs and bring them with you in a fresh play through (and weapons and gear) serving as a poor mans new game plus (But starting a new game with a full set of legendary level 60 gear and multiple legendary orcs to deploy into your army and help you conquer the world all over again is certainly a fun power trip, who doesnt like 1-shotting all the orcs who gave you trouble before? that is, if you can even find the same orcs since the nemesis system generates millions of possible orc combinations--- and by no means are these simple paint swaps.  Each orc can have one class, one tribe, one specialization, and multiple extra features including flags, probabilities, possible upgrades, multiply all that together and you have literaly millions of possible unique orcs, and the voice overs are so varied that you might not hear the same line twice.)

You should play shadow of mordor first but you dont have to. its one long continuous story ,but again, you dont have to.

I've given this game multiple chances, each time i've tried to get into it but I just can't. Something always prevents me from continuing. Talion is bland and dumb, Celery Bimbob is bland and an asshole. The story is boring and feels like some tolkein fanfiction I wrote in 6th grade.

The gameplay is fine though. I like the challenge, I like how the captains encourage you to be smart because a one on one fight with the orcs is often a losing proposition. I like how the game is unfair, encouraging YOU to be smart and use weaknesses, making you feel smart when you take down a captain. But after a while it just becomes a slog. You take over a region, collect the collectibles, and that's fun. Then it tells you to do it for six or seven other regions and I just.. can't. I can't care. I can't engage. I don't want to climb on the hamster wheel and do all of it again. It feels grindy, it feels unsatisfying to do the same thing over and over until the boring story progresses.

Maybe this will appeal to you, but it didn't appeal to me.

At the time of the writing of this review I've only put about 7 hours into the game, and yet even so I can fully understand how and why someone could/would sink hundreds of hours into this game. Middle-earth: Shadow of War reminds me a mixture of Dante's Inferno, Assassin's Creed, and Dynasty Warriors. The gameplay is fluid and polished, the controls are intuitive, the overall creative design is top notch, and the Nemesis System is highly engaging and addictive. I am very glad I pulled the trigger on this game (a full 6 years after release ;) and am already looking forward to milking this title for all its worth.

While I m sure this is a good game. 
I am having lots of issues playing it on the steam deck. 
1) The controls will stop working suddenly for no reason.
2) The controls will switch to keyboard input and I will need to restart the game
3) It doesn't save often, I played for a good 45 mins, only to have the key input issues, restart the game and I was back to the beginning. 40 mins of the gameplay was gone.

As far as game play goes, I really enjoy Shadows of War.  It is generally smooth and rewards quick response time, and probably does this sort of game as well as can be expected.

As far as the lore goes, I'm okay with it, but it does take some pretty strong liberties with the source material.  I'm no Tolkien scholar, but I've read enough that tells me this is possibly within the bounds of middle earth mythology, but it I believe it pushes the line.  That said, I really enjoyed the story regardless.

If you relish the idea of a Numenorean demi-wraith and an elf blade threading a ruined city delivering cold steel justice from the shadows, this game is for you.  I feel it ranks up there with the original Assassin's Creed and the original Shadows of Mordor game in terms of quality games with this sort of experience.  The cinematics are a bit overdone, but they are well voice acted and make the game experience better overall.  High recommendations.

Really weird game. It's good until it breaks and it breaks too often for my taste. Combat can be going great until Talion gets stuck on something and fails to hit the orc he just slid 15 feet to attack. Prompts fail to appear too often. I've been playing on the highest difficulty and the game will just spawn mobs of orcs behind or around me, thinking I wouldn't notice them pop in on the mini-map. It gets really intense, which is great, but the dissatisfaction of seeing how artificial the challenge is at the high difficulties or dying to the weird combat inconsistencies can suck the fun out of a play session fast. The Orc Captain interactions happen too often and last too long, which really takes me out of the game. I found myself rolling my eyes and much of the dialogue and at the 3rd Captain that randomly spawns in and treats you to an unskippable cutscene after I just watched 2 other unskippable cutscenes from the first 2 Captains that randomly spawned in.
There are good aspects though. The expanded nemesis system is like a whole other game nested inside the storyline. I can see how people find it good enough to recommend the game, but I can't get over the inconsistencies of the game in general, so I can't immerse myself in the system. I also like the online vendettas.
I would say the game summed up in one word is "inconsistent".

[h1]Disclaimer[/h1]
I finished the game on Hard.

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
Nemesis System is ok. The mechanics of combat are not without problems, but marginally acceptable.

Everything else, most importantly controls - are ass.

Your enjoyment of this game depends solely on how much you find Nemesis engaging. To me it got old after around 15h and never became anything other that tiresome.

[h1]Description[/h1]
It's an action-adventure game. If you played any Ubisoft game - you played this, with one difference - Nemesis System.

Nemesis System governs your interactions with enemy leaders. It lets you kill them, but also provides options for recruiting some for your own army. You may recruit bodyguards of your enemy and then have them betray him for an easy kill. Enemies that kill you will grow stronger, but taking revenge will give you better rewards. You can stregthen your forces while weaking the enemy in many ways.

All that while doing typical open-world quest-questing, collectible-collecting and tower-... climbing. Outside the Nemesis System this is the most generic-by-the-numbers-soulless-open-world-action-adventure you've ever seen.

You play as Talion and you fight Sauron. That's all context you need.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
[b]+ Nemesis system[/b]
It's ok and fun for the first 15h, which is about half of the playtime.

[b]+ Orcs[/b]
There are many of them. Lots of different kinds, different faces, classes, weaknesess and powers. They all even have their own personality, will react to your meddling and even have different reactions based on events during fighting them. Some may run from you when broken, some may even reappear after being killed. Some may lose their mind if you decide to spare them.

Interactions are not only fluff, but are integrated into the very mechanics of the Nemesis System. It was important for this part of the game to be good and holy fk - they managed it.

[b]+ RPG mechanics[/b]
Equipment is fully modelled on your character. Skills offer a lot of combat options.

[b]+ Last mission[/b]
Actually exciting despite making no sense. After all is done you can continue indulging in Nemesis System if you want and you get some new, cool powers to boot.

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
[b]- Freerunning/parkour[/b]
If you dare to try and sprint in any kind of environment that isn't a perfectly flat area with no clutter/walls/enemies around - your character will do EVERYTHING in his power to climb, vault over or grab onto every god-fking-damn piece of scenery and will bump into every single thing instead of doing what you'd want him to do. At some points I was convinced that the game was trolling me with how unpredictable parkour behaved.

[b]- General control fkery[/b]
Don't enable "toggle stealth", the game was not made with it in mind. You won't be able to enter stealth while sprinting for example, which is not a problem when using normal "hold" staealth.

Every time the game requires you to do anything in combat that requires precision (except shooting your bow, that works ok) - you may be sure that Talion will do anything but the thing you want him to. An orc in front of you that you want to just hit? You will instead target a berserker behind him, who counters normal hits. Want to dominate a broken doggo when a captain is near it? Your dominate will target the captain even though it cannot work on him until he himself is broken. There is no way to guarantee what target you will actually hit with any of your soft-auto-targetting abilities from basic attack to executions.

[b]- Dodging[/b]
There are some enemies that have attacks that cannot be avoided in certain distance. In a game designed around parrying and dodging attacks this is a bad thing. You are forced to either kill those enemies with your bow, restoring your limited ammo using pickups many times until you deal enough damage to kill, or you risk getting mashed by an undodgeable attack.

Then there's problems with dodging itself not working when you really need it. People lie that it doesn't have invincibility frames and you have to dodge out of an attack. That's untrue. Dodge makes you untargetable for an attack, but only when specific conditions are met and it's mechanics are inconsistent. Example - to dodge an arrow, you must press dodge as the arrow is being fired regardless of the distance and travel time of the attack. You will get hit if you try to dodge it by visuals - it will connect mid-rolling animation. On the other hand - many attacks with "DODGE IT!" have to be dodged entirely while the attack is in effect already. If you dodge at the moment when attack is beginning, like with arrows - you'll get hit mid-roll.

Most of the time it's ok to get hit a bit because of this, but when you are forced to fight Orcs that can 1-shot your entire HP (or suffer through hours of grind) - that's a problem.

[b]- Characters/Story[/b]
Nobody is intreresting and you will care about no character. In many ways the Orcs have more personality than all those people you are watching talk at you during cutscenes. The plot is predictable and shallow. There are 2 plotlines that make attempt to be interesting and end up not being total garbage, but nothing is "good".

Don't let me start on how little is has in common with Tolkien's world. Then again, this game clearly wanted us to have fun and didn't really care about the rest, which I can at least respect to some degree, unlike sht like "Rings of Power". That trash didn't care about Tolkien and certainly didn't care about fun.

[b]- Nemesis System not perfect[/b]
I have some gripes with it. For example I've had my Orcs participate in 1v1 combat trials and they often seem far too random. My high level Orc with resistance to arrows could die by getting slapped in the face by a low-level crossbow Orc 20 times in a row with same animation playing every time. My fighter could kill the crossbow guy in 2 hits, but I guess the crossbow slap thing was higher on game's priority list when checking for conditions of an attack, so it just looped forever until my Orc was dead. In fact, my Orcs seem to die to enemies that are weaker than them far too often for it to be a coincidence, there must be some fkery going on.

You can get vastly overwhelmed when trying to dominate an Orc, which leads to fishing for a stealth dominate or something. Coupled with bad controls it's infuriating.

[b]- Excessive immunities[/b]
Some Orcs are immune to arrows, basic attacks, freezing and a lot of other things. At some point it leads to you finding gimmick ways of dealing with them and it's just too much sometimes.

[b]- Grind[/b]
At some point you either keep forcing yourself to fight orcs that are 10+ levels above you and can kill you with 1 ranged hit while throwing multiple attacks in a row and having infinite reinforcements of berserkers and defenders, OR - you swallow the bitter pill of level grinding. It can take multiple hours to grind out 1 level once you have no more quests to do and rely only on the Nemesis System.

[b]- Quests[/b]
Most main story quests are boring. They follow typical "follow NPC" design, but dialogue and characters are bad so you don't care about most stuff that happens. Then you have slap-fights vs bosses, which take too long and are insultingly shallow.

[h1]Lowdown[/h1]
It's what it is. Nemesis System wrapped around a very generic open-world action-adventure game with poor controls, story and characters. If Nemesis was not in this game, then it would be a forgettable 4/10, mostly due to problems with lack of proper control over most of your actions.

But since Nemesis does lead to engaging gameplay elements, dynamic storytelling and is fun to experience overall - it elevates an otherwise mediocre game to a new standard. At least for a while.

I got this game for $9 or so with everything, far after it expired and they gave up on trying to cash out on MTX in a singleplayer game.

I don't really remember much of the first game. I thought it was a cool diversion from the Assassin's Creed formula in a more chaotic, frantic way and I just like Lord of the Rings in general. Naturally, the nemesis system is the highlight of this and its prequel; the particular system patented in all of its legally-restricted glory that no other game can emulate for another 13 years (as of now the patents were extended to 2036).

But this game is very anti-player. It's very hard on the hands. I play on a gamepad because these types of games are just more enjoyable to me that way, much alike playing Elden Ring. But this game is the only game that manages to make my fingers hurt after 2 or 3 hours of play.

This is crazy to me. I've had 10 hour sessions in Elden Ring with very few breaks and I don't think my fingers have ever hurt this much from playing a game for 2 hours. The combat is genuinely so awful. I don't think mechanically it's bad, but the APM required to not die in any given fight or just to move around the environment just hurts my hands. Why do I have to hold the A button to run? Were they incapable of scaling movement off of how far you move the thumbstick?

I tried to play this game for two different sessions. I ragequit after my first one and again on my second attempt because I just wasn't having fun. This game started to bring up all the bad memories I had of the first game being much of the same way: mechanically a fun game, but functionally terrible for the player to enjoy. I was so gods-damned relieved I beat the first game after 15 or so hours. I actually tried to do a lot of the side content too.

There's stuff here and there to enjoy but the UI is awful, the gameplay is awful, my hands hurt, and I'm frankly not invested that much in the characters to care anymore.

I wanted to really like this game because of how cool the protagonist is, but the more that I played the more that i felt that the game was a bit shallow. I played 15 hours, which is a good amount of time to get a feel for a game and after that time I felt that the game had little to make the journey worth playing. The appeal is the nemesis system where orcs are made to be interactive every time that you meet a captain, but it got annoying real quick. Their dialogue is all almost similar, the combat with them feels like you're just hacking at a bigger target with no strategy needed to kill most of them. At times its more irritating when they gain immunity's becuse then they just manhandle you when you accidentally try to jump over them. Despite that tho i thought the story was good and the atmosphere of the game was great those were the two things that made me want to keep on pushing through the story. But the combat is the biggest with the game where i feel like it's a dynasty warrior with a couple more mechanics to the combat system,

After having enough problems with the controls, specifically in any situation involving banners and shield users, the combat gets way too buggy and doesn't register a lot of the buttons pressed even with extra allotted time. It's not a matter of hitting buttons on time, it's the fact that you get hit regardless and now you're a dummy for all other follow up attacks. The Commander Captain can summon reinforcements with no cool down while also giving an attack buff that spawns the banners, which he summons after each on is destroyed. Sure, clearing infinite normal Uruks is easy even with some Ologs mixed in, but one Commander spamming Reinforcement Call is testament to why I am giving this a negative review. Everything else is great and has some insane depth to the overall life of the game that I would love to list, but as I proceed through combat I am reminded why I waited to get this game for 75% off. I do recommend this game if it's on sale for less than 30$ if you really want to play it.

Update: I have sobered from my rage and played an additional 50 hours to get my moneys worth. I wish I had just quit. I destroyed the game on Nemesis, despite what people say online. I'd already been screaming at the game the entire 50 hours for the janky climb mechanics and constant stop you mid fight captain speech interruptions, mind you, so I'm pretty angry at this point ready to beat the game and be done. I get the next spy broken, go to recruit him while I'm at full health and get tackled by a Caragor. Do the quicktime and press space bar to roll away aaaand there was another quick time. No damage no dazed none of that sh*t, just one hit you're dead bye bye. Yeah, bye bye game! Not even worth finishing with that cheap nonsense. I destroyed every enemy in the game up to that point and got killed in one hit by a quick time event. No thanks. I'll play shadow of Mordor see how hard that sucks.

Excellent game play, story and graphics. Even when you complete it 100%, you can replay or continue to attack fortresses or play vendetta's

Plenty of games direct their player-driven narratives in common methods. Shadow of War's patented Nemesis system awes the player with its impactful unpredictability, which makes every encounter thrilling and unique. You will get ambushed mid-mission, be saved when confronted by death, etc.

Revenge is an atrocious, primitive feeling. The directors know this, and implementing it into a game surpasses other games in the usual kill quests, or any other objectives. Finally executing an orc that has killed you multiple times is so satisfactory, until their necromancer blood-brother rushes in to the supposedly ended fight, only to resurrect my trophy kill and have them murder me again as undead. It makes the story feel highly personal and captivating at times.

Although, it is a shame no other game studios can replicate the Nemesis system as it is very promising for the gaming industry in creating procedurally-generated narratives.

Highly recommended, playing the first game is optional.

Yet another episode of: I wish steams reviews weren't just yes or no.

Yes, I liked the game... I had fun. However the story fell of at the end of act 3. I hated act 4, I didn't finish it. The true ending is well written, the grind to reach it is bs. I feel that the lack of resolution between Talion and Calibrimbor is very dissatisfying. Talion even mentions how he misses the ringmaker even though he betrayed him. The concept of Talion just fighting until he loses to the ring just feels like a painful ending. On another note, I'm glad the final fights weren't just quick time events as they were in the previous game. Overall, I just felt like the game left me wanting more and I hate that feeling. It's not a "oh I want more because it's so fun", it's a "I need more because I feel let down". 

Anyway, I like Eltariel though her betrayal felt way out of left field. There was almost no build-up to that. Her DLC was insanely fun, loved the NPCs. I wish we had more of those in the main game that were more reoccurring. 

I think my main issue with this game was game build up. I think that each area should have unlocked once you completed a fort and the main story there. I ended up jumping around a ton because I completed things in a poor order which semi-killed my interest in the game. I don't mind a bit of linear gameplay - sometimes it's better for the story.

This is my third playthrough on the game. I've always been fan of Assassins Creed style games and always a huge fan of LoTR content. If you enjoy both, you will most likely enjoy this game. 

The game has a nice combat system that can be repetitive unless you make use of the skill unlocks and constantly switch up your traits for your current "prey". I use the term prey because you're essentially hunting down Orcs to add to your Bastion defenses. That isn't the story though, just a nice little game mechanic. You can challenge Orc leaders who have different traits, and once almost beaten you can break their will and have them work for you.

Other than that it's fun running around absolutely manhandling these Orcs. If you pay attention you should rarely die on Normal. I imbibe the devil's lettuce and my super slow reaction time still has me leagues against these Orcs.

Just add the Middle-earth™: The Shadow Bundle to your cart and you can thank me later :)

TL;DR: 
Verdict: 7/10
Act I is a chore; Act II ignites the fire.

Review:
Act I is brutally hard to complete; not because of it's difficulty, but because of it's boring, repetitive, A-B quests that have you shaking your head in frustration.  I refunded this title 3 other times before... all because of Act I.  Act II, is a whole different experience which leads me to recommend this title.

HUGE world with nothing to do... common in most "open-world" title of this age.  The story is vastly underwhelming.  It is not engrossing at all and you're not going to connect to any character. Bummer, because the first title of Middle-Earth was the exact opposite and the first carried you through the game.  That being said, ME: Shadow of War really shines in the gameplay starting in Act II.  In Act I you're literally running to opposite sides of the map to start quests and it's very linear.  Starting in Act II, you're able to "control" Orcs and other beasts to build your army.  Super cool! 

I spend most of my time building my army and finding the biggest, baddest, creepiest looking Orcs I can to fill the ranks.  I came across this one a**hole Orc who killed me three times (lol?) because he countered many of my takedowns and didn't allow me to have a "second wind".  I had to put my ego aside and recruit this f***er,  After adding him to my ranks (finally), he was assassinated by a rival Orc tribe.  Then, one of my bros attempted to assassinate me! The audacity!  

Sending death threats to captains and collecting gear is pretty fun.  I still have no idea what is going on with the story, but that's OK because the gameplay in Act II makes up for it.  Is it kinda repetitive? Yes.  Is it kinda empty? Yes.  Does the story absolutely suck? Yes.  If you can stomach Act I, then you won't be disappointed with title starting in Act II... trust me, I refunded this title 3 other times before and STEAM kindly accepted my refund request each time.

But, the gameplay makes up for the many negatives.

This game is so FUN to play!! Don't bother playing it in a higher difficulty than Normal or potentially Nenemis as the game is already challenging enough if you don't have any particular advantage over your enemy. Since the captains adapt to you combat style, they can easily become almost invisible if you take your time to kill them. But that’s why the nemesis system is awesome! Enemy adaption is really a great idea and is very well implemented in the game. You will have to face dozens of captains during your game and there is this feeling that all captains are unique. The redundancies start to occur after 30h of game, though.
The combats are also a great source of fun. It’s very similar to Shadow of Mordor, so similar to the Batman Arkham series. Fights against captains are hugely influenced by the strength and weakness traits of your enemy but there are enough of these traits to offer multiple combinations that will force you to adapt your style of game. Since each fight is different, it is very hard to get bored even after more than 30h.
On top of that there is the fortress system. You must capture them killing several though enemies while your army and their army are fighting. But when captured, you must defend your fortress so you become the defender and you loose, you will to capture it again.
The graphism is good for a game that will celebrate its 5th birthday this year. No issue to run it at 100+ FPS in 1440p full details with my 1080 Ti.
Only bad point in my opinion: the story. It is not linear so it’s easy to get lost. At the end, it’s just a story of conquest with some more or less memorable quests in the middle. It’s gets better toward the end. You might dislike the faith of your character because it’s probably incompatible with TLOTR lore but it is one of the two options the devs had, and I find it interesting.
The game is currently on special offer at -85%! For only £5.99 don’t miss the bargain.

Story is amazing. Gameplay mechanics are good, but there are a few things that should be different. For example, friendly fire should not exist in this game, because you're in a bunch of enemies pretty much all the time, and you get stuck fighting your own allies. Next thing, there's a LOT of grinding, which in my opinion should be a bit less for this type of game. Next thing, maybe it's my PC, but I played this game on 2 different PCs and I feel like it's not optimised enough. Next thing is the worst. I find this game to be really fun. I think the nemesis system is one of the most interesting real world application of AI (well now that GPT-3.5 is out, that might change). I think nearly every system in the game is fun. The choices that have to be made when leveling. The gear progression. The crystal farming. The only negative I can think of is the loot box system. I basically never touched it, but I know there were many issues with it. 

I also know that people complained about the grind to get to the real ending. I would disagree. I have got the real ending twice now. Both times were fairly easy and did not feel like a grind. I could see how it could be hard if you did not take full advantage of the nemesis system and did not have strong allies that counter the definitely unkillable at that point captains. 

I do not think there is much replayability after completing the game on the hardest difficulty. 

Also, if you are a fan of the Lord of the Rings books, then you will probably hate the story. You still might like the gameplay.

Launched in 2017 but is still heaps of fun today. Aside from the lore and atmosphere of being a Lords of the Rings game, I think it is the nemesis system that keeps players entertained. They should not have made a paywall for the DLCs - Blade of Galadriel, etc. Instead, I would have paid for DLCs that gave the orcs more accents on top of the English ones, e.g., Jackie Chan, Chris Rock, Antonio Banderas - making the nemesis system even funnier. This game is a solid 8/10 even by today's standards. Try to buy it on sale: max price €7.

Middle-earth: Shadow of War has its ups and downs, but the one thing that really sets it apart for me is the interaction between the orcs. The Nemesis System, which creates unique orc captains and allows you to build relationships (or rivalries) with them, is just plain cool.

Seeing the way that different captains react to your actions and remembering them from battle to battle is incredibly satisfying. It's like playing a game within a game, and I could spend hours just messing around with the orcs and seeing what happens.

Unfortunately, the rest of the game is a bit underwhelming. The story and characters are forgettable, and the gameplay can get repetitive. The graphics are nice, but not enough to carry the whole game.

Overall, I'd say that if you're a fan of the orc interactions and want to see more of the world of Middle-earth, then Shadow of War is worth checking out. But if you're looking for a truly immersive and well-rounded gaming experience, you may want to look elsewhere.

Shadow of War praise for its improved combat mechanics, detailed open-world, and the inclusion of the Nemesis system, which creates unique enemy characters with distinct personalities and motivations. Some players criticized the game's reliance on microtransactions, lengthy cutscenes, and repetitive side missions. Despite these criticisms, the game is widely considered a strong entry in the Middle-earth series and a must-play for fans of the Lord of the Rings franchise and action RPGs. Personal opinions on Middle-earth: Shadow of War vary, with some players enjoying its immersive world, engaging combat, and memorable enemy characters, while others feel that it falls short in certain areas, such as its repetitive missions and heavy reliance on microtransactions.

I have had soooo much fun in this game, and it's prequel! For me they are the games that Assassin's Creed series should be. It helps to have a love of the Cinematic LOTR universe to truly love this game, and really adds to that I feel rather than just exploiting it, but at the same time it isn't core to the gameplay or fun if you're not bothered.

The Orc nemesis system is even better in this sequel, and for me the arrival of each war-chief remains the highlight of the game. The sheer amount of love and care that has obviously gone into each character I am in awe of, and I honestly barely noticed two warchiefs make the same introduction as another after almost 70 hours of play encountering literally hundreds of them - and still finding character types I hadn't seen before after that time. It's an amazing artistic aspect of the game. 

The combat system and default key bindings - whilst not necessarily where I'd have put them - become absolute second nature after a few hours play, and allow you move around the world using all the various methods, and fight, with both ease and comfort.

The game's biggest downside is only how similar it still is to the prequel. You may well be disappointed with this if you play them back to back, but after several years since the first game I was delighted to return, and there were enough new angles and challenges and story to make it all enticing. The counter-point to this, is that you won't really miss that much except a bit of back-story if you play this one first (or only).

If I had one other minor issue, it would be the constant influx of inventory gear - much of which is clearly useless as you progress - and the lack of a quick and consistent way to dispose and recycle them (some you can 'sell' with one key, others require a sub menu, for no obvious reason). There's also fundamental issues with the Legendary gear being almost universally worse than the best items of Epic and Rare throughout the game, at least until the end-game when you can don most of a full suit above level 60. But none of this affects what you're doing or why as they all just fall in your lap regardless as you progress - the inventory just could have been implemented a bit smoother.

I gather some aspects of the online stuff has been stripped from the game, but I honestly didn't notice what, and I was expecting to, given the warnings. It is of such credit to the devs that they tidied this game up for long-term viability and recognise where it needed this rather than leaving it to just break and be abandoned.

I probably wouldn't (and didn't) buy it at full list price after all this time, but for around just £5 that I paid in the Steam Sale for the Definitive edition, it was bargain of the Century.

[b] Achievements. A bit of everything. [/b] 

[h1] The Game[/h1]
Open-world action game with a heavy focus on the story, nemesis-system and recruiting followers to expand your army. 

[h1] The Achievements [/h1]
The achievements have a mix of everything in encounters, story and challenges. Guides are available, completes in about 70 hours. DLC is required.


[h1] Recommendation [/h1]
The game offers a lot of freedom to find and recruit specific orcs to your army. With different personalities and a good nemesis-system the enemies and ancounters feel great and offer a lot of depth in terms of difficulty and variation. A great recommendation.

Side note: the micro transactions have been removed from the game. You can however earn in game loot-boxes from challenges. Beware of cheaters that massively boost their followers.

OPINION: 
So far so good, I am enjoying the pace. I have just come of RDR2 and this is like a breath of fresh air. 

SCORE: a Solid 7/10

GRIPE(s):
I have a few, but for the most part everything is as it should be.
1. The gear you have currently equipped will NOT show in any cut scene, or any alternative skin you obtained. 
2. If you have a female skin equipped the orcs still refers to you as he and him. Not very LBQGT. I am joking... Its just annoying.

COMBAT: 
The combat is entertaining interesting and just challenging enough to keep wanting more. The skill tree progresses nicely and keeps up with the elevation in difficulty. 

Stealth combat in this game is rewarding and not too slow, which often happens. Had that experience with AC Valhalla, where you could stealth infiltrate a base but ending up saying "screw this" and letting the proverbial guns blaze. Afterwards always asking, could that have been more rewarding if I stuck to stealth?

RELEVANCE: 
I have to keep reminding myself that this game is 7 years old (as far as I know) I have always liked the Tokien lore, this so far is very true to John's work. 

OTHER NOTES:
The games takes your hand, walks you into the front door, switches on the light in the entrance hall and leaves you there to find the rest out for yourself, but just as you are about to go into the wrong room it grabs your hand. I find this refreshing. You are free to explore at your own pace, fight one on one or do stealth, and like a concerned parent it guides you along the path. That is without feeling as if you are being forced.

Other reviews are far more detailed, so I'll only list a few pointers here.

I bought the basic game with no expansions.  

TLDR:  If you enjoy the LOTR universe, and you don't mind that the writers significantly expanded upon Tolkien's story, then I feel this game is worth your money and time.  The writing is good, and the LOTR style and flavor remains, despite it not being canon.

Certainly, if you enjoyed the first game, this one is bigger, better, and even more fun.  I found it addictive and very entertaining, giving it an 8 or 9 on my personal scale.  If you haven't played the first game, this one catches you up in the first 10 minutes, so no worries.

The basic game loop... exploring, combat (both stealth and head-on), revealing the map areas, leveling your character (and eventually, your "hirelings"), adding powers, abilities, armor and weapons is a joy in this game.

Despite obviously being contrived, the story is still really good, with lots of exciting cut scenes and good acting.  Sauron and his more powerful minions are suitably scary... and while the constant banter of the orcs can be disgusting or even terrifying, it is more often hilarious.

If you choose to thoroughly scour each area before you move on, you'll see your character become unbelievably powerful... though it is possible to go very far (maybe even finish?) the game without focusing on min/maxing or grinding through much combat.  But why?  The grind in this game is SO MUCH FUN.

I enjoyed the combat so much that I kept putting off the story quests for a very long time... I just didn't want it to end!

I've had a handful of minor bugs, but no game-breaking ones.  The game feels very polished, in fact.

Lastly, I purchased this game because I knew it would be better than the first, but also because they removed the microtransactions.  If they hadn't, I simply wouldn't be playing it.  Hats off to WB for removing them!

Great game with crappy chunk of grind. 
Despite having a similar formula it's one of few open world games that doesn't feel like Assassin's Creed open world chore-list.

[h1]Gameplay (9/10)[/h1]
So it's an open world game. What makes it different?
[list]
[*] First of all: Nemesis/army systems. All generals are named, have personalities, strengths weakness guards and such, and YOU can exploit every single one of them by recruiting them, pitting them against each other, etc. 
It's not a complete sandbox experience, but other games only mimic in what this game achieved in gimmicky ways.
[*] Nicely balanced progression system. Progression includes levels, skill tree (unlocks/changes active abilities), equipment, gems and orcs themselves. Most of the game nicely lays out progression to trickle in and give you the feeling of growth.
[*] Action oriented combat. In some ways it's similar to Assassin's creed games, but it feels faster and more dynamic,
[*] Stealth that doesn't slow you down. Unlike in similar games I don't feel like I have to crawl everywhere to avoid getting spotted.
[*] Orcs commanders. They have 3 selling points.
[list]
[*] Orcs are proceduraly generated (?). Dialogs have personalities and don't repeat (at least not that I've seen). Dialogs are contextual, so a commander might talk about how how you failed to kill him with your headshot as he comes back.
[*] They have different combinations of traits, which keeps combat interesting. They can be of different classes, factions (which gives them skills), have relationships to other orcs, be strong or weak to specific things (including your moves).
[*] Stronger orcs serve as a great reward when you recruit them to your own army.
[/list]
[/list]

[b]What brought experience down was 2nd half grind[/b]
At first you collect your army and they are competent. Towards the end of the game you have to do it all again, and despite being the strongest troops you ever had they fold like wet paper. That means you you need re-recruit good chunks of your army several times. That last bit in particular is so drawn out and devoid of substance, I've grown to be tired of everything I loved about first half of the game.
The sheer amount of funny voiced Orcs that are in this game is honestly astounding and impressive. 10/10

This is a  very solid game, the graphics are to date, the story line and voice acting are fantastic. For those reasons alone, this is a fantastic game. Unfortunately, this is not a game that is cohesive for PC players.

I'll reduce it down to the good, the bad, the ugly.
The good:
-The story, very immersive
-Graphics are exceptional. Very good use of the engine.
-Voice acting is beyond acceptable keeping the story immersive {for the most part}
-Playability: {Oof} You'll get your money's worth out of this game
-Diversity, though most of the AI look the same, it is not a total copy/paste

The bad:
-Despite the creators' efforts of making the AI diverse, they muddy it to the point where you have to pay attention to see any diversity in artwork
-Despite their best efforts, everything becomes muddy and repetitive 
-I do understand and respect how they wanted to make every encounter unique and challenge players based on adaptability; however, most encounters are less about learning and skill and more about learning how to beat specific boss/general/chief/etc. whereas, unfortunately, it is more about learning specific sequences and then playing out repetitive motion.
-Boss/elite/legendary/chief structuring lacks in any kind of imagination, rather seem to absorb time with repetitive controls/moves
-General world AI: this game is massive; however, you can simply run past everything with no real impact or you can spend hundreds of hours fighting every single NPC, which is very immersion-breaking.

The ugly:
-Bosses that learn and leave you doing the same repetitive motion over and over again for what feels like hours 
-Learning bosses: seems like a really good idea until you have to fight one
-Controls: I'm a PC player and it's very obvious this was not created for PC. My space key is used for everything. Along the same line, the controls are janky and confusing with no option to edit {what game does not allow you to change your key binds these days?!?!} Something that is made further frustrating with the 'intelligent AI' that leads to very frustrating and tedious battles with little to no gain. {There are A LOT of these battles}.

In conclusion, I would recommend this game. It has a very immersive story, the controls suck for PC, and the developers missed the mark on intuitive AI. However, you will play this game for hours, as frustrating as they are. So I will both recommend and not recommend this game at the same time based on your gaming platform. In this game, controller is god.

I would make a long review but this game does not deserve it. The short of it is that microtransactions killed the potential of this game. Making orcs stronger means spending some time in menus and spending coins rather than training them or sending them on missions.

You're supposed to command an army but you pretty much HAVE to babysit your uruks one mission at a time. 
During a siege, SO MUCH time is spent on watching captains talk, it's unskippable. I usually would enjoy this, but literally in the middle of battle everything would stop so we can listen to them. A captain dies? cutscene. Your captain dies? cutscene. Someone farted? cutscene. It cuts the flow of battle so hard, why can't you let them talk while things are happening? Sure, gestures might be missed but the flow of the game would be 3x better.

Also, pit fights are unskippable. And infiltrating an uruk forces you to watch them... multiple times sometimes...

Yeah, I enjoyed my time, but I enjoyed it for the combat more than anything. This is a leap backwards from everything that Shadow of Mordor revolutionized and it's pathetic.

The only positive thing I have to say is that cheating death is more common, and captains will look for you. Also, double jump i neat. 

tl;dr menu hell, one man army, more of the same

Aight. 50 hours, 72/72 achievements... I think its time for a review. Im too lazy rn though so it won't be super in-depth.

Shadow of War is the sequel to Shadow of Mordor. While having similar systems and mechanics in place, such as the nemesis system, the combat, parkour, etc, Shadow of War vastly improves on all of them. 

The Gameplay.
Shadow of War has a combat system and parkour system that is very similar to the older Assassins Creed games. The combat flows very well and isn't very jank. You can tailor how you want to fight through the many different skills you can learn through the skill tree (which is vastly superior to Shadow of Mordor), and, while being simple, it's pretty difficult to master as you can easily get stomped by enemies if you don't know what you're doing. Stealth is very simple, not a core mechanic like in Assassins Creed, but its there, and it's fine. Nothing special. Parkour on the other hand is very nice. Again, nothing amazing when compared to Dying Light or Assassins creed which have a focus on parkour, but Shadow of War has a great sense of verticality and flow.

Story and Characters.
Compared to Shadow of Mordor, Shadow of War definitely puts more effort into the story as well as its characters. Its longer play time allows it to flesh out the larger cast of characters better this time (Although most of the characters are kinda sh*t), and explore the alternate version of Middle-Earth that follows Talion. I don't want to spoil the story as it is quite intriguing, but the highlight of the story is the relationship between Celebrimbor and Talion, which is constantly twisting and turning and eventually culminates into a nice climax. Story = 8/10.

The Nemesis System.
The Nemesis System is by far one of the best video game mechanics in any video game ever. What the Nemesis System does is make every small event that happens between the simple orc captains that you encounter throughout the game so much more meaningful. What you thought was a pointless orc captain you killed who had no relevance to you whatsoever, suddenly returns to life after his friends put him back together and is hunting you for revenge. Or how an orc captain taunts you after he encounters you again after defeating you the first time. Or how after to plant a spy in the enemy stronghold, some orc captains might tell you that they know you have a spy in their ranks, and will find him. It makes every encounter unique and never the same twice. 

In conclusion, Shadow of War is great game. Its characters is definitely not its strong suit, but the universe, the plot, the gameplay, the NEMESIS SYSTEM (Please put systems like it in other games) make it such a joy to play.

The gameplay is a perfect blend of action, stealth, and strategy, with a unique Nemesis System that makes every battle feel personal and memorable. The graphics are breathtaking, creating a fully-realized version of Middle-earth that looks straight out of the movies. The game's story is engaging and takes you on a journey you won't forget. The combat mechanics are fluid and satisfying, making every battle feel like a truly epic encounter. The open world nature of the game is also a plus, allowing players to explore the rich and diverse environments of Middle-earth. Overall, Middle-earth: Shadow of War is a must-play for any fans of the franchise and action-RPG enthusiasts.
Highly recommend - if you enjoyed the Arkham series, this is up your alley.

Pretty damn good game, it takes most if not all of the aspects of the previous game (Shadow of Mordor) and improves upon them significantly. Game itself is fairly long but even after you've "beaten" the game there will always be more to do due to the ridiculous amount of uruk/olog customization. Online play is limited to fortress sieges and overlord duels, and both of these have a pretty high number of cheated orcs that just curbstomp anything you have (and you.) The pit fight AI could be MUCH better, in its current state its absolutely terrible, sometimes orcs will just sit there and let themselves die and I've had multiple legendary orcs die to regular ones with significantly lower levels. The lore is based off the LOTR, and it takes a lot of creative freedoms but other than some things that don't make sense (haradrim captain of gondor) but it stays fairly true to the lore and doesn't try to be something else entirely which is respectable. Overall a pretty good game 8/10.

Writing this review after the end of Act 3, very minor spoilers could be deducted, but trying to keep my keyboard shut. Haven't been in online conquests, haven't started lvl 80 grind yet, I had just finished the main story missions, I am lvl 49. All things considered, I think ideally the story should be finished between lvl 30 and 40. (of course this depends on your difficulty, playstyle, how challenging you want it, etc.)

I have two grudges against the game:
1) defenders and Ologs have some annoying, non-counterable (but in theory, dodgeable) attacks and sometimes there are just too many of them, and can get you in a stun-lock, which doesn't really play as fun
2) sometimes movement control and free-running is wonky, I got stuck in a tower, on a staircase, or little objects that should just be walkable.

These two combined could cause some frustration.

Otherwise, good game with quite a lot of content. Don't listen to those who berate the story, it's actually pretty good (nothing mind-blowingly amazing, but it is good). Orc captain personalities can result in pretty funny/epic/weird-in-a-positive-way moments. But after 20 hours, listening to every captain introducing themselves and taunting Talion after he conquered half of Mordor and slain armies... when player knows they will be 2-hit kill... it gets boring. There should be a level-difference like 15 or 20 when captains just keep their mouths shut.

Devs pulled off open-world pretty well, with separate regions, but collecting 3 different types of items/puzzles could have been a bit more motivating.

Back to the story, during Act 2, the personality of Celebrimbor starts soaking through, main characters' and most of the captains' voice acting, dialogs are good (some of these scratch awesomeness). However, multiple quest lines and separate freedom in leveling results in inconsistency. For example, fighting a battle that supposed to be epic and hard and a challenge, I found myself butchering captains 20 levels below me... You have to find a balance between leveling, free-roaming, sidequesting and doing main quests to maintain a sense of difficulty and variety, because the game won't hold your hands after act 1/lvl 20. There are some minor requirements, but only so much that keep the world consistent, or locked until you have a certain skill unlocked.

I only encountered one game-breaking bug, a specific captain always went to a ghul hunt, reward was +0 XP and when I decided to join him, the game entered a never-ending loading screen. Otherwise, the game is stable, load times are good. Auto-save is brilliant, never had to rollback any progress.
