I loved the first game, I really enjoyed this one too, even though there were a lot of annoying stuff. I didn't touch the online stuff, just the story and really enjoyed taking fortresses, making ennemies out of certains orks, but farming stuff and leveling my warchiefs was not part of my objective.

The first problem is the inability to aim what you want to aim. To many times you get to hit something that you are not facing, even sometimes in your back. It's a real shame and demonstrate the low quality port of the game to PC, since it should be perfect with a mouse and keyboard. You cannot have a combo system with that kind of problem, you end up losing your hit streak and taking a hit because you wanted to hit a common ork and get countered against an ennemy that you are not allowed to hit in the front.

This issue was also pretty annoying with the parkour system, you would get to do stupid stuff. The worst is probably that some places were bugged and you couldn't climb them and you can't even jump horizontaly. I got stuck on small platforms which was pretty ridiculous.

Other problem: the cutscenes with ork captains taunting you at the beginning of a fight is pretty cool, but when you get to fight 3 or 4 of them, it's interrupts the action too much. Sometimes, at the end of the cutscene, you get some hits in your face because you didn't have control and sometimes you can even see the tooltips of ennemy attacks for you to counter. I have spent some fights with more than 2 minutes cutscenes again and again, 10 secondes fight, 15 seconds cutscene, and it goes on when a captain flees or get executed, so you potentialy get 10 cutscenes in a single 3 minutes fight, which was kind of annoying.

Last issue was with the camera: never fight close to a wall as you will not a thing and you won't even see ennemies attacking you. It's sad because it's a very common issue in games nowadays that should not exist in a AAA game.


I'm only highlighting the problems, but I had a good time overall. This game can be pretty unnerving sometimes, especially during the toughest fights.
It was an improvement to the last game which I was loving aswell, more in the game and would recommend to other players
Do you like open world games? Do you like Lord of the Rings? Need more orks in your life? 'nuff said, game is good.

Well this is a hard recommendation. 

After the Shadow of Mordor, this game's story is child-play. That one was the first entrance to this glorious world with nice revenge plot that also gives you some different explanation on the rings' creation. The Shadow of War's story is almost non-existent when you compare it with that. Almost nothing to remember.

Initial reason to come to Shadow of Mordor was to taste the atmosphere of Middle-Earth. SoW has more of it. A lot more of it. To the degree of tediousness and repeating and grinding over and over. 

Nemesis System is really nice, still really nice. Maybe there are some upgrades from SoM, but it's been some time I played SoM, so not really sure about it. But it is really enjoyable for firts 1-2 forts. Then it turns into a chore. 

Listening to every single Orc Captain to talk is outright annoying. I don't care about any of them, why do I need to listen their insults without being able to skip it. I mean, Bright Lord, one who brings Mordor to its knees, is unable to shut the haters up and have to listen to their garbage. Unbelievable. 

And since there is so much of grinding, these kind of (normally) small annoyances, become big issues. Like when a Captain gets Enraged/Terrified you gotta focus on them and watch. Totally destroys the fluidity of the gameplay.

I loved the Fight Pits though. Each Captain with their own strengths/weaknesses and you just throw them in to fight with each other, yours win, they level up, enemy win, you just dominate them to have even better army. Tediousness aside, it was really fun to participate in them. Good management side-game. 

I think the collectible amount was just right, and most of them was somehow relevant, not too far from where you would go, and with a in-game mini-game to locate them easily. 

Overall, it's worth the play, but feels like more of the same.

A great sequels and conclusion of Shadow of "Mordor/War" series. The game definitely powered up in nemesis system, worlds, hierarchy, orcs personalities and war/defense system. Underrated games at the time that should be more bigger than it should.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
+ A great upgrades from Shadow of Mordor in every aspect
+ Graphics isn't the best but not heavy enough for my PC so it can run 60fps in medium settings
+ Nemesis System upgraded greatly, more challenge, more scenarios, more personality, more consequences, more challenge
+ Armor upgrades while the looks mostly repetitive, the skills with it is different and sometimes its fun to mix & match certain items to kill a captain
+ Online Invasion of other players orcs sometimes annoying but challenging. My lvl 30 talion invaded with lvl 60 Ologs one time and I almost died multiple times. But the reward killing them is truly satisfying lol.
+ Online defense/Raid is also fun. Sometimes I imagined how bad My own fortress againts other player that clearly more skilled than me lol.
+ The DLC of Eltariel and Baranor is worth it. But I hoped it was longer and had much depths. They played differently than Talion especially Baranor. I feel like Batman lol

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
- The annoying Elves running that we must keep pressing spacebar and lost focus is annoying, why we can't have horse or truly owned Caragors? Don't forget this game isnt like Assassins Creed that certain boulder/walls/etc. Isn't climbable and suddenly stop you from running, no falling down or jumping to parkour back. Theres obvious gap between 2 boulders or craters that we can shoot or jump but the game just wont let you do it. The Parkour still pale againt's AC series capability lol.
- Those Wraith moves sometimes get you stuck on walls, halting us from progress killing warchiefs/captains/take over outposts. Thankfully you can escape with fast travel and can resume the attacks while not restarting the missions before.
- Sneak almost doesn't mean anything later in game, they dealt barely any damages except the captain is mortal/instant kill with it and many orcs valiant againts stealth. Almost entire orcs has it after I conquer 2nd city. So focusing on executions, wraith wrath, elemental supershot is better than stealth
- Bodyguard Orcs isn't useful at all except for Eltariel DLC. Bodyguards ended up death and makes me wasting my time upgrading them, especially in Baranor DLC human bodyguard is the worst. Don't bother invest in them except for guarding outpost or filling certain spots that seems dangerous.
- The captain upgrades in the game is either help them fight creatures, vs other captains, vs other captains in arena, or spend the upgrades coins in the "former lootbox" menu. The upgrades also annoying we must hold enter for 5 seconds and watching they gloried each time, such a long progress and annoying we can only upgrade 5 level each while we are in lvl 80 and visiting our 1st taken city with lvl 20 ish captains. 
- The only gears that matter to upgrade is the rare ones, the only good loking also the rare ones. Why bother upgrading and getting the epic/legendary? Except for coins only??
- This is personal, [spoiler]but I hated how the story ends. Like what happen in SoM and first half of SoW doesnt matter. Switching from Talion to Eltariel who is introduced shallowly in the story is a bad move, i hated Celebrimbor now. The end of Talion story he just turned evil and hollow as nazgul. The end he freed bcs of the hobbits. It felt "Middle Earth Shadow of" series doesnt matter at all. I know this isnt canon but I just felt sad to Talion.[/spoiler]

I hoped Nemesis system in this game return to other games, rumor said [strike]Gotham Knights[/strike] (Well they F*ck it up ladies and gentlemen) or Suicide Squads will implement this system. But I really hoped they don't botch it. Recommended game...

One of the best games I've played, a one up from Shadow of Mordor. The lore is a bit wonky and Tolkien would be horrified but the humour is great and the gameplay is nothing revolutionary, but still quite enjoyable when you lead an army into war. The nemesis system is one of the best gameplay aspects I have genuinely seen in all of gaming, you can kill some orc and there is a chance he turns even more powerful and keeps coming back hellbent on revenge. Each orc on your first playthrough is their own unique character in the story and the dialogue is insanely entertaining when you first hear it, even multiple playthroughs later I still get new dialogue because of how many combinations there is to encounter, I could not encourage you enough to give Shadow of War a go when it's on sale, even if you don't care for the story the gameplay makes up for it.

I'm so burnt out on this title. This game is insanely repetitive. It ended up feeling like a chore and not any fun. 60 hours sunk in and I have a region to 100%, otherwise the content is pretty wrapped up but wow, that got rapidly boring. Weirdly, the amount of nonsense, menial tasks crowded the story so I can't recall much about it. I'm tired of playing it. The first one was way better but I can't diss Lord of the Rings content. . .

Fantastic game! If you enjoyed the first you will undoubtedly enjoy this one. Game play loop is very good. The refined nemesis system makes every encounter feel somewhat fresh. The combat is very easy to learn and very fulfilling. Its kinda like a Pokemon game at some points. You can dominate other enemies and send them to a do vast variety of things. My only negatives are, 1 the low quality gear improvement system and the 1 dimensional end game. I would give this game an easy 9/10 one of the best games I've played in the past 5 years.

Like numerous WB games, there's a LOT to be said about it. Not just from the content, but also the press surrounding it, how it went in heavily on microtransactions and even has a Orc Merchant character who smirks and cheers whenever you spend money to get random Orcs in these lootboxes.

This has been changed and gutted, but it's clear that this game was built with that in mind from the very beginning as all Orcs and Equipment have a rarity value that plays exactly like mobile games and MMOs (Commons, rares, epics, legendaries being the highest) making it a fact that cannot be ignored as it permeates every part of this game. That said, let's talk about the gameplay.

All I really have to say about storyline and gameplay is that if you enjoyed the first game, then you'll certainly enjoy this one. Especially in it's current state and not how it used to be prevalent with micro-transaction filth. Now it's a far better game, though flaws have been cleaned up too. However you also still have things like daily challenges and ect that remind you of it's failed attempt to be a full-priced game that was lousy with Micro-transactions.

The story essentially continuing the fight and battle from the first game, but then getting wiped out by the Dark Lord and having to start over. Interesting idea, however the only issue I have with this is you don't start with the ability to dominate Orcs and we all know that's one of the most fun bits of this game is dominating and controlling legions of Orcs. There's even a mechanic later of bringing them back from the dead to be zombies that are under your control!

With many side-missions to keep you entertained for hours, one of the things I hated using was the fighting pit. You have no control over your Orc as they fight a different orc and even if yours is a Legendary that you've leveled up, improved their abilities and more, they can still be defeated by a Common at half it's level making you curse the fighting pits and just getting on with the far more interesting side-missions like collecting artefacts, uncovering the past or finding Shelob's fragments that are scattered throughout the world and give you a look in her role for the rise of the dark lord.

Shelob has the ability to turn into a sexy woman, because, it's not like that's been done a billion times before! Though I admit she did have the voice of the very sexy Claudia Black so I also would like to give it a pass too. You get an ability to summon spiders if you find all of them, but it's a shame that the spiders come in only one size catagory and you can't, for example, have a Caragor-sized spider to charge around on, but that's a minor thing and it's especially fun when you're hunting a captain who is terrified of spiders so you immediately break him.

Without giving spoilers, the ending is certainly an interesting one and gives you a reason to come back and keep playing it and in a way that fits the narrative of the story, even giving you new powers and abilities to try out.

The game currently comes on sale quite often so if you're interested in more Shadow of Mordor, then certainly go ahead. If you want a fun action game then this is certainly fun and worth the price it often is on sale. Especially if you can get all the DLC to mess with extra characters and stories.

ME(tm): SoW(tm) is a fantastic game to play.

Ironic for a game set in the magnificently written Lord of the Rings universe, the story is that of Gondorian football jock / family man Tallion and the elf equivalent of Walter White. That is all you need to know, or ever will care to know. 

Sometimes the spider lady with the voice of Reverb makes her jiggly appearance with very high cheekbones, to say something incomprehensible. You will also frequently be joined by Mean Girl Elf 1 and 2. They are indistinguishable. 

As long as you repeatedly make your best Calibrimbor voice impression of, "Tallion, we need to cook," every time you respawn, the story is perfectly adequate to ignore as you wreck Orc lives.

And wreck Orc lives you will, because they are the most enjoyable part of this game. Nemesis System is cool as hell. 

Every time you get killed by one of these ugly knobs, they level up and remember you. Every fun thing you do in this game will revolve around this. Either capturing them as you endure the main quest to get the Domination ability, or roaring in annoyance that your Drain ability no longer gives you elf shot when you drain, making that awesome Shadow Whatever ability jump you across the map and up the ass of some archer to recharge the 2 elf shot this cool ninja elf bullshit uses to murder them all. If you cold use Drain and Dominate, all my complaints about this game would end there.

The powers are very fun used in combination with each other, and the weapons all have cool synergies as well. Getting a sword that does fire damage on crits, and a hood that  that doubles crits, and another armor that doubles fire damage, is awesome. 

It is a roaring good time, total entertainment, very fun gameplay. 

8/10 only because the story is ironically passable for such a legendary franchise from one of the 20th Century's greatest minds and a cultural treasure. The only lasting narrative legacy I will hold from this game is that Hammer Elf is selling Elf Meth in those Rings, and no one can take that from me. 

Also, fuck the Orc Hoggrief in particular. Motherfucker was level 50 when I was 30 and haunted me across Middle Earth like a disease. I had to beat him, barely, after dying half a dozen times, shaming him into total slobbering madness before he was finally able to be dominated. 

Hilarious, and I will never forget it. 10/10 just for that, would be Man Swine again.

Let me tell you a story of a quest for revenge. TL:DR at the end.

[b] One man army [/b]

I was dicking around in  Cirith Ungol, brutalizing orcs, blowing up barrels of grog, you know the fun stuff. It was going fine until I stumbled across a  trap mission for a warchief and I fully believed that I was capable enough to kill this warchief. So I  accepted it and went to kill Ghash the Merciful (mind you I did not gather Intel for this) I infiltrated his fort and went to activate the trap. It activated and we started to fight. It was a standard fight for me, until I start to  mess up my attacks. He was able to get the best of me and instead of  striking me down, he outright humiliated me. I got up and  continued to fight In the middle of this, I get ambushed by a Orc captain that I forgot the name of, so we will refer to him as Olaf. He kept diverting my attention to him as I tried to kill of Ghash. He,again, got the best of me and humiliated me.

I continued to fight Olaf and Ghash, when another Captain called Shaka the glory hunter ambushed me. These 3 were just  too much for me and for the last time I got bested. But not by a captain, but by a random grunt. This grunt was called Krakhorn, and after ending my life, he gives himself the nickname of Krakhorn the Tark Slayer and was promoted to captain. The other 3 also got leveled up and I truly wasn't going to let that slide. So I began hunting. But before I did that I got alot of intel from worms, even for unknown captains

[b] Confused Climbing [/b]

My first target was Olaf as he was the closest. He was situated in a high platform in some mining quarry and thought this would be a piece of cake.

It was not.

My blind ass just attempted to bullshit ways up to that high platform. I tried to jump my way across, I climbed  structures not even remotely connected to the high platform. Not to mention that I kept missing jumps and keep falling to the bottom.  On one of these climbs I found one of the random unknown captains I gained intel for, Flargo (that was not his name but i forgot it) the fire hawk. His attacks were fire based but weirdly was mortally wounded by fire attacks. I made short work of him and continued my climb. After many attempts , I finally made it all the way to the platform where I find Olaf. It was just me and him. 

A EPIC BATTLE THAT WIL- Nah I am just kidding I made quick work of him. I jumped all the way down and went to my next hunt.

[b] Payback [/b]

My next target was Krakhorn the Tark Slayer, the random grunt who killed me. He was meeting with another orc captain, Golm the inscrutable. I went to gain intel from a worm for Golm where I learn that he was mortally afraid by stealth attacks, so I was able to make him run away when I attack Krakhorn. I attack Golm, making him run away, leaving only me and Krakhorn. He was admittedly another easy fight, only taking a few minutes to fight. As I was leaving the area to fight Shaka, I get ambushed by a orc captain, Shag the gambler.

I already knew Shag, I sent a death threat to him and intended to deal with him later once I am finished. I guess he wanted to deal with me. He was a much harder fight than Krakhorn. As I almost got the best of him, he started to flee. I wasn't going to let him go now. I made chase after him. We rush through armies of orcs, each trying  to kill me as I elven ran towards him and was able to shoot him down, shagging shag with a arrow.

[b] DEJA VU [/b]

Shaka was situated in the same fort where I got killed at , so I know the area already. I was ready to end the Glory hunter...

...UNTIL I got ambushed by the weirdest captain I have met, Bagga the Bard. He introduced him with a SONG, A F#$%ING  SONG. I was not able to land hits due to him being a trickster type. So I skedaddled out of there and went to find a worm. Turns out I already had intel on this idiot. He was mortally wounded by stealth attacks, so thats what I did. I stealth killed him and got rid of my least favourite captain.

Anywho, I found Shaka in the middle of the same place the last I saw him and start to fight him. My fight against him was way easier due to the lack of captains. As I ended Shaka, I got ambushed by Maku the crazy, just like last time. Although Maku was relatively a low level to me, so I killed him easily.

Now time to find Ghash

[b] Last ditch attempt [/b]

I screwed up. 

I was in the search area when I truly got ambushed by a captain,Ur Lisak the Herald. No seriously, he just randomly attacked me before he introduced himself. He was a olog so I had a difficult time killing him. So I went to find a worm to find some intel. He was mortally wounded by stealth attacks, so I had to get out of enemy sight to silently kill him. While I was doing this, I got out of the mission area, which failed me, making Ghash nowhere to be found. I killed Ur Lisak and attempt to find Ghash in the area, which led to nothing. 

I had seemingly failed my revenge, until I notice the bodyguard system. With Ghash being a warchief, a orc captain was his bodyguard. Flak tasty (what kinda name is that!?). So I hunted him down, in hopes of finding Ghash when I found him. I did not find Ghash, I just killed a captain for nothing.

So in defeat, I did the unthinkable, I did a story quest. In this quest, I found out the actual function of the bodyguard system and was able to kill another captain, Koth the Chop. When I finished this mission, I got a new trap mission thinking that this will bring me to the warchief that Koth was protecting.

I read his name and it was....... GHASH THE MERCIFUL?

[b] The alpha [/b]

Blah blah, I got ambushed by a orc captain and I holocaust'd him.

As I went to activate the trap mission,  ANOTHER captain ambushed me, Ronk the fearless. I ran away from him, with the intent of locating a worm to find a weakness. He was heavily damaged by stealth, is what i gain from the intel. When I attacked him, I mistakenly started the trap mission, which brought Ghash out. So  now, I fought against a Orc warchief, a orc captain and was surrounded by multiple orcs. I caused Ronk to become enraged, which in turn made Ghash enrage as he was bloodlusted. With these two being enraged, they started to fight. And when I was just so close on killing Ghash, Ronk took my glory and stole my kill. He then shortly after that, killed me.

I was enraged, I wasted so long just to get my revenge for only a random orc captain to steal it from me and kill me.

I wasn't going to let that slide.

[b] Finale [/b]

I will cut to the chase.

I am pursuing Ronk through Cirith Ungol, where he led me to a attack. I called in reinforcements which led them to killing the enemies there, but also led to their demise. Leaving only me and Ronk to duke it out.
As I mentioned before, Ronk was a savage, a enemy I had difficulty dealing with, which only made the fight harder. He was also a tank, which made any hit less. But I was too determined to lose, and after 5 minutes, I was able to  get Ronk down, who in turn DEATH DEFY ME and we continue to fight. He was able to counter my vaults now, which only made the fight way harder.

But finally, as I land the final blow, he begs for death, he  yearns for me to kill him, and since I was in act one, that is what I gave him. I amputated his arms and pinned him down with my sword. My revenge, although incomplete, is fulfilled.

The auto-generated cutscenes are cancer and they interrupt the gameplay basically every 30 seconds even if you aren't dying. I've seen some people speak positively about them but personally I cannot fathom how you would get any enjoyment out of your game getting interrupted every 2 minutes to watch an orc dance back and forth for a full fucking minute. I'd almost find it less offensive if they just replaced it with ads because then at least someone would be making money off of it. As it stands right now it's literally just a waste of life. 

Even disregarding that, movement is super clunky and there's a huge delay between when you hit the W key and when your character moves even if you're running at 60 fps. Random terrain items will randomly block you and you can't jump over them. It's a decent game but there's a lot of very basic shit that would greatly improve the gameplay. I give it a 3/10 with potential to hit 7.5/10 if they give a toggle option to remove cutscenes and made the movement more responsive.

EDIT: After playing more, I feel even more vindicated. Absolute waste of a game. This shit could have been so good and they absolutely butchered it.

Shadow of War is one of the better games I've played. It's combat progresses well, doesn't make you feel weak, also doesn't make you feel invincible. It's hard to tell which shines more, the story or the gameplay, but both are great. If you're even remotely a fan of LoTR, get this game, you can't possibly dislike it. Repetitive, boring, and clunky.

It's pretty fun, there are alot of notable glitches. Even in the cutscenes. 

It's one of those games where the same button does different things for areas so you gotta understand where you are in the situation to do something.

Don't let my playtime deceive you, I've played this game on PS4 before succumbing to the master race. 
With that out of the way  can tell you if you like unique games as well as fighting games this might just be up your alley. Even if you're not familiar with LOTR and even if - like me - you didn't like the first entry. 
Actually the story isn't all that important. It's not boring or anything but you'll spend the most time raising an orc army by fighting orcs, shaming orcs, dominating orcs and listening to the unique dialogue of orcs. So while your protagonist is as serious as they come you will notice rather quickly that this game is a loveletter to lighthearted carnage. The combat doesn't get too repetitive because there's countless combinations of traits the orcs can possibly have and because each foe has unique attire and dialogue (at least the named ones which any single orc can become by killing you). You will meet familiar faces between playthroughs but during one run surprisingly little gets ever reused.
One last thing I want to tell you is you should really consider playing the game on normal difficulty or above. I don't usually seek a challenge with these types of games but in this case you're really missing out on a lot of content if you never die.

Okay.

The game mechanics are ambitious and I've been really enjoying it. However, the mechanics are ambitious and game play is often quirky as a result. 

Playing on higher difficulty is incredibly frustrating because of how quirky the mechanics are. You might just die during a siege because the game has decided you wanted to jump over a grunt into a landmine...

Even though it's an RPG, it doesn't have many of the RPG elements you would expect from a game of this era. The elements it does have are shallow in comparison to it's competition. However, it shines as an action game. They give you an absolutely CHONKY tool belt with which you can obliterate every Uruk you see. This plays way more like Arkham Knight than it does The Witcher.

Highly recommend it at a discount. I'd be upset if I paid full price. There are certainly way better games than this.
Awesome game, very well made.  I should have got it earlier.  Probably would have if not for the reviews. I'm not to end game yet but so far i really like it.  Assassins creed LOTR.

Lots of things to like in this game, the orcs are hilarious and varied, Shelob is simultaneously good-looking and spooky AF (in a fun way), and there's a LOT of variety between the many captain/boss fights where you have to use different approaches for each fight. All of that makes for many fun hours of play with minimal grinding. Other reviews covered these positives better than I can, so I'll leave it at that. 

The only major negatives are (a) the controls and the tremendous lag that go with them and (b) many many crashes, some causing BSOD's on Win 10.

(a) Controls - I played on nemesis difficulty with KB+M and the controls were infuriatingly sluggish and muddled - sometimes Talion is just standing there and still takes a while to respond to inputs, IDK why. What's worse is the context-specific controls where the same key/button has different functions. So e.g. <SPACE> can be either jump, dodge, or run (instead of the default walk). Imagine trying to dodge/run near a wall and the game decides you meant to jump onto it. Or trying to jump onto a wall and the game decides you were trying to run/dodge into it. 🤦‍♂️ Now imagine all this happening hundreds, if not thousands of times over the course of the entire game during various fights. Plus the camera gets messed up near walls, it stays loosely focused from the wall behind Talion onto the enemies in front of him so you can't even see him while he's getting pummeled. Yeah, you get the idea. Not fun.

(b) Crashes - Long story short, verified game file integrity many times through the Steam app but it never showed any issues. I finally reduced the crashes to a manageable amount by turning down some graphics settings and closing all other background apps while playing the game. Though it doesn't make sense why higher graphics settings should cause Nvidia driver crashes (1080 Ti + Windows 10 22H2 + 10th Gen i5 + 32 GB RAM) and BSODs, at worst it should just reduce the frame rate. The reason why I think it's a game issue and not my system is the crashes/hangs always happened while loading the next level/area or cutscene. Never during actual gameplay. If it was an issue with my system, the game would've crashed while actually playing, during a graphics/CPU intensive scene. Also, nothing like this happened with any other game I've played on this system, some of those games being newer and//or more demanding.

Overall, I'd rate this game an 8/10. It's a pity, because it would have easily been a 9.5+ if it wasn't for the above and would've qualified as one of my favorite games of all time - the rest of the gameplay is a whole lot of fun.

These Middle-Earth games are not canon and even some of the lore of the game contradicts the real lore of the real Middle-Earth, but man I love the games. I think even with them being wrong about several things, they're still great and I love the stories they do tell. Like Shelob, I love her story in Shadow of war. It's tragic and amazing. Then there's Baranor, his story is amazing and the ending of his story is just great and a true sibling thing. But even with the wrong lore it's just great games and I love the stories it does tell. All around I highly recommend this game it's addicting

This is one fantastic orc-shooter! The graphics are absolutely stunning, and the character movement is almost photographically lifelike. The "Nemesis" foe management process is interesting and adds an element of development for the opponents. Although it is a "Middle Earth" game, the association with the Lord of the Rings is very tenuous and feels almost gratuitous. So, even though Gollum does appear for a few scenes, don't be looking for your favorite LOTR references. But that's OK - the action of the game is snappy and the combat is not at all contrived or awkward. The ONLY shortcoming that I would mention is the lack of a story line with any depth. This results in the game ending with no real sense of glory at the denouement. But, do not despair. This is a hack-and-slash royale and, well, you get to kill some orcs. A LOT of orcs. In a world of phenomenal artistry and believable physics. This one is worth every penny!

Update: This is one of the best games i have played, it DOES take some getting used to though. But once you get past that barrier, it's absolutely phenomenal. The old review outlines why, and it is still very difficult, but i have learned to accept it, and infact, love it.

old review: [strike] I'll start off by addressing the fact that they improved most systems across the board compared to the first game. Combat feels more lively, the healing system is better, the way you fight monsters is vastly improved, they added big orcs which are awesome to fight.

I feel like all of this is ruined by how the new nemesis system works. In some areas, it is way better, being overall more dynamic with them having more personalities and generally feeling much more interesting, but what really ruins it for me is the difficulty of some of them. 

They adapt to most of your moves over time, which can make some fights outright impossible (e.g defender getting immune to your stun + vault), and then i'd think "Well let's try stealth", but for some reason, they can wind up randomly disappearing, or i guess running away, but it never prompted that so i was just left confused and annoyed at the fact that i spent 5 minutes fighting someone, only for them to run away when i made a quick "tactical retreat". 

I am sure i just need to get better at the game, but i have had many, many moments where i thought "Why did that happen? Why is this happening?", a good example of that are ranged enemies, especially a ranged nemesis. they can do SO much damage, hit very accurately, and fire quite fast. Sure i could go in and fight them up close, but then there's some random orc that fires off a horn, and then i am absolutely surrounded by enemies, meaning i can only go around and hide, weirdly taking out the horde slowly, making it a tedious, slow fight.

Again, i could just suck, but i have had way too much frustration to warrant playing it any further, and so i also decided to leave this review. [/strike]

Much, much worse than the first game.

The game is so boring that I couldn't bring myself to finish it. Eighty percent of the missions are the same - go somewhere, kill the orcs, then kill the captain, the end. Over and over again. Everything repeats ad nausea. The mandatory siege missions are what broke me. Kill warlord, kill warlord, kill warlord, kill warlord, kill overlord, repeat five times. And after capturing all the fortresses, you have to go through about 20 defensive missions to reach the end. The grind is insane. The worst Ubisoft games don't compare to this.

They've added loot this time, and it's the most boring action RPG loot you can imagine. 95% of what you find is garbage. But you still have to go to the menus every 10 minutes and check and disassemble items.

Managing your army is another chore you have to do, and again it's just clicking through menus. Like a crappy football management simulator.

Even the leveling is broken. At 30% into the game I unlocked all the skills and perks I wanted and from then on it was just a matter of unlocking perks I didn't want to use (because each skill has multiple perks, but you can only have one active).

And the orc speeches. Oh god. They constantly interrupt the gameplay. You just want to fight, but the game is interrupted by every orc captain telling you their life story in an UNSKIPPABLE cutscene. They just talk and talk and never have anything interesting to say, it's just taunts and threats. Sometimes there are like five captains in a fight and it takes more than a minute to get through all the speeches. Just let me play the damn game!

This game brings a direct improvement to the first game's formula. If you liked the first one, it's hard to go wrong with the second. If you haven't played the first game, you can still play this game first. I'd only caution that it's hard to go back to the first once you play the second, as there's a lot more features in the second that make it a complete experience.

Edit: While I still recommend this game, I do have to put forth the caution that the online experience has degraded with time. Once you reach a certain level in the ranks of online conquest, there's nothing but scumbag cheaters clogging the ranked fortresses with their cheated orcs. It took 110 hours of gameplay for me to reach the point where they were all that I was facing, so there's some good gameplay in this game. I'm just throwing this up because its always very sad to see a dev completely neglect to remove obvious cheaters. 

If you're one of the scumbags that run cheated orcs in your fortresses, I wish you all the pain, misfortune, and misery that's coming your way. Rest assured, it's coming.

Overall score; 8/10

This review is only about the base game, expansion reviews I've written on the dedicated DLC pages

Overall this is a great all-round fun experience. That really shines through innovative gameplay and despite being an open world game a very focused gameplay vision. Where the devs manage to keep gameplay fresh and find new ways to freshen up the experience the deeper into the game you get so that it doesn't become a repetitive boring slog.

In terms of story, there is a solid story that definitely helps hold the experience together and give you reasons for what you are doing in the game. Perhaps the best part about the story are the flashback scenes which tell a bit more about the origins of the rings of power and how the different Nazgul came to acquire them and become Nazgul. What is particularly interesting here is if you contrast this with how the Amazon series shows the creation of the Rings of Power and the deception by Sauron vs how this game shows it in the flashbacks. This game does a much much better job of it. Neither are canon anyway so it is a fair comparison and this is substantially lower budget production than the billion dollar production of Amazon's Rings of Power. The writers on this game did a much better job telling the same exact story and just seeing glimpses of it makes me really sad to see what could have been had better writers done the Amazon series.

The Rings of Power flashbacks aside, in the Lord of the Rings movies the Nazgul beyond the Witch King all come across as one and the same. But in the game they've done well to make each Nazgul be unique, have their own identity and associated flashbacks to show their brief origin story so-to-speak. Additionally, it was also a great creative idea to make Shelob be such an important character and I actually prefer their creative vision about Shelob over the canon version of Shelob by Tolkien. That's no small achievement! Few writers can top canon.

Gameplay wise a lot of improvements have been made since the first Middle-Earth Shadow of Mordor game. There is a large skill tree with options to pick from to really make Talion fight in your preferred playstyle and if that's not enough you have legendary gear sets to find and acquire that give you unique new passive abilities to further focus on a unique playstyles that suits you. This is a great addition to the game and I wish more open world RPG's had these kind of stuff that build towards making your character a completely different beast towards the end-game. In my case I love to use beasts to kill orcs and thus I went for the the legendary gear set that combined with my skill tree selection lets me instantly tame any beast in the game even drakes!

Speaking of end-game gear sets.... Another brilliant thing this game does that I've actually never seen any other games do is despite being open world they use story acts that kind of change and evolve the world with the story as it progresses but also lets them change up the gameplay by having stuff happen to your character that then gives you new abilities or even swaps out entire ability sets. I won't spoil it but the end-game in this game is perhaps one of the best I've ever seen in any open world game.

The music is great, the sound design is visceral, the visuals are stunning with highly detailed high resolution graphics (especially thanks to the 4K free texture DLC pack). The game is well optimised and on my i9 9900K + RTX 2080 running the game maxed out at 1440p I had a smooth FPS ranging between 100 to 140 FPS with few to no dips under the 100 FPS.

Voice acting is very well done with professional A+++ tier voice actors who are famous for their other voice acting works across multiple games and animated series and movies. I can't even imagine how much voice acting was done for this game as with the nemesis system of the orcs I never once encountered the same voice or same voice line multiple times. Each orc captain has multiple voice lines all seemingly done by different voice actors (with some possibly done by the same voice actor but doing a different voice so you don't recognise it as the same voice actor).

The nemesis system continues to be a great innovation and I love how the system reacts to how you are playing it. I was hunting collectibles for a bit and kept running away from fights using elven speed. After running away from 3 captains I suddenly got ambushed while sprinting away by an captain who commented on the fact I love to run away from fights and he won't let me run away anymore. That was quite the surprise.

I've had similar things happen where I kept opening on orc Captains with stealth attacks (if they were vulnerable to it) and then while sneaking around an orc base I suddenly got ambushed by a captain commenting on the fact I love to sneak around.

Other ambushes seem to be more random based and just happen based on time or other triggers in the nemesis system, but overall this reaction to how you play is great. Especially when a captain adapts to you using the same combat abilities too much. Be it executions, counters, jumping over them etc.... Do that too much and they adapt and you can no longer do that to them.

The game gives you a fair fighting chance though through your powerful abilities combined with a summonable mount and bodyguard. If you manage to recruit a powerful orc captain and turn him in your bodyguard it can really make a big difference in the fights as unlike other games, in Shadow of War NPCs you recruit remain as powerful as they were when you fought them. I wish more games did this.

I should mention that the game does still have a few bugs left after all these years that were never patched out. One recurring issue I had is that nemesis missions kept bugging out on me. So if I entered the mission as soon as I would move the mission would automatically fail. Not game breaking but definitely a bit of a frustration. I had a few other bugs here and there.

While I've reviewed the two DLC on their appropriate Steam pages, I will say that the DLC are very good and very innovative offering completely different gameplay from what the base game offers. I thoroughly enjoyed the DLCs for this game.

Highly recommend this game, especially if you are a fan of games like Witcher, Assassin's Creed, God of War, etc... then you will probably love this game as well. I would say to play the first game first, Shadow of Mordor. But even if you haven't this game remains fun and enjoyable. It is worth noting that Shadow of War is substantially better than Shadow of Mordor.

The nemesis system is brilliant. Although the start is a bit of a slow burn once things and heads starts rolling the game will keep you entertained for hours. I love that enemies have personality and coming across them is always fun. The collectable isnt annoying to get and the Online vendetta system adds a nice cherry ontop of an already beautifully done cake. 
Plus who doesnt like taking apart your enemies limb by limb.

If you enjoyed Witcher 3 or Assassin's Creed, you will probably get some kicks from this title. However, while the mechanics of gameplay are similar, the gameplay loop itself is very different. You will spend the majority of your time hunting down orcs to recruit, helping them level up, customizing them with training orders, growing your army, laying siege to fortresses and outposts, and eventually defending them. As you grow in power, you will become an unstoppable nightmare, and only the most stacked captains will provide a modicum of challenge. This definitely feels intentional. If you're like me, you'll enjoy collecting orcs like Pokemon and seeking captains with cool looks or strange/interesting/funny dialogue.

War feels like a coalescence of everything Mordor was trying to do. The combat is more satisfying, movement is freer, the world is much larger, and the nemesis system has more depth. There are plenty of challenges to complete, collectibles to gather, and abilities to experiment with. I would absolutely recommend this game on sale to any fan of high fantasy action RPGs and I could easily understand why someone would spend hundreds of hours in it. My only real complaint is that I found the storytelling lackluster.
I like this game maybe a lil too much. Definitely a 10/10 i freaking love it. Runs super smooth on my GTX 1060 :)

shadow of war is a great game and (in my opinion) is the true successor to its first game, shadow of mordor. most of the negative reviews about this game are years out of date and almost all of the issues have been patched or fixed. btw while my playtime says only ten hours (as of right now) i have completely beaten the game on another platform. now, lets start with the positives 
 
the regions in this game are a lot better than the first ones. the first game had two regions and they both felt  gray, boring, and empty. the second game has five regions, plus one more that requires the Desolation of mordor dlc to play. the regions are more colorful, have more unique areas, and are generally better. 

the combat system is mostly the same as the first games one, and while there are some new abilities that improve the gameplay slightly, its nothing too huge  

this game implements lots of new mechanics, like seigeing fortresses, putting dominated orcs against enemies in the fight pits, and the nemesis system which is what the game is known for, has been improved upon. each interaction with an orc captain changes what will happen the next time you meet with them. if you kill a captain they could come back to life. if you dominate a captain, they could betray you. theres lots of possibilities. dont forget that theres a new enemy called olog hai, basically big trolls twice the size of normal uruk captains. 

the story is pretty good, and feels satisfying when you finally beat it. its pretty long, and in the epilogue at the end of the game, issues have been fixed. ive heard that the epilogue used to take hours of constant, boring grinding to beat, but now its reasonably quick and can be beaten in a few hours. 

the game has been fixed more than when it came out. ive looked at some reviews of this game when it first came out, and it appears a lot of issues that they had has been fixed. first of all, all microtransactions have been completely removed, which means you cant pay to get the best orcs and gear. i have not had any problems with bugs, so it seems that it has been mostly patched.  

onto the negatives. there really isnt that much that is bad about this game, except that sometimes it can feel like an absolute grind and get a little stale/boring/hard sometimes. also hunting down captains for your army, branding and dominating them, and repeating can get really boring sometimes. apart from that, theres not really anything else bad about this game

Ambushes and Rebellions are an inconvenience but at the same time can make the game so incredibly fun and to build and see your army in action is so enjoyable.

[h1] 💻 Description: [/h1]
Shadow of War nowadays is considered a [b] must [/b] have game for the diehard fans of the L.O.T.R. franchise. Even though it does not follow the story of the book, it describes an amazing adventure that can please even the most demanding players. Like its predecessor, Shadow of Mordor, the game is an epic story-driven action RPG game, where you utilize the power of the ring to its full potential. You fight and recruit armies of orcs that sometimes lead to epic battles, alliances and even betrayals. I enjoy the game in its highest difficulty since it adapts to the needs and the playstyle of the player.

[h1] 📖 Setting: [/h1]
[h3] Summary [/h3]
In Shadow of War, we are following Talion who is still infused with the ancient lord Celebrimbor, in their attempts to defeat the Dark Lord. This time, both travel to Mount Doom, where they forge a new Ring of Power, free of Sauron's corruption. Celebrimbor believes that the ring could be controlled, thus giving the wielder the ability to become the new King. Talion, who is not as interested in power, believes that Celebrimbor`s cause is just and they both decide to face Sauron and his Nazgul army in Mordor.

[h3] Development [/h3]
Shadow of War’s plot is a very delicate matter. As mentioned before, the game sometimes even completely breaks the lore, with the addition of characters like Shelob or the necromancer Zog etc… The fanbase was quite mad with some of the character progression, and the ending frustrated the hell out of the community as well. I agree with some statements, but not all of them are accurate for the reasons mentioned below. During your whole playthrough, the stronger emphasis is on the relation of Talion and Celembrimbor. Both begin to question their motives, as according to them, peace should be achieved differently. Celembrimbor’s opinion revolves around control, whereas Talion’s opinion around freedom. They both make valid points and force the player to question the morality of the cause, thus giving a neat touch to the interactive nature of the game.

[h1] 🕹️ Gameplay: [/h1]
The free-flow combat as well as its parkour aspect are both thrilling and mesmerizing at the same time. You can really ‘feel’ the power of the ring, as its combos and the surprising changes in certain ‘loved’ (by fans) abilities leave a special charm. The skill tree in my opinion is very well made and you can always switch playstyles to adapt to your different needs. Last but not least, the game revolves around repetition, grinding and careful planning, that’s why it takes time before Shadow of War reveals its true potential.

[h3] Progression [/h3]
I enjoyed the different unique personalities you encounter during your playthroughs, both by ncps and protagonists alike. The main cast express feelings that can be relatable to our own. Their interactions concerning death and defeat, approach those of the true world, thus making their conversation more memorable and appealing. Furthermore, their adventures are not l. The lore has been tweaked, depending on the needs of the game. Shelob, as we all know is not considered a valid character in the books. On the contrary, she is just a deadly spider. This is not the problem though. I personally welcome changes, as long as they are properly made. However, certain plot holes can not be unnoticed. For example, the ability to summon Balrogs by certain [b] special [/b] orcs was baffling to me. How the hell can an orc move a stick and at the same time revive a demon? At least explain the process. Overall, the plot is decent but I cannot compare it to its supreme [b] gameplay [/b] style.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2898678773
[h3] Scaling [/h3]
Equipment is primarily obtained by defeating Orc Captains and completing missions in Shadow of War. More difficult Orcs with higher rarities will drop gear that matches their rarity. You can upgrade the gear in the future, to match your level by coins or by completing a given [b] challenge [/b]. Legendary armour sets provide bonus stats, making Talion a deadly machine. During your adventures, you will encounter orcs with different specialities and levels. The rarity varies from common to legendary. What rarity Orcs spawn at, is out of your hands, however, it is worth tracking them down and claiming them as your own. That's why, look carefully at the nemesis system, since some orcs are very rare to encounter! Most of the time, higher tier Orcs will have some immunities and strengths. You can exploit them to your advantage, by tracking down a [b] Worm. [/b] For example, some orcs are immune to arrows etc... [b] Fortress captains [/b] tend to have more strengths than weaknesses, so be careful with that. Plan your ambush and get prepared before joining a fight.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2898677633
[h3] Nemesis system [/h3]
Even though certain aspects remain the same like in the original, some tweaks make it more interactive and thus more enjoyable than the previous game. It is high risk - high reward play in other words, so choose your approach carefully.

[b] You can send death threats [/b] 
In that way, you upgrade the gear quality obtained by an enemy orc. On the downside, the targeted champion comes well prepared, setting a trap of his own. The encounter becomes harder and you risk defeat. 

[b] Orc development [/b]
It feels like magic how each orc evolves, depending on whether you make them an ally, shame them or simply cut them into pieces. I humiliated an orc so many times, that after some point he became obsessed with me! Your actions now have consequences, so do not be surprised if an enemy or ally champion cheats death, just so that he can serve you or even worse, kill you.

[b] You can send ambushes [/b]
Ally champions join the fight. Encounters become easier, but you are risking the life of your companion. With this strategy, you can also level up your orcs!

[b] You can send spies to infiltrate the enemy lines [/b]
Your champion needs to defeat an enemy captain in the [b] the arena [/b] to take the enemy's place. There are lots of benefits to this technique. However, there are also some risks. If your orc is defeated in the arena or for some reason is caught by the fortress master. Then, it is guaranteed you will bid him fair well, as he gonna meet his maker (forever ???). If he wins though, he may even become the personal bodyguard of [b] the Fortress Captain. [/b]

It feels like magic how each orc evolves, depending on whether you make them an ally, shame them or simply cut them into pieces. I humiliated an orc so many times, that after some point he became obsessed with me! Your actions now have consequences...
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2898679507
[h1] 🗃️ Side Notes: [/h1]
Microtransactions were among the core problems of the game back in the day. However, this has changed making it more approachable and thus more appealing for us the players. The Blade of Galadriel DLC for me was a nuisance. Of all the protagonists Eltariel is the least favourable, but that’s another story for another review. The developers expanded the universe without reason. They tried to milk the already beloved concept, without putting much thought into the consequences. That was a bad move and they paid it in the end dearly.

[h1] 📋 Verdict: [/h1]
For the first time after so many years, we the L.O.T.R. nerds finally got a game that truly deserves our attention and respect! Came for the plot, stayed for the combat...

-In memory of Garl Warmonger ([b] Legendary [/b]) orc.

[h1]Gravewalker! I died defending your fortress...just wanted to let you know I'm back![/h1]
[b]NOTE:[/b] The storyline in this game is not canon - take that into account when reading this and/or playing the game.

Middle-earth: Shadow of War is the sequel to Shadow of Mordor (they really could have done better with the naming to avoid confusion) and carries on the story of Talion of Gondor. In true sequel style, it really is more of the first game: more abilities, more places to go, more things to see, more orcs to kill. While this is not necessarily a bad thing, some might find the similarity/familiarity a negative, although I would argue more of something good it not a bad thing when it is not overused. Due to the story not being canon, it can be jarring if you care about such things or are familiar with the universe, but this ultimately does not detract from enjoyment or ruin the experience. It is still a well designed game: the world/areas are amazingly varied and properly beautiful, from lush forests to snow to lava filled landscapes, incredibly well optimised to run smoothly and a well-managed ride through an original story (even if it is a little far-fetched at times). The voice acting and characterisation deserves special mention and praise: many of the lines will have you literally laughing and the banter is so well written - this is a game with very high production values and it shows at every turn.

The undoubted star of the show however is the Nemesis system. Introduced in Shadow of Mordor and perfected (as well as patented) here, the Nemesis system essentially adds a layer of persistent AI to each encounter. An enemy will remember if they have run from you or killed you, remark on it, adapt accordingly and keep you off balance. There is also every chance that an orc you kill will suddenly ambush you at some point in the future, miraculously resurrected and with a vengeance. This enhancement goes a very long way to keeping each encounter fresh and engaging, rather than just being a copy paste battle. Fortresses are the other major new feature: each has an overlord, with war chiefs underneath and the resulting captains. Conquering the fortress is key to progressing and needed to take control of territories in Mordor: while most are fairly similar (excepting the orcs manning them), it is still challenging enough if you just dive right in without any preparation beforehand.

There is an online (asynchronous) aspect as well to the game in the form of Conquests. Essentially, you are able to assault other players and their fortresses by downloading a copy of their setup and going up against it. While not in real time, this is an enjoyable way to pass a few hours and a good test to see how good your defense/offense is by attacking another person. Each conquest gets progressively tougher until they are virtually impossible. This can be avoided completely but it is a welcome addition to a game which already has a lot of different content in it. The DLC is also worthwhile, especially the Baranor campaign as it plays completely different from the rest of the game and comes as a welcome change of pace and gameplay, while still being entertaining.

The gameplay can get a little stale sometimes, but the Nemesis system does a superb job of keeping you hooked and entertained, while ensuring each encounter is a fresh challenge. In general, if you enjoyed the first title you can expect similar enjoyment from this. Conversely, if you did not enjoy the first game, you may find this is not to your liking either. Either way, I would highly recommend it to action game fans.

Played on Windows 11 Pro x64 without any issues.

P.S. If your hardware can handle it, the High Resolution Texture Pack is highly recommended - performance remains buttery smooth even with the upgraded visuals.

One of the best games I've ever played, the nemesis system in full effect takes your single player experience to the next level. Plenty of unique weapon and armor bonuses to boost your character and form your playstyle on top of the multiple combat techniques available in the skill tree. With these two elements combined you have the perfect recipe for a custom playstyle that you form. On top of that, you're rewarded for grinding in standard forms of xp and gear but on top of that, the nemesis system makes that grinding so much more enjoyable because you encounter so many different orcs (uruk if you prefer the lotr jargon) that have unique traits, with fun gimmicks, and of course you're 'punished' for dying by the orc who killed you getting stronger. But thats where the true game begins. see dying doesn't mean a loss of progress, it means a new story develops, your nemesis develops. Suddenly No'Ruk the young becomes No'Ruk the Black, he gets a new sword, its Dark from your blood. You encounter him on accident because he hunts you, using his new sword he poisons you, killing you again. and again. and now he's No'Ruk the Demon. You finally kill him, taking that sweet sweet revenge, and you gain your own new sword, a legendary set sword that has a chance to poison on hit and a higher crit chance against poisoned enemies. And this is just one of the many many orcs in your game and no 2 are the same. You'll spend hours making your way through a map clearing orcs, finishing objectives, leveling, gathering loot, collectibles, all the while fighting named orcs and before you know it you'll find yourself up at 4am on a tuesday morning when the hell the sun went down! And of course there's the story which you don't need to be a lord of the rings giganerd or anything as it happens to be an origin story that tells you who you are, why you're there and what you're doing. playing the first game isn't a requirement because it has a recap in the game for you. I owned this game on console before pc and have played through the game 3 times and on my 4th playthrough now. With combat similar to the batman arkham series and movement similar to the old school assassin's creed games, the game feels fluid to play and combat has plenty of depth, with how you approach orcs being different depending on their traits. 

And that's just the first part of the game.

see once you reach a certain part in the story you get a new power. I won't spoil it but trust me on this: you'll open up a whole new world. all of that time you spent in the first part was preparing you for the second, utilizing you're skills and the nemesis system you'll write a new chapter in your story and the enemy's story. the second part is truly where the game begins and where the fun truly awaits. and just when you think the game has shown you everything it has to offer

the 3rd part shows up. and this time its endless. I wont say anymore because it's truly a surprise worth playing for. 



Now if you're wondering where the bad is, there are certain trivial things like sometimes terrain is not climable but there once was a legitimate criticism of the games postgame. originally intended to be a primarily online mode, the endgame and certain elements throughout the game were the subject of controversy on launch. see you were able to buy advantages towards xp gain, weapons, armor, basically time savers. and other things but that would be spoiler. after such criticism, the developers went in and fixed everything by removing the microtransactions and instead making anything relevant to gameplay obtainable through gameplay, restoring the balance offset by bigger wallets and truly making an even playing field and the best part is you don't have to play online if you don't want too! you can ignore all of it (because while cool it isnt necassary to your enjoyment) and not feel like you're missing out.

I'm really on the fence about voting no for this game but after sitting with my thoughts for a bit I think this is deserved.  The game takes a story that was enjoyable and makes the characters idiots.  Every plot advancement (if you can call it those) relies on the main characters being smacked by a stupid stick.  It's very frustrating to take what was a good bond between the two main characters and throw it all out the window.  Characters constantly reinforce that Orcs cannot be trusted but are shocked that Orcs constantly betray them.  It's a very tiring experience.

The combat camera and controls are improved from Shadow of Mordor but then unnecessarily complicated by weird if not worthless combat upgrades and a weapon upgrade system that tries to be interesting but ultimately just gets ignored.  Taking castles is interesting the first one or two times but then just becomes exhausting to move the story forward (maybe not necessary but feels like it is.  Even then taking a castle doesn't establish complete control over an area).

There are some highlights to this game but overall, if you're here for the story... well.... fly you fools.  If you want to siege other players castles and enjoy chopping off orcs heads then look no further!

While inferior in many points to the first game in the saga, Shadow of War is decent enough. The endgame is grindy, and frankly unnecessary, but the end of Talion's journey was tasteful and meaningful.

As far as I'm concerned, this is Tolkien fanfiction, none of this should be attempted to make sense in the real story, but as far as fanfiction goes, it's pretty good.

Review By ChatGPT.
Middle-earth: Shadow of War is an action role-playing game developed by Monolith Productions and published by Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment. It is the sequel to the highly-acclaimed game Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor, and is set in the world of J.R.R. Tolkien's The Lord of the Rings.

In Middle-earth: Shadow of War, players control Talion, a ranger of Gondor who is bonded with the wraith of the Elven lord Celebrimbor. Together, they must confront the dark lord Sauron and his armies, who seek to conquer Middle-earth. The game features a vast open-world environment, filled with iconic locations and characters from the world of Middle-earth.

One of the standout features of Middle-earth: Shadow of War is its combat system, which combines the fast-paced action of a hack-and-slash game with the strategic depth of a role-playing game. Players can use a wide range of abilities and weapons to defeat their enemies, and must carefully plan their attacks and defenses in order to emerge victorious. The game also features a number of powerful enemies known as "Nemeses", who have their own unique strengths and weaknesses and provide a challenging combat experience.

Another highlight of Middle-earth: Shadow of War is its "Nemesis System", which generates unique enemies for the player to face based on their actions and choices in the game. This means that no two playthroughs of the game are the same, and players must adapt to the changing landscape of Middle-earth in order to survive.

In addition to its single-player campaign, Middle-earth: Shadow of War also includes a multiplayer mode known as "Shadow Wars". In this mode, players must defend their fortresses against waves of enemy attackers, and can recruit powerful allies to help them in battle. This mode adds an additional layer of depth and replayability to the game, and provides a fun and challenging experience for players who want to test their skills against others.

One of the criticisms of Middle-earth: Shadow of War is its repetitive side quests, which often involve completing the same tasks over and over again in different locations. While these quests can be enjoyable at first, they can become tedious and boring after a while. Additionally, some players have criticized the game's use of microtransactions, which allow players to purchase in-game items and abilities with real money.

Despite these flaws, however, Middle-earth: Shadow of War is a solid action-RPG that offers a rich and immersive experience for fans of the genre. Its combat system is deep and engaging, and its open-world environment is filled with interesting characters and locations to explore. While it may not be as groundbreaking as its predecessor, Middle-earth: Shadow of War is still a must-play for fans of The Lord of the Rings and action-RPGs in general.

It's a recommendation, with a few caveats.

The good:
Fighting and exploiting the weaknesses of Orcs is fun. No denying that.
Lots of options to approach encounters.
The Orcs have a lot of personality, and even dialogue is rarely reused.

The bad:
The story. I didn't really care for whatever Protagonist Guy wants to do, he's just a generic grizzled hero type.

The ugly:
The game and its mechanics outstay their welcome. I played half of the game back in late 2019 and finished it yesterday, late 2022. There was a big break in between and after finally finishing off the last bit of the story mode I remembered why. The orcs manipulation mechanics are fun, but the RNG involved in getting them where you want them to be are not. Sometimes they have rocks in their skulls - particularly when there's a friendly Olog gang present - and sometimes they just one-shot their opponents in the fight club.
Further, the last bit of the game has you defend conquered regions, which wouldn't be so bad if 1) friendly orcs didn't die like moths in an active volcano, 2) sieges occurred in any region that actually has defenses instead of the ones conquered in the early game and 3) if the orcs would continue fighting if you go down while you're trying to help allies get back up. After the nth time of a "this orc somehow prevents you from getting back up when knocked down even though the story's boss does let you do that a few times" making me go re-conquer a fortress I'd had enough and I'm glad I'm done with the game because at this stage I'm going to need another 3 years before I can consider going back for the postgame.

Great game, super worth it especially for the hugely discounted price it often goes for. 

The story is fairly easy to follow and there's not too much of it. However, it concludes really nicely.

But let's be honest, you buy this mainly for the gameplay, which is really solid and you can spend a ton of time just hanging around the open world enjoying the combat for the sake of it.

The only annoying thing about the game are the damn orc captain "intros" (where every named orc has something to say when you encounter them). It's a cool concept at first but after a while you just want to skip them because they interrupt the gameplay flow and there's no official setting for it, only some workarounds which may break things. Especially end-game, when you  face multiple, like 6+, captains at once and everyone has something to say, plus interrupts showing you that someone died, plus interrupts that someone got enraged and you can go grab yourself a drink because the mini cutscenes just keep going.

This game is criminally cheap right now, so if you've played and enjoyed the first game, 'Shadow Of Mordor', then you really owe it to yourself to play this one. Especially at its current, dirt cheap price (80% off as of the time of this writing until 30th November 2022) for both the standard and the Definitive Edition. Imagine paying less than a meal's worth for a Definitive Edition, now that's not very common nowadays with how companies are charging for their games, even with a sale.

I played this game before on my PS4 and finished it back then but decided to pick it up during this sale period for a nostalgic revisit plus, have I mentioned how stupidly cheap it is?? A personal bonus for me was not knowing that you can now change game audio language so I get to replay this game with a really good Japanese dub! A huge plus ontop of the revisit for a JRPG fan. I'm not a weeb I swear xd

Also, it needs to be mentioned that this is the most well optimized game I have ever played on PC. Like holy shit, my 1660s has 6GB of VRAM but it can still run this game at everything set to Ultra along with the High Resolution Texture Pack (Ultra settings for textures) without my frames eating crap for breakfast despite being 8k~GB/6GB. It's really impressive how Monolith Productions optimized this game.

EDIT: Forgot to mention, I had already started playing before they decided to remove loot boxes back then due to backlash

Expands really well on the systems of the first game, with the free DLC textures it looks really good. The captains are a lot more varied and interesting/entertaining and there doesn't seem to be as many gathering quests as the first game. Inventory system lets you pick your play style a bit more. Only downgrade feels like it would be splitting up a lot of the powers from the first game into different upgrades on existing powers. Limits feeling too powerful, but can be frustrating when you are used to playing with every ability unlocked.

If you are a LotR fan, I recommend this. If you're interested in assassin type action, I recommend this. If you didn't play its prequel, play that first.

Story is up to interpretation. You can either say it's utterly redundant because we know how the LotR story goes and this leads up to it. On the other hand, it can also be the entire reason why it's amazing, in a "doing the right thing at all costs" way.

Gameplay is overall pretty great, assuming you end up enjoying the gameplay loop, otherwise it can get old fast. It's no power fantasy because even a motley gang of orcs can kill you but if you play smart it's a blast.

A perfect game for lovers of The Lord of the Rings series, full of action and well-prepared characters, with a visual that perfectly suits this type of games and a wide variety of mechanics that draw you for hours in this fabulous universe... 10/10

This is a great game and I highly recommend it. Having said that... the only thing I don't like is that all the Orcs seem to be  members of the local amateur community theater troupe. I say that because every time you encounter one of them, he launches into an unskippable, cringe-inducing monologue, delivered (of course) in the required-by-law British accent. I like the idea of giving these guys some individual personalities, but making them all master thespians is not the way to go. Just mute the game during the speeches, and you'll enjoy the other 99.5% of the game.
