So firstly, before you even bother reading reviews of this game, you should play the first one. It's really well made and contextualizes almost everything you see in this one. Also, this game's story doesn't really have legs and most characters are totally static, so you probably won't enjoy it if you haven't seen what comes before.

I finally beat this game, having previously made a few attempts to get into it that ultimately ended in boredom and frustration. It's not the smoothest experience, and it has many shortcomings (probably more than the first game), but I did have fun in the end and I don't regret spending the 40-ish hours it took me to beat the base game. Shadow of War is a continuation / expansion of Shadow of Mordor, and what was lost in charm and polish was gained in nuance and variety. I'll elaborate on what I mean about "continuation / expansion" because that's a little nebulous, and I'll keep coming back to the first game as a point of comparison because you should really play it if you want to play this one. 

The story picks up right where Shadow of Mordor left off, with a little bit of a recap cutscene in case you're an IDIOT and didn't play the first game before playing this one, which you should do if you haven't. Talion and Celebrimbor are back to the bickering and bitching they did lots of near the start of the previous game, and while I totally understand that since the pressure of their situation has let up a bit they might not feel the urge to work together as cleanly as they were doing, it still feels like the relationship they developed collapsed overnight, and this especially left me feeling disappointed. Shelob is a sexy lady now[spoiler] and totally not also a horrifying monstrosity[/spoiler], which is very sexy and cool and salvaged the start of the game in a way, since she has some motivations that aren't really elaborated upon until later and it makes for some interesting speculation and intrigue. After some plot stuff, Talion goes to Minas Ithil to make friends with other humans, and Celebrimbor is very upset about this because [spoiler]he's sorta toxic[/spoiler]. All of the side characters introduced here, aside from Shelob, are pretty 2-D and boring to interact with, and don't get any more interesting for the rest of the story. They're sort of like cardboard cutout versions of side characters in the previous game (have you played it yet? I sure hope so). Hopefully that summary helps to illustrate what I mean by SoW being a continuation of SoM. There's not as much new stuff happening as I would hope, and it's all concepts from the first game being stretched as far as possible. It feels like the writers were reluctant to make a plot happen and maybe they just wanted to write dialogue and not make a video game story at all, and it's very much not what I would like in a video game (to be clear: I want a video game story in my video game). Look: I get that a lot of stories write themselves, but counterpoint: have you ever played a JRPG? There is NO COASTING there, it is twists and turns all the way.

Talion controls pretty similarly, but this time he can double jump and sprint whenever he wants [spoiler]go white boy, go[/spoiler]. Stealth is even more trivial now that you can stay above the orcs at all times, but let's be honest, this isn't Metal Gear; Talion is hidden when he wants to be and seen when he wants to be, for the most part. The dodge roll is way more powerful in this game, and gives you a solid second's worth of i-frames, which is nice, but now dodge rolling is absolutely essential for a lot of fights and breaks up the flow of combat. I think it would be better if the dodge roll was a shorter animation requiring tighter timing, so that way you could at least get back to hitting things faster. There are a few extra abilities that didn't exist in the first game, and a lot of your previous ones are unlocked very early on, which is why you should play the first game, to learn how to use those abilities and work them into your muscle memory. The controls get pretty cluttered in this game, and I had to switch from a controller to keyboard and mouse because I couldn't handle all the weird funky multi-button inputs and kept making stupid mistakes because of it. Passive abilities are now presented as upgrades for your base kit that you spend skill points on, and only one passive can be used at a time per active ability. There's more strategy involved in leveling Talion up, and it's possible to screw yourself out of a victory because you chose crap abilities, which I appreciate and think lends more weight to the player's decisions. There are some disappointing passives, things like adding an elemental effect to certain moves, which I think is a little lazy; though it's useful in gameplay, it isn't very imaginative. Fewer abilities are unlocked by beating missions now, which I miss. The old rune system has been replaced with gear unlocks, which is definitely lamer, and their effects are far less interesting. There are some "legendary" sets of equipment that are meant to help you specialize, but most of their set bonuses suck girthy uruk-hai cock[spoiler] like a champ![/spoiler] and the only set I found interesting was the machine one, which blows up orcs that you kill, and sets you on fire, AND it lets you call in suicide bombers, which is fucking epic and I am a huge fan. Visually, all of these sets look pretty similar and don't really evoke the imagery of their respective origins in a compelling or thoughtful way. There are also these gems that you can affix for a totally bland upgrade like +16% damage or +10% lifesteal, which again, are very boring and make me sad. 

So if you are reading this and wondering, "hey, why did this guy give Middle Earth: Shadow of War a positive review when all of his praise comes with criticism?" here's your answer: THE ORCS. There is a reason that the soulless suit fucks at WB patented the nemesis system, and it is not a good one, but the nemesis system, and the content related to it, is excellent. For starters, there are so many different hair styles, skin tones, body types, tatoos, armors, injuries, weapons, eyes, etc., etc., ETC. orcs can have, and now even the grunts have a fair amount of variety. Honestly it puts The Sims to shame. Now a lot of these options look similar or are derivative of each other, but you'll never look at two orcs and think they look identical, regardless. My only criticism regarding how the orcs look is that I think there should be a handsome, pretty orc somewhere just to shake up the formula. There's a lot more variety in encounters, too; I've had a captain ambush me right after I got intel on him and comment on the fact that I learned his weaknesses, captains will have different dialogue each time you encounter them, rather than just playing the same lines on repeat encounters like the previous game (which you've played, right?), some captains will seek you out at every opportunity and try to become the bane of your existence. It's really staggering how much variety there is; this system that used to be cool but repetitive has finally come into its own, and is finally fun to engage with on every level. There are now "advanced classes" which show up independent of an orc's weapon type, so you can now get a Defender orc that's also a Berserker and charges into battle rather than hiding behind his shield and waddling around; on the other hand you can get a Savage that's also a Tank, who attacks infrequently but uses crowd control abilities to lock down the opposition while he heals. There's even an entire class of captain that will raise a posse and hunt you down if you're in the same region as them, which can be both very fun and nerve-wracking.

I'd love to keep going, but Steam has a character limit for reviews and I am very close to it now. 
TL;DR: Play Shadow of Mordor, and if you like the orcs, play Shadow of War as well.

An excellent game. My problem with the previous game was that combats are not very challenging so that you need not to take care of the Nemesis system and special abilities. They have improved it a lot. Being tough enough, orc armies try to defy your control in many different ways. Some uruk-hais even look semi-invincible at first glance. You need cunning. Also the story of SoW feels like being "LotR" while SoM was a bit simple (anti) hero story.

Two DLCs add unique and fun experiences to the base game though both felt short a little. Maybe that's just because I wanted to play MORE. My playtime is 40+ hrs for the base game without completing lots of weapon challenges. 40 hrs for two DLCs. It's enough, I guess.
Especially the 2nd expansion The Desolation of Mordor is pretty good. Which is parkour stealth TPaction with perma-death. I believe this style is so promising for the future.

If you've enjoyed Peter Jackson's LotR and (the assassin's creed style) quest-driven action RPGs, the game is worth trying. A note you should know is that you might not want to play it just after the previous one as the two games share many elements.
